IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative. DNA polymerase theta (Polq), a DNA repair factor important for microhomology-mediated end-joining (MMEJ) of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs), has recently been validated as a drug target in BRCA1/2 mutated cancers in pre-clinical studies. Early stage Polq inhibitors (Polqi), however, have significant deficiencies which may limit their efficacy and development in clinical studies. Our collaborative team (Pomerantz, Johnson, and Childers labs) plans to develop a novel chemical entity as a potentially best-in-class Polqi by employing an innovative prodrug strategy which is expected to prolong its exposure and activity in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Maintaining glucose control (i.e. HbA1c <7.0%) reduces the risk of microvascular complications in T2DM patients; currently approximately one half of patients with T2DM fail to maintain the target for glucose control. Thus, therapeutic regimens that produce a durable reduction in the HbA1c is an unmet need for the management of patients with T2DM. The current grant proposal is a comparative effectiveness study of the efficacy and durability of HbA1c reduction by two initial combination therapies in patients with new onset diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In eukaryotes, the attachment of ubiquitin to histone proteins regulates diverse processes that include transcription, DNA damage repair, and genome stability. To understand how these processes are controlled, we will design sensor molecules to observe ubiquitin attachment to specific histones and to measure their locations and dynamics in the cell nucleus. The strategies and tools we develop will be broadly useful in basic cancer research and will generate new diagnostic capabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Food insecurity is present in 11% of the US population, but disparately higher at 33% in the US territory of Puerto Rico that is simultaneously experiencing social and cardiovascular-related inequities, compounded by vulnerability to climate change events. The lack of systematic, longitudinal studies has hindered understanding of the complex mechanistic pathways connecting food insecurity to cardiometabolic disease, posited to operate through biological, diet-related, or psychosocial factors, nor their interconnections with food procurement or climate-change indicators. To address this, we will extend and enrich the existing rigorous and comprehensive data from the highly-productive Puerto Rico Observational Study of Psychosocial, Environmental, and Chronic disease Trends (PROSPECT), a longitudinal cohort of adults in PR, to generate compelling evidence elucidating the mechanisms between food insecurity and cardiometabolic disease, and to inform programs and policy that can alleviate these inequities in PR, while serving as a model for other populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because a detailed understanding of the role of Aldh2 and alcohol-induced epithelial cell injury will fundamentally advance the fields of alcohol-related diseases, both benign and malignant. The proposed model systems and findings will provide a platform for new avenues of translational applications related to head-and-neck and esophageal squamous cell carcinomas and other alcohol-induced human pathologies. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burden of human diseases.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative  Given that only 2-7% of U.S. health care spending is devoted to primary care, a chronically underfunded but foundational part of the delivery system, states across the country are increasingly adopting policies to increase primary care spending, hoping to slow total spending and improve the quality of care. Four states— Colorado, Delaware, Oregon, and Rhode Island—have enacted legislation or regulations to explicitly raise the percent of health care spending spent on primary care, but the effects of these models on primary care access and continuity, total health care spending, utilization (in and outside of primary care), and quality of care remain largely unknown. This gap in knowledge is increasingly detrimental as many additional states are now debating or designing similar legislation to increase primary care spending; this project addresses this key gap through rigorous quasi-experimental evaluations of the Colorado, Delaware, Oregon, and Rhode Island models, using newer statistical methodology in matching and weighting to improve causal inference.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluations of Increasing State Investments in Primary Care: Effects on Health Care Spending, Utilization, and Quality

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Our project, focused on celiac disease and Crohn’s disease, takes a combined genomic and epigenomic approach to pinpoint and understand the mechanisms of action of genetic variants that regulate critical genes specifically in intestinal epithelial cells or in cells of the immune system, and thereby confer increased risk of these common and difficult to treat gastrointestinal conditions. Our research team includes investigators with expertise in molecular genetics, intestinal epithelial cell biology, bioinformatics and statistical genetics, and clinical aspects of these diseases. Using intestinal organoid cultures from biopsies, with and without exposure to disease relevant external stimuli, whole-genome and targeted DNA methylation sequencing, and CRISPR- Cas9 manipulations in tissue culture, we expect that our research will elucidate cell type-specific biological pathways, and gene-environment interactions, that drive the onset and progression of these diseases, with implications for improved prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Low-value care (LVC), defined as care where harms or costs outweigh the benefits, is common (nearly half of U.S. patients may receive >1 LVC service every year). LVC can result in physical harm from the service itself, unnecessary follow-up tests/procedures, and needless out-of-pocket costs. The research proposed is a foundational step toward accurately measuring LVC, identifying which LVC services should be prioritized for reduction, and assessing the effectiveness and possible unintended consequences of a program to reduce LVC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work benefits public health by systematically assessing the dynamics of the computations un- derlying perceptual decisions using multiple sensory systems and how decisions take into account the uncer- tainty of sensory information, prior knowledge, and changes over time in the environment as well as in the sen- sory systems themselves. A variety of medical conditions can impact both the reliability and accuracy of senso- ry information (e.g., macular degeneration, amblyopia, stroke). The proposed research will improve our under- standing of how sensory inputs from multiple modalities are combined so as to optimize a perceptual decision or a motor plan, and thus can serve to help in the design of rehabilitative plans and sensory-substitution de- vices when sensory input is disrupted (change in bias, gain and/or variability) by disease or other health-relat- ed conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Relevance We propose to understand how the metabolic state of hair follicle stem cells controls their quiescence and ability to initiate the hair cycle. We will use gain and loss of function approaches to target particular metabolic nodes to understand how they promote or inhibit stem cell activation or the ability of stem cells to initiate tumorigenesis. This work will not only uncover the role metabolic regulation plays in normal tissue, but also how this regulation can influence tumor initiation and wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As the population of the United States ages, increased incidence of age-associated dementias including Alzheimer's disease will become a major public health issue. Interventions that could delay the onset of cognitive decline would have a major public health impact. These studies will help determine mechanisms by which short-term administration of estrogens near the time of menopause could exert lasting benefits to the cognitive health of women as they age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Smith-Magenis Syndrome (SMS) patients exhibit circadian rhythm disturbance and unruly behavior, such as self-injury, making life difficult for patients and their families. Unfortunately, mouse models of SMS are nocturnal and lack melatonin, a key modulator of sleep, limiting their utility for elucidating the role of the causative gene RAI1 and for therapeutic inventions. The proposed research aims to develop the first diurnal animal model of RAI1 deficiency by deleting RAI1 in diurnal Nile grass rats, which will allow a better understanding of RAI1 and will lead to the development of evidence-based treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term objective of this collaboration is to discover the essential logic and underlying molecular mechanisms that drive planar cell polarity (PCP) signaling, a highly conserved pathway that is a critical component of normal heart development. Previously applied experimental approaches have proven unable to untangle the interlocking feedback loops that are thought to underlie PCP signaling. We describe novel genetic, biochemical, imaging and computational modeling approaches that will reveal both the underlying molecular logic and mechanistic basis for this critical component of normal heart development.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the revolutionary discovery of immunotherapy as a highly effective treatment for cancer, the immune system, and specifically the interaction between CD8 T cells and HLA molecules, has emerged as an essential player in cancer treatment, but its role in early tumorigenesis is understudied. Germline HLA heterozygosity been shown to improve tumor immunogenicity and thus response to immunotherapy as well as lower susceptibility to viral infection, but its role in cancer risk is unknown. This proposed research will use large, diverse clinical and genomic datasets and an in vivo model of HLA-mediated immune surveillance to implicate germline HLA zygosity in cancer risk, potentially identifying an important biomarker for increased cancer screening, and provide insights into the mechanism of HLA-mediated immune surveillance of early tumors to guide treatment and prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Traditional methods for estimating exposure-hearing relations, which typically use pure-tone average hearing thresholds to define the outcome, may not comprehensively capture useful information encompassed by the shape of the audiogram across the range of frequencies; since existing statistical methods are insufficient for analysis of the audiogram shape data, we will develop analytical methods for estimating exposure-hearing relations when the outcomes are hearing phenotypes characterized by audiogram shapes. In addition, current analytic methods rely on either pure-tone audiometry data or self-reported hearing data as the outcome, but not both; these two outcome measures are in fact complementary, and we will develop statistical methods for integrating the pure-tone audiometric data and self-reported data. We will apply the hearing data analysis methods to the Conservation of Hearing Study within the Nurses’ Health Study II, the Medical University of South Carolina Hearing Study, and the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES), and user-friendly software developed to implement all new methods will be made publicly available.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vancomycin is the most common first-line empiric coverage for suspected late-onset sepsis in preterm infants, even though (1) national guidelines recommend against such use, (2) such use offers no added advantage, and (3) is linked to a rise in infections with vancomycin resistant pathogens. Using a mixed-methods approach we will implement a vancomycin-reducing protocol in preterm infants across 13 neonatal intensive care units in two large healthcare networks. By critically investigating factors influencing the implementation of the protocol and reduction of unnecessary vancomycin use in this multi-center study, we will provide a road map for the broader implementation of vancomycin reducing protocols across NICUs in the United States
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementing vancomycin-sparing regimens in preterm infants
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: POJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common and the most lethal primary malignant brain tumor. Immunotherapeutic strategies represent promising new therapeutic tools as they seek to promote an effective antitumor immune response against a patient’s own tumor. In this proposal, we take advantage of the relatively immune-rich microenvironment of RAF-driven glioma to investigate novel determinants of the glioma-associated immune response, including microglia, macrophages, and T cells.

PHR: Narrative: MEF2 is a protein the controls many processes in the body including muscle and neural development, and mutations affecting MEF2 can result in human disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVES This project aims to translate a new cancer imaging biomarker of cell proliferation ([18F]FMAU) to the clinic. This biomarker could provide high-accuracy assessment of tumor response to treatment, improving the care of cancer patients, better guiding therapy selection (when multiple options are available), and providing a powerful research tool for discovery and development of new cancer treatments. Through a synergistic academic- industrial partnership, the overall goal of this project is to make this biomarker more widely available via novel droplet radiochemistry technology and to set the stage to enable wide clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mpox is a zoonotic infectious disease caused by Mpox virus, which has been endemic in Africa and has recently caused an ongoing global health emergency involving 100 countries around the world. There are currently no FDA-approved drugs that target Mpox virus, and while there are some options available to use repurposed drugs, these antivirals have a low barrier to resistance, resulting in a lack of efficacious drugs for the treatment and prevention of Mpox virus. The goal of this project is to utilize exceptional expertise in drug discovery, high- throughput assay development, screening technologies, and mechanism of action studies towards the discovery of innovative antivirals that target Mpox virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will first develop the automated image processing pipeline needed to convert inhale/exhale CT image pairs into perfusion, ventilation, and VQ functional information using state-of-the-art deep learning methods. We will employ the functional information to develop machine learning models for quantifying COPD severity and predicting 5-year survival. Unlike existing approaches, our novel CT-derived functional imaging VQ markers are robust to patient breathing effort, and therefore have the potential to better inform both clinical decision making and assessments of therapeutic efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop a miniaturized imaging device that can record brain activity in high resolution over the cortex in freely-behaving animals. Using this device, we will study how multiple regions of the brain function together in mice during behavioral tasks and how the visual cortex in head-unrestrained macaques mediates visual perception. This new imaging device will enable research on how different brain regions support behavior, and on mechanisms and treatments of various neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE The XKR proteins play a central role in the transport of the phosphatidylserine lipid to the external surface of dying (apoptotic) cells, where it acts as the key cue for their recognition and clearance by immune surveillance cells. Despite recent progress in elucidating the structure of XKR proteins, our ability to recognize their functions in human physiology and to design targeted pharmacological interventions is limited by our poor understanding of the mechanisms that regulate their activity. The goal of our project is to overcome these limitations by determining how the XKR proteins transport these lipids and how their activity is regulated in cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Biological function - including respiration, biocatalysis and programmed cell death - rely on charge transfer reactions within the cell. Extracellular charge transfer, in contrast, underlies the function of some bacteria and bacterial colonies, yet is very poorly understood. Our study uses theory, modeling, and simulation to describe the nature of extracellular charge transfer, with the aims of informing future strategies to combat bacterial pro- liferation and to interface living and abiotic structures for applications in biomolecular sensing, biomedicine, and biotechnology.

PHR: Project Narrative This study represents a novel and significant advance for air pollution epidemiology through characterizing the dose of BC in human respiratory system as well as its dose-response relationships with lung aging and mortality. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Short interspersed elements are a type of genomic repeats that can form double stranded RNA capable of activating the immune system in a way similar to that of a viral state. We will study the role of these repeats in idiopathic inflammatory myopathies, which can lead to new insights into the molecular nature of disease and ultimately lead to better therapeutics. In the long term, this can also lead to a better understanding of autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While there are effective, widely available methods for cervical cancer screening, there are no such screening programs for human papillomavirus (HPV)-related oropharyngeal cancer (OPC), even though there are more cases per year of OPC than there are of cervical cancer. Exciting new ways of detection are using peripheral blood collected in a clinical setting; however, if remote self-sampling could be reliably used instead, it would offer a non-invasive alternative for screening the general population and for post-treatment monitoring of patients with HPV-related OPC. Screening using saliva, oral rinse, and urine sampling 1) offers the advantage of making mailed sample collection possible, 2) increases the likelihood of regular screening, even for those living in remote geographic areas or with limited health care access, and 3) potentially prevents late diagnosis of OPC which requires more aggressive treatment with serious lifelong consequences and early non-cancer mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will investigate the mechanisms regulating the production and activity of platelets, the main mediators of blood clotting. We aim to understand how platelet generation is altered during aging. The findings will inform strategies for mitigating platelet-related disorders such as stroke and thrombosis that frequently plague the elderly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Stochastic fate specification, in which a cell randomly chooses between two or more fates, is critical for diversifying visual photoreceptors, olfactory receptors, motor neurons, immune cells, and stem cells. Breakdowns in these regulatory mechanisms contribute to vision disorders, anosmia, autism, immunodeficiencies, and lymphoma, emphasizing the need to investigate the molecular underpinnings of this biological process. Using the fly eye as a model, we will characterize the roles of transcriptional and chromatin dynamics and cell-cell signaling in stochastic photoreceptor fate specification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiac regeneration post-injury is critically dependent on cardiomyocyte (CM) proliferation and the involvement of multiple biological processes. Our present proposal emphasizes using modified mRNA (modRNA) based delivery of a PSAT1 to induce robust CM proliferation and activate its pleiotropic effects during the cardiac remodeling process. The project will investigate the efficacy of global or cell-specific PSAT1 modRNA approach for reversal of acute or chronic post-MI heart failure (Aim 1), uncover the novel molecular signaling mechanisms by which PSAT1 induces CM proliferation and role of serine synthesis pathway in CM proliferation and cardiac regeneration in MI model (Aim 2 and 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Older adults with Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias along with other chronic conditions face substantial care coordination challenges due to their cognitive impairments and complex care needs, making them particularly vulnerable to the negative outcomes associated with care fragmentation. This proposal uses social network analysis and electronic health record data to uncover the interdependent network of relationships between clinicians involved in coordinating care across settings and over time, as well as the contribution of such clinician relationship networks to disparities in health outcomes for this population. Greater transparency in these networks has the potential to inform and empower patients, assist clinicians, and optimize health system operations to advance healthcare quality, efficiency, and equity for patients vulnerable to care fragmentation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver transplantation is the only definitive therapy available for treatment of inherited metabolic diseases affecting the liver, but it has severe drawbacks. We aim to directly compare different delivery approaches for introducing gene editing reagents into hepatocytes combined with a novel approach for selecting edited hepatocytes in the liver using transient administration of acetaminophen as a novel treatment for familial hypercholesterolemia. We will study the repopulation potential, capacity of edited hepatocytes to overcome immunity to gene editing reagents in the liver, and extent that our approach reverses the disease in a mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insulin resistance and endothelial dysfunction are major etiological factors in the development of obesity, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular disease (CVD). Extracellular vesicles (EVs) have emerged as potential mediators of vascular insulin resistance, and this project will examine the role of plasma EVs from lean normal glucose tolerant (NGT), obese NGT and obese T2D participants on EV uptake and vascular function in culture and on mouse resistance/microcirculatory blood vessels before and after insulin-stimulation. We will also address differential roles of insulin signaling proteins and miRNA/small RNAs that are carried by EVs across these groups before and after exercise training to discern clinical relevance of an insulin-mediated EV mechanism that has potential to identify novel mechanisms for prevention/treatment of chronic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This research addresses a critical, relevant public health concern as it will provide a platform to develop new antivirals that can target type I fusion proteins, which we are applying to the highly pathogenic viruses SARS- CoV-2, RSV, Nipah virus and MERS. This new class of antivirals is based on small, highly stable computationally designed proteins. A tight coupling between computation and experiments will also allow the development of data-driven protein design algorithms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease with variable presentation of symptoms and inconsistent response to therapy. Here, we propose to use highly innovative single cell epigenomic, transcriptomic, and proteomic analyses to map the cell-type-specific molecular and genetic basis underlying SLE heterogeneity. We expect our findings to shed light on the pathogenic states in specific immune cell subsets stratifying SLE patients, which, in turn, will create new opportunities for therapies directed toward each specific patient subgroup. 2

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Over the past 12 years, the therapeutic landscape for melanoma patients has been transformed by the success of FDA-approved immuno-oncology and pathway-targeted therapeutics. However, major challenges remain in pharmacologic targeting of mutationally-activated NRAS oncoprotein signaling in melanoma patients who are either ineligible for, or who fail first-line immunotherapy. To address this challenge, we propose to employ state-of-the-art experimental systems to design and evaluate new, rationally targeted therapeutic strategies to directly target NRAS oncoprotein signaling in melanoma, with the long-term goal of rendering melanoma a chronic or curable disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Maintaining homeostasis of the neural stem cell pool is fundamental to the development and integrity of the nervous system. By providing insights into the mechanism of how the evolutionarily conserved Notch signaling pathway acts in a non-canonical manner to regulate neural stem cell homeostasis, this study has the potential to lead to deeper understanding of the development and maintenance of the nervous system and inform the development of novel therapy for brain tumors and a range of neurological conditions where altered Notch signaling has been implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Biomedical research often involves the collection of error-prone, complex, high-dimensional functional and scalar data. We will develop novel approaches to survival analysis using Bayesian and frequentist frameworks to correct for biases in physical activity and dietary intake assessments and thus improve understanding of the intricate relationships among energy balance, obesity, type 2 diabetes, and mortality. Our models will inform personalized recommendations for PA and DI and address health disparities in vulnerable populations, and public use software that implements our models will allow researchers to apply our methods in diverse biomedical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic tumors consist of many diverse cell types engaged in crosstalk mechanisms to support cancer cell growth and survival. Our work has identified metabolically distinct subpopulations of pancreatic cancer cells that exchange nutrients to support resistance to mitochondrial inhibition. This proposal will define the factors underpinning metabolic heterogeneity in pancreatic cancer cells and use a combination of metabolic inhibitors to sensitize pancreatic tumors to therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative We will identify the non-protein-coding regions of the genome that play an important role in tumor initiation and growth by modulating the expression of protein-coding regions. We will develop innovative computational methods that will make it feasible to identify these regions in metastatic cancer patients using non-invasive liquid biopsies. We will use high-throughput CRISPR screens to understand the impact of perturbation of thousands of regions and also probe their roles in specific contexts, such as resistant to therapy in breast cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Dry eye is a widespread condition that significantly impacts the elderly population globally. Inflammation of the lacrimal gland, responsible for producing aqueous tears, often correlates with aging. This proposal aims to elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying calorie restriction and explore its impact on progenitor cell function and gland regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Niemann-Pick type C (NPC) is a rare neurodegenerative and metabolic disease triggered by aberrant trafficking and partitioning of cholesterol in lysosomes. This proposal will combine mTORC1 manipulations with high throughput functional genomics and metabolomics to deepen our understanding of NPC drivers, with relevance to common neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Heart failure is a major public health problem in the United States and around the world. In this research, we apply complementary genetic and gene-expression approaches to identify novel genes and pathways that predispose individuals to heart failure. Importantly, we will integrate the approaches of Mendelian rare variant analyses with findings from Genome Wide Association Studies (GWAS). We further carry out functional validation studies using explanted hearts and patients’ hiPSC-cardiomyocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Background parenchymal enhancement (BPE) is a promising new marker of breast cancer risk that has been studied almost exclusively using magnetic resonance imaging, an expensive screening modality that is indicated primarily for women with high risk of breast cancer. We propose here to measure BPE quantitatively using contrast-enhanced mammogram (CEM), a rapidly emerging screening modality that is more affordable and generalizable than MRI, and assess the potential of BPE measured on CEM as a marker of breast cancer risk. Our long-term goal is to use our new, objective measure of BPE on CEM to improve assessment of breast cancer risk, enabling personalization of breast cancer screening to detect breast cancer earlier and ultimately reduce breast cancer mortality.

PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this project is to harness the unique multimodal infant MRI data collected via the Baby Connectome Project (BCP) and a set of infant-centric computational tools developed at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill for investigating structural and functional connectomes, tissue macrostructure and mi- crostructure, and their interplay during early brain development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe burn victims and patients suffering from congenital sweat gland deficiencies are unable to properly maintain body temperature, which can lead to hyperthermia, heat stroke, brain damage, and potentially death. Restoring the capacity of these patients to thermoregulate requires the ability to regenerate skin with functional sweat glands that are precisely regulated by the nervous system. This proposal will uncover novel molecular mechanisms of neuronal control in sweat gland development, advancing our understanding of skin and sweat gland regeneration and the development of therapeutics to treat patients with sweating deficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Excessive binge alcohol intake has been widely recognized as a strong risk factor for atrial fibrillation (AF), [especially a significant AF trigger in the aging population]. While alcohol is known to enhance inflammation, the ineffectiveness of anti-inflammation clinical therapies in clinical trials for AF patients demonstrates the urgent need to understand the detailed underlying mechanisms of alcohol and inflammation-associated AF. This proposal is designed to fill this knowledge gap by identifying stress-response c-Jun N-terminal kinase JNK2 as an important nodal point in alcohol-provoked inflammation-associated AF development and the results from this proposal will form a strong foundation toward achieving our long-term goal of developing novel therapies to treat and prevent AF.

Finally, we will develop new therapeutic approaches to overcome cardio fibrosis using novel NRP1 inhibitors (NRP1i) and novel targeted liposomal formulations and develop novel therapies to overcome one of the most common myocardial pathologies, which is an unmet clinical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Poor sleep, which occurs in nearly half of adults and disproportionately affects women and especially racial/ethnic minority women, significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and all-cause mortality. While sleep duration and quality have been well-studied in relation to cardiac risk, little is known about the cardiovascular implications of sleep timing and variability in bedtimes and wake times among non-shift workers, particularly in diverse populations of women across various stages of life (e.g., pre- and post- menopausal). This project will determine the prevalence of objectively-measured sleep variability in two diverse, well-phenotyped cohorts of women, associations of sleep variability with cardiovascular health, whether these associations vary by race/ethnicity and/or menopausal status, and potential mechanisms underlying these associations, to inform the development of public health guidance on sleep that may reduce the burden of cardiovascular disease among women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Urolithin A (UroA) is a microbial metabolite and treatment with UroA attenuated colitis in pre-clinical models without exhibiting toxicity. Current proposal investigates the mechanisms of selective activation of intestinal epithelial cell AHR-NLRP6 axis by microbial metabolite UroA in regulating gut barrier function under inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) conditions. Identifying such novel mechanisms and compounds that restore gut homeostasis and block unwarranted inflammation would offer new therapeutic options to control IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men and the second leading cause of cancer death. Men with clinically insignificant prostate cancer are placed on active surveillance which consists or repeat laboratory analysis, imaging, and prostate biopsy until patients progress to clinically significant prostate at which point they need treatment. The objective of this proposal is to explore the use of Prostate Specific Membrane Antigen Positron Emission Tomography- Computed Tomography (PSMA-PET CT) in detecting clinically significant prostate cancer in patients on active surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Urinary tract infections (UTI) are among the most common healthcare-associated infections worldwide, and the urothelium is the initial site of host-microbe interactions in the urinary tract. Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are an important barrier against bacterial infection of the urothelium, but some common pathogens have enzymes to degrade GAGs. The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness as we will determine the contribution of GAGs and microbial GAGases to infection, urosepsis, and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Proper formation of the eye relies on an enigmatic cell-cell communication circuit called the Hedgehog pathway that is deployed repeatedly in different contexts throughout eye development, and whose malfunction results in a spectrum of human developmental eye disorders. The proposed research will teach us how the Hedgehog pathway transmits signals during eye development, laying the groundwork for new strategy to activate Hedgehog signaling in ways that are more selective and specific than existing agents. The project is relevant to the mission of the National Eye Institute because it will define the signaling pathways that direct formation of multiple eye structures, including the optic cup and retina, reveal the molecular etiology of uveal colobomas and other birth defects affecting the visual system, and advance regenerative efforts aimed at directing ocular cell types toward specific lineage decisions for targeted cell replacement therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE During development, cells are arranged into intricately structured organs that carry out the many functions of the human body. To uncover the individual roles of cells in tissue function, and to determine how cells become dysfunctional in disease, we need technologies that can measure cell states within intact tissues. This proposal will develop a technology called Slide-tags that will enable detailed measurements of cells across entire human organs, shedding light on tissue function in both normal and disease conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE): We identified calcium-activated chloride channel regulator 1 (CLCA1) protein as a specific potentiator of the calcium-activated chloride channel TMEM16A, however, this channel and modulator play an underappreciated role in human airway biology, in part due to the challenges of studying the system in the setting of broader airway channel activity. Cystic fibrosis represents an ideal context to study the CLCA1-TMEM16A system in human airway disease, allowing for both the unmasked investigation of TMEM16A channel activity (in the absence of CFTR) and the opportunity to evaluate a unique potential therapeutic angle for patients unresponsive to CFTR modulator therapy. In this proposal we investigate the cellular and tissue expression patterns of TMEM16A in human disease, the potential beneficial impact of CLCA1 on TMEM16A-mediated airway function, and determine the molecular features of the CLCA1-TMEM16A interaction in order to produce the molecular framework needed to develop new therapeutics for diseases hallmarked by mucus obstruction, such as cystic fibrosis (CF) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Overproduction of aldosterone causes high blood pressure in ~80M people and is among the most challenging forms of high blood pressure to treat. We recently discovered three pathways that can lower aldosterone levels suggesting they may represent potential targets of future therapies. Defining the pathways that govern aldosterone regulation will provide critical insight into the mechanisms causing high BP and lead to new targeted therapies for these high-risk patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The application of machine learning to randomized clinical trials (RCTs) represents a novel avenue for developing tools to enhance precision cardiovascular care. To realize the potential of care personalization algorithms derived from RCTs to improve outcomes, the proposed investigations will develop an end-to-end strategy for model evaluation and adaption to electronic health records to facilitate real-world, pragmatic validation and implementation. This will be achieved through an empirical approach to evaluating personalized effect estimates derived from RCTs and addressing information streams in RCTs concurrently with real-world data in the electronic health record to enhance translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this work is to understand the role of the vitamin D pathway in the developing kidney and the mechanisms that connect vitamin D deficiency to chronic kidney disease in preterm neonates as a key component to preventing kidney disease. We will investigate the vitamin D pathway and how this pathway influences kidney development, focusing on a key cell in the kidney, the podocyte. Our findings will build the foundation for a clinical trial in preterm babies that optimizes environmental and maternal factors to reduce chronic kidney disease development in preterm babies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Most common diseases and medically important traits are influenced by a combination of many genes; one of these, obesity, is a pressing public health problem for which there are still few long-term effective and safe treatments. Discovering and understanding the genetic variation that influences the risk of obesity would provide new biological clues to guide better treatments. We plan to (1) use and expand our successful studies of the genetics of human height, a model trait, to chart out the best path to expand our studies of the genetics of obesity, (2) expand our already world-leading genetic studies of obesity and height to include more diverse and informative types of genetic variation studied in larger, more diverse sets of people, and (3) use new, innovative methods that combine genetic and other large data sets to better understand the biology that is implicated by these genetic studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypocretin/orexin (H/OX) neurons in the mammalian hypothalamus are critical for coordinating fundamental behavioral states such as arousal, stress, and motivation, and their dysfunction is implicated in devastating neurological and sleep disorders, notably narcolepsy with cataplexy. This proposal will use new and innovative molecular, cellular, and behavioral techniques to dissect the synaptic signaling pathways through which H/OX neurons shape physiology and behavior. In so doing, we hope to identify targets for therapeutic intervention in treating and improving the quality of life of patients suffering from neurological and sleep disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertrophic scars arise in over 50% of all surgical procedures and 90% of burn injuries, and are physically uncomfortable and painful, as well as inflict psychological damage due to their negative cosmetic appearances. Current treatment options are limited in their scope and efficacy, as they do not target the underlying cause of scar development: a dysregulated wound healing response. Here, the sustained and localized delivery of the natural antifibrotic peptide hormone, relaxin-2, via a hydrogel, is described as a novel solution to treat both the underlying etiology and symptomatic presentation of hypertrophic scars.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Patterning Genes in Retinal Development  Public Health Impact Statement  This project will discover mechanisms regulating the expression of “tandemly-replicated” cone visual pigment opsin genes, such as those on the human X chromosome encoding the red- and green-sensitive cone opsins. The results of the proposed studies will provide key information regarding endocrine signaling pathways, receptors, and genetic response elements that mediate this regulation. Understanding these regulatory pathways will be important as the Vision Science community develops regenerative medicine-based methods for replacing photoreceptors that are lost to disease or injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to elucidate sub-cellular compartment homeostasis that is disrupted by developmental PFAS exposure, including PFOA, PFBA, and GenX, that collectively contribute to neurotoxicity later in life by increasing cellular vulnerability to established neuro-risk factors associated with neurodegeneration. We will combine derived human dopaminergic neuronal cells and zebrafish animal model to compare the neurotoxicity of selected PFAS and identify key pathogenic pathways driving the neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Relevance Over the past decade, evidence has emerged of a direct (but only an associative) relationship between pro- inflammatory mediators and impulsive aggression in humans. In this study, we propose to demonstrate a causal relationship between pro-inflammatory proteins and impulsive aggression in human subjects by showing that an acute pro-inflammatory state, via endotoxin challenge, will increase aggressive responding, and increase hostile social cognition to a greater degree in “aggressive”, compared with “non-aggressive”, individuals. If supported, this finding will provide a strong rationale for clinical trials of anti-inflammatory agents in impulsive aggressive individuals.

PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary hypertension is a disease where there is narrowing of the blood vessels in the lungs causing the dysfunction and failure in the right side of heart, which are associated with poor prognosis. This proposed study will investigate the reasons that underlie the weakening of the right side of heart with a focus on mechanisms responsible for energy generation in the heart muscle. Should the experiments be successful, we will discover a new way to increase energy generation in the heart muscle in the right side of heart and thereby improve the heart function and outcomes in patients suffering from pulmonary hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to investigate mechanisms by which amino acids impact cell health when their storage and regulated uptake is altered, as occurs during aging. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall aim of this project is to engineer whole-cell, living biosensors that can detect tumors within the gastrointestinal system and respond with a diagnostic output. We will integrate our knowledge of synthetic biology, cancer and our clinical expertise to develop, test, and optimize genetic circuits capable of sensing and responding to common gastrointestinal tract cancer mutations in DNA. The motivation is to increase participation in cancer screening, catch gastrointestinal cancers in earlier stages, decrease healthcare costs and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project seeks to evaluate the effectiveness and implementation of the Breastfeeding Education Support Tool for Baby (BEST4Baby) intervention, an mHealth-supported community-based peer counselor breastfeeding intervention for mothers in India. Given that rates of optimal infant feeding practices have remained stagnant over the past two decades in India, and that India is the most populous country and icontributes one-fifth of all global live births, this project could have major global health implications if the intervention is found to improve maternal breastfeeding practices and infant clinical outcomes. The project will also provide evidence needed to adopt BEST4Baby nationally and in other low resource communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Synovial inflammation (synovitis) plays a role in the onset, pathogenesis and is a key target for disease modifying drugs in Osteoarthritis (OA), a leading cause of pain, reduced joint function, and disability. While associations between synovitis and OA are known, our understanding of the role of synovitis in OA has been hampered by a lack of a non-invasive and non-contrast methods to evaluate synovitis. This work aims to develop new, non- contrast MRI methods to assess synovial inflammation in knee OA and to demonstrate their predictive power for OA whole joint disease progression and both prediction and monitoring of treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Ricin is one of the most potent toxins known and a type B biothreat agent and the related Shiga toxins (Stxs) produced by E. coli (STEC) and Shigella dysenteriae remain enormous global health problems because at present, there is no known therapy against ricin or STEC. The proposed studies will develop novel small molecules that inhibit ricin and Shiga toxin 2 a by targeting their interactions with the ribosome. The findings are expected to be of great impact as they address the unmet need to develop novel ricin and STEC therapeutics by targeting toxin/ribosome interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Metastatic uveal melanoma is one of the deadliest cancers – often associated with metastatic dissemination to the liver. Given that there is only one FDA-approved agent that improves survival by just six months, we are compelled to investigate novel treatment avenues to combat metastatic uveal melanoma. In this proposal we seek to gain mechanistic insights and highlight therapeutic vulnerabilities associated with the unique interplay between the liver microenvironment and uveal melanoma metastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic viral infections such as HBV, HCV, and HIV cause significant morbidity and mortality globally. Although T lymphocytes confer critical protection against viral infections, T cells often become dysfunctional or ‘exhausted’ in response to persistent pathogens. This proposal will investigate how key epigenetic regulators control T cell exhaustion in the setting of chronic infection, which may provide insights into novel therapeutic strategies to restore function to exhausted cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE The burden of mental health disorders among children in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) such as Tanzania is an urgent global public health issue that must be addressed by interventions that target the upstream drivers of mental illness. The objective of this study is to identify malleable features of the primary school environment that longitudinally impact mental health outcomes and foster resilience among adversity-exposed youth in Tanzania. The study will inform the development of effective whole school interventions to promote mental health among children in Tanzania and other LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: While we have significantly advanced the therapeutic options for breast cancer over the past decades, recurrent disease, often in a highly aggressive metastatic form, occurs years or even decades after remission and represents a significant hurdle in our ability to effectively cure breast cancer patients. Recurrent disease is thought to be powered by a process known as dormancy, which is when disseminated cancer cells from primary tumors temporarily inactivate and later re-awaken in a metastatic form; despite known to occur for over 60 years, our understanding of the molecular circuits that regulate this process is very limited, which has hindered the development of efficacious therapeutics that target disease relapse and prevent patient mortality. Here, we aim to gain a deep understanding of the cell-intrinsic pathways that drive dormancy and allow breast cancer cells to retain vitality in this state as well as how these cell-intrinsic pathways are fine-tuned by the environment at secondary organs with the overarching goal of unveiling new therapeutic targets for inactive breast cancer cells and thereby lead to the development of targeted therapies that can effectively prevent recurrent metastatic disease in breast cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Veterans and the general public who suffer from traumatic brain injury (TBI) are at a significantly higher risk of developing psychiatric disorders such as posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety, and depression. A growing body of evidence demonstrates that TBI can disrupt the balance of gut microbiota, leading to a condition known as gut microbiota dysbiosis, which is strongly associated with psychiatric disorders. The objective of this project is to investigate the role of extracellular vesicles (EVs) derived from gut microbiota dysbiosis induced by TBI in the pathophysiology of comorbid psychiatric-like behaviors as well as explore the therapeutic potential of beneficial bacterial EVs by targeting the serotonergic system and neuroinflammation in a preclinical model of TBI, which will not only provide novel insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying psychiatric complications following TBI but also have the potential to facilitate the development of microbial- based approaches for the prevention and treatment of TBI in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE R-loops are RNA-DNA hybrids that normally help regulate gene expression, yet they can also lead to genome instability and have been implicated in diverse diseases ranging from cancer to neurological disorders. The proposed studies will elucidate the mechanisms that lead to the formation of deleterious R loops and the processes by which they are removed from the chromatin. Ultimately, a deeper understanding of these mechanisms may reveal strategies to harness R-loop metabolism for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE The memory and cognitive deficits observed in Alzheimer’s disease (AD), dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) and Parkinson’s disease dementia (PDD) are largely attributable to a loss of cholinergic function and neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert (NBM). Here we propose a Phase I single surgical-center, double-blinded clinical trial involving bilateral autologous peripheral nerve tissue (PNT) into the NBM to address “repair cell” support of cholinergic neurons. The major goal of this trial is to identify the feasibility and safety of bilateral implantation of reparative PNT to the NBM with the eventual goal to improve function of cholinergic neurons in dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative We propose that the methylation status of osteoblasts is altered by IDH1/2 mutant hematopoietic cells that arise with aging and during age related clonal hematopoiesis (ARCH). We will delineate how epigenetically modified mouse and human stromal cells and osteoblasts provide support for IDH clonal hematopoietic cells to expand and transform to MDS/AML with aging. These studies will identify osteoblast-derived signals that may be targeted therapeutically alone or in combination with current IDH inhibitors to improve treatment or prevent development of IDH mutant MDS/AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Old age is the most important unmodifiable risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) and CC-motif chemokine ligand 11 (CCL11) is circulating factor that increases in rodents and humans with aging. CCL11 distorts lung immune response and brain reparative functions that impact ICH-induced damages. We propose that inhibition of CCL11 signaling can be used as new therapeutic approach to treat ICH, especially in old age patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Efficient DNA excision repair is critical to maintain genome stability and prevent the accumulation of carcinogenic mutations. How excision repair factors are able to recognize and repair DNA lesions resident in damaged nucleosomes, however, is unclear. In this application, we propose to use next-generation sequencing methods to characterize the fate of damaged nucleosomes in cells and elucidate how DNA repair and chromatin modifying factors promote the recognition and repair of DNA lesions in chromatin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Our project to adapt a powerful laboratory test for leukemia diagnosis in Kenya creates three unique interconnected systems critical for the project's success. The three systems, sample collection and handling, advanced high parameter flow cytometry, and comprehensive training of personnel, are routine practice in the United States and other High-Income Countries but are not part of the fabric for routine care structure of most Low- and Middle-Income Countries yet. Demonstrating the feasibility and sustainability of this process has the potential to improve the diagnosis of childhood leukemia vastly and, with available treatments in Kenya, to save lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Acute kidney injury is a common complication in critically ill patients who require mechanical ventilation to support life, with devastating consequences for morbidity and mortality. The causes of acute kidney injury due to mechanical ventilation are unclear, and no proven treatments exist. This project explores the physiological and molecular pathways of ventilator induced kidney injury to identify pathways for novel treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Description The goal of this research project is to understand the underlying molecular mechanisms of human retinitis pigmentosa, the most common form of inherited retina diseases. Through studying of the Ddx41 mutant mice model just established, we plan to reveal how the DDX gene family is involved in retinal degeneration in human. In parallel, we propose to improve the rate of molecular diagnostic for the disease by identifying novel pathogenic mutations and disease associated genes that will address a major gap of the field and provide the basis for developing new therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research goals are to understand why older individuals exhibit higher severity of and mortality from viral infections than younger adults and how viruses evolve within their aged hosts. Our studies in the fruit fly Drosophila show that we can effectively model aged host-virus interactions in this genetically tractable organism and we are using this system to identify the cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie the capability of the aged organism to survive infection and limit pathogen mutations and spread. This research could potentially lead to therapeutic improvements for infected elderly patients as well as to the prevention of the emergence of novel viral strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Skin contains diverse cell types that provide a physical barrier, sensors of pain and touch, and surveillance of invading organisms or foreign bodies. For this project we aim to construct a near-complete and functioning representation of human skin inside a silicone device, called a tissue chip or organoid-on-a-chip. Our findings will provide new insights into how human skin develops and will produce a new model that researchers and drug developers can use to study a wide range of inflammatory diseases and cancers.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Diagnostic errors lead to an estimated 40,000-80,000 deaths every year in the United States. Most diagnostic errors include cognitive causes, but accurate awareness of these causes by the clinicians making them is vital to help them prevent future diagnostic errors. We developed and will now test a resource aimed at helping clinicians gain insight into their own diagnostic performance, a vital step in improving the accuracy and timeliness of diagnosis for patients. .
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluation of Calibrate Dx: A Resource to Improve Diagnostic Decisions in the Hospital Setting
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have previously demonstrated through high-throughput drug screening that amongst solid tumors, MYCN- amplified neuroblastoma are the most sensitive to targeting of the anti-apoptotic proteins, BCL-2 and BCL-xL, and that targeting BCL-2 with the FDA-approved BCL-2 inhibitor, venetoclax, may be an important strategy in rational drug combination therapies. In this grant renewal, we reveal two clinically-relevant rational drug partners with venetoclax, SHP2 allosteric inhibitors, which have entered clinical trials at a blistering pace, and ABBV-155, a first in-class, in-human antibody drug conjugate BCL-xL inhibitor; in both cases, SHP2 inhibitor + venetoclax, and ABBV-155 + venetoclax, complimentarily modulate BCL-2 family proteins and induce toxicity and marked tumor responses in MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma. Overall, this grant aims to methodically test these two novel combination therapies to gather the preclinical evidence of an effective treatment regimen to put forward in a pediatric cancer with a high unmet need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: In this grant renewal, we investigate how the small adaptor protein Crk and its phosphorylation function as a molecular switch to turn immune cell function on and off. We use newly identified pCrk inhibitors as a tool to dissect out Crk’s ability to integrate activating and inhibitory immune cell influences in a variety of clinically relevant settings: live human immune cells, a common human immunodeficiency (partial DiGeorge syndrome, pDGS), and mouse models of breast cancer. Outcomes will result in a new view of Crk in immune responses, tumor suppression, and immune cell exhaustion, and will set the stage for immune restoration in immunodeficiency and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the role of GATA3 in facial development and to understand why loss of Gata3 results in asymmetric dysmorphic features. Using a combination of existing mouse genetic tools, we will investigate the timing of neural crest cell defects, molecular changes associated with sidedness and the roles of BMP4 and FGF8 in the Gata3 mutant phenotype. Elucidating the basis of facial defects in Gata3 mutants is crucial for future assessment and treatment of individuals with hemifacial microsomia, and therefore this research proposal addresses an important human health problem aligned with the mission of the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Different mutations in the same gene usually give rise to phenotypes that may be more or less severe, but in the case of the RNA-binding protein PUMILIO1 (PUM1), two different missense mutations produce markedly different phenotypes: one is a mild late-onset ataxia, the other is a congenital neurodevelopmental syndrome with global developmental delay and seizures. We hypothesized that the milder disease results from target dysregulation while the more severe disease involves disruption of PUM1 native interactions, and this seems to be the case in cell lines. Now, armed with a robust targetome and interactome for PUM1, we will test this hypothesis thoroughly in mouse models of the mild and severe diseases to uncover their molecular pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance The analysis of longitudinal imaging data holds the promise of more accurate computer-aided diagnosis of neurodegenerative disease as well as more effective and efficient quantification of the effects of potential therapeutic interventions. The successful completion of the proposed project would update the mostly widely used longitudinal neuroimaging analysis tools to be significantly more sensitive and specific to Alzheimer’s Disease effects, run orders of magnitude faster and apply to a dramatically wider range of scan types than the tools we developed in the previous cycle, providing them to the thousands of clinicians and researchers that currently use FreeSurfer, improving the power of a wide array of NIH-funded studies to quantify disease and drug effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The vast majority of patients with TNBCs are offered adjuvant chemotherapy after surgery. However, there are no tools, apart from tumor infiltrating lymphocytes, to optimize therapy for these patients. This proposal will develop a novel multi-modal CaPRI score that integrates clinicopathologic, radiomic, pathomic and immune features in to a single score for predicting risk of lethality and therapeutic optimization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Predictors of postoperative complications, treatment toxicities, and clinical or patient-reported outcomes in older colorectal cancer patients are not yet completely understood; current clinical management of these patients is largely driven by chronological age, though functional status may be a better predictor of outcomes. We will evaluate clinical and patient-reported outcomes in a prospectively enrolled cohort of newly diagnosed stage I-III colorectal cancer patients ages 70 years and older in relation to physical function, multidimensional geriatric assessment, and relevant biomarkers. Information gained from this project will inform tailored treatments for older colorectal cancer patients based on their physical function, frailty, and biological age, independent of their chronological age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to establish an in vitro human Parkinson's disease (PD) model equipped with a functional cerebral vasculature that mediates the interaction between the neuronal network and peripheral blood. Using this platform, we will investigate PD pathology caused by the pathologic aggregation of α-syn in midbrain dopaminergic neurons and blood. The proposed model is also expected to provide a cost-effective and convenient means to quickly screen candidate treatment options, opening a new avenue for advanced PD research and therapy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eating disorders and non-eating disorders internalizing-spectrum disorders (e.g., major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, social phobia, obsessive-compulsive disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder) are chronic, debilitating, and frequently co-occurring disorders, which often onset in adolescence. This multi-site, multidisciplinary study will identify symptom trajectories across the overall internalising spectrum (across eating disorders and non-eating-disorders-internalising disorders) from late childhood through emerging adulthood in two population-based samples (ABCD and ALSPAC) and identify genetic and phenotypic factors associated with these developmental trajectories. The results will inform nosology, pathophysiology, and ultimately early identification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Bacterial pneumonia is a leading cause of death in the US and worldwide. Furthermore bacterial pneumonia is one of the most common causes of ARDS, a lung disease also associated with high morbidity and mortality, and bacterial co-infection is known to significantly increase mortality in patients infected with influenza. This project will investigate how one of our own molecules called glypican protects against Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia by promoting the early clearance of bacteria and preventing bacterial invasion of host cells in the lung. The proposed studies will generate new scientific information and identify new therapeutic targets for bacterial pneumonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Projective Narrative Oral squamous cell carcinoma is the sixth most common, infiltrative, and lethal tumor type affecting the adult population. These tumors contain highly migratory and invasive cells, making recurrence rates exceedingly high. This proposal will improve our understanding of how the stiffness of the surrounding environment enables tumor cells to acquire, consolidate, and recall metastatic behaviors that promote invasion of adjacent tissues, which could suggest new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Pineoblastoma (PB) is a poorly understood malignant embryonal tumor of the pineal gland for which safer and more effective therapies are urgently needed. Applying multi-omic analyses to a large international cohort of bulk PB tumor specimens, we recently identified four distinct molecular subgroups of PB, each characterized by discriminatory genetics, demographics, and clinical outcomes. This multidisciplinary proposal seeks to deconstruct the cellular and developmental basis of novel PB subgroups, while producing biologically faithful preclinical models required to improve treatments and outcomes for affected children in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastric cancer remains an important health burden in the United States and worldwide; its etiology is not fully understood and effective biomarkers for risk assessment are still lacking. Recent advancement in metabolomics techniques provides new opportunities for uncovering new etiologic factors and novel biomarkers to assist in identification of high-risk populations for gastric cancer, and ultimately improve disease prevention. To achieve these goals, we propose to conduct a comprehensive metabolomics study of gastric cancer risk with a multi- center, nested case-control design within a new international consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The conversion of somatic cells, specifically skin fibroblasts, into therapeutically beneficial cell types holds promising implications for the treatment of gastrointestinal and hepatic diseases. Nevertheless, current lineage reprogramming protocols often exhibit limited efficiency, and the resultant cells frequently fail to recapitulate the attributes of the intended cell type accurately. In this study, we propose to scrutinize the mechanistic intricacies of cell fate reprogramming by employing innovative experimental and computational genomic methodologies. Our objective is to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms underlying lineage reprogramming and leverage these insights to refine strategies for deriving human hepatic and intestinal cell types, thereby augmenting the potential for accurate disease modeling and effective therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Oxygen is administered to unconscious, critically ill patients on mechanical ventilation who have survived cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) to keep them adequately oxygenated. Oxygen is not normally toxic at these concentrations but in this population of patients the threshold for oxygen toxicity is lowered resulting in increased brain injury and inflammation. This project investigates the molecular basis for increased oxygen toxicity following cardiac arrest and proposes therapeutic strategies to mitigates its effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Macrophage fusion resulting in the formation of destructive multinucleated giant cells, accompany various disorders associated with chronic inflammation, including the long-term failure of implanted prosthetic vascular grafts and other medical devices. The proposed studies will determine why and how the fibrin polymer deposited on implanted biomaterials drives macrophage fusion and establish the cellular and molecular details of the recently discovered membrane protrusion that initiates macrophage fusion. The knowledge obtained from these studies will be employed to design new biomaterials with reduced macrophage fusion and test their properties in vivo animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to determine the molecular requirements for healthy cardiac muscle function, in order to pave the way for discovery and design of more effective therapies for heart disease. Our work will answer crucial questions about how the protein myosin-binding protein C (MyBP-C), the leading cause of cardiomyopathy, functions in the heart, using reporter probes to visualize dynamic protein structures by testing its specific mechanistic roles in healthy and diseased heart cells. This research will greatly improve the human health prospects by understanding effects of disease mutations and developing tools that can be used to discover novel treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm birth is common in the U.S., with tremendous impact upon children and families. While many go on to productive lives, growing evidence suggests adult disease manifestations for the formerly preterm—yet, we have limited understanding of the impact and mechanistic drivers among formerly preterm children (FPC). This proposal will expand the prevailing understanding of the impact of preterm birth even upon presumably ‘healthy’ children by determining the clinical, biochemical, and molecular characteristics of FPC to provide novel insights and potentially provide new therapeutic targets to modify before adulthood.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Clostridioides difficile spores are recognized as the morphotype of infection, persistence and transmission. Our proposed studies aim to understand the interactions between C. difficile spores and the host ́s intestinal mucosa that contribute to C. difficile persistence and recurrence of the infection. This research will reveal novel therapeutic targets from both, pathogen and host, to treat C. difficile infections and prevent disease recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative  Deposition of Amyloid beta (Ab) affects the microvasculature (MV) in Alzheimer’s disease and the related condition of Congophilic Amyloid Angiopathy (CAA). One sequelae of this deposition in or near the MV is alteration in collagen IV (Col IV), the primary structural protein in the MV basement membrane (BM). This proposal will examine the effect of Ab deposition on Col IV stability during disease progression in human and mouse models, and will define how different methods of removal of Ab could degrade Col IV and the MV BM leading to clinically significant damage such as MV disruption and microhemorrhage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Lowe syndrome is a rare disease in boys that causes glaucoma and cataracts, kidney failure, intellectual disabilities, and seizures; there is no therapy for this severe vision- and life-threatening disease. In this proposal, we are developing several groundbreaking strategies using CRISPR-mediated gene therapy to rescue OCRL loss and serve as treatments for Lowe syndrome. The potential benefits of this proposed research include development of the first effective treatment for a rare but severe pediatric disease: a chance to save vision and prolong lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The kappa opioid receptor (KOR) is a highly desirable therapeutic target capable of treating not only pain but also affective disorders and addiction. Non-traditional signaling effectors and pathways underlying KOR activation play important roles in ligand-specific responses. Identifying the key triggers and mediators involved in KOR signaling will provide new routes for developing modulators of KOR as opioid alternatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative. We are developing a technology that will render the in-vivo measurement of creatinine, urea, and other uremic solutes as convenient as the continuous glucose monitor has rendered the measurement of blood sugar. By adding renal clearance to the list of vital signs that can be monitored unobtrusively and in real time, such an advance would speed the diagnosis and improve the treatment of acute kidney injury, and enhance the precision with which renal replacement therapies can be personalized to match the needs of individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to perform human immunologic studies to define immunoprotective role of skin B cells located at the forefront of host defense against HSV-2 and capable of producing antibodies able to prevent HSV-2 infection. The overall goal of the project is to identify critical, currently unidentified mediators of protection during infection and mechanisms of post-infection virus control. This work could lead to the development of a protective vaccine that eliminates the burden of HSV-2 worldwide.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: The biomedical research and practice fields are becoming increasingly reliant on the use of sophisticated analytical instrumentation, including UHPLC-QTOF (Ultra-High-Performance Liquid Chromatography-Quadrupole Time-of-Flight mass spectrometer). The high resolution and sensitivity of Agilent’s state-of-the-art 6530 QTOF MS integrated with Agilent’s equally advanced 1290 Infinity Series II UHPLC create a robust system capable of effective and precise analysis of complex biological samples, such as tissues, fluids or environmental samples, making identification of contaminants, toxins, or disease markers possible; high-resolution mass spectrometry continues to be a foundational approach to both small molecule and metabolic interaction identification in biomedical research. Knowing the fundamental operation and how to employ these sophisticated instruments in addressing biomedical-related concerns through monitoring, early detection, and accurate assessment of health risks, supporting public health initiatives and interventions.
