IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative: Everything we do is informed by our surroundings, but little is known about how sensory systems translate the complexity of natural ‘real world’ environments into meaningful neural codes. Our research will provide a comprehensive understanding of how the environment, sensory neurons, and motor action work together to drive optimal behavior. This knowledge is necessary to advance our understanding of chemosensation, neural coding, and how sensory systems function during natural behavior.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early childhood education programs can influence a host of developmental outcomes through their provision of stimulating learning spaces, nutritious meals, screening for vision, hearing, health, and developmental difficulties, and by providing safe and reliable childcare that enables parents to work or further their education. However, most pre-kindergarten evaluation studies examine academic achievement outcomes alone, leaving a large gap in our understanding of how early learning interventions affect child health and family well-being. We will be the first to evaluate the impact of state pre-k investments over the past 20 years on a comprehensive set of child and family outcomes, including child physical and mental health, and maternal mental health and employment, to test whether pre-kindergarten investments have broad impact and to determine the pathways through which children develop.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Major depressive disorder (MDD), comorbid anxiety and cognitive dysfunction are linked to deficits in brain en- ergetic function. In an animal model of treatment-resistant depression, we will examine 3 bioenergetic com- pounds, creatine, cyclocreatine and acetyl-L-carnitine for their potential therapeutic use for depression, anxiety and cognitive dysfunction. Since bioenergetic deficits can cause inflammation and oxidative stress to promote onset of MDD, we will study the impact of these bioenergetic compounds on inflammation and oxidative stress, and then identify signaling pathways which may be involved.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Following the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v Wade, 14 states have banned abortion, and the consequences of this dramatic shift in legal abortion access are unknown. This study will apply a rigorous quasi- experimental design to examine the long-term health and economic consequences for people who obtained abortions despite or before imposition of a state ban and those for whom abortion is legally restricted. The study will document how people’s lives are affected by unwanted pregnancies in this new legal landscape, and the findings will be able to inform state policy decisions regarding abortion bans and the development of harm- reduction strategies for pregnant people living in states where legal abortion is no longer available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Solitary fibrous tumors (SFTs), historically sometimes called hemangiopericytomas (HPCs), are nonhereditary cancers which is a result of an environmental intrachromosomal gene fusion between NAB2 and STAT6 on chromosome 12. We propose to systematically evaluate the in vitro and in vivo efficacy and specificity of BET inhibitors against SFTs, and explore the underlying molecular mechanisms related to NAB2- STAT6 fusions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Anxiety-related processes are characterized by social avoidance and enhanced fear. While it is known that the ventral tegmental area (VTA) participates in the regulation of such motivated behaviors, the specific cell-types and circuits that govern these behaviors are unclear. This research program will determine the involvement of specific circuits and neurotransmitters released by cell-type specific VTA neurons that regulate behavioral outcomes that follow traumatic stress, which may provide new cellular- based intervention strategies for stress-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic life events play a critical role in the etiology of a number of psychiatric conditions; however the outcome of a traumatic event can vary widely between individuals. Thus, an understanding of what factors produce resilience to the impact of a traumatic event, as well as the neural mechanisms that mediate these factors, is of clinical importance. The proposed research is directed at these issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors have transformed modern cancer medicine, however the severe toxicity rate is up to ~60% in melanoma patients treated with combination immunotherapy. Unfortunately, the pathophysiology underlying these severe immune-related toxicities remains unclear, and we have no way in clinical practice to forecast who will experience them. To address these issues, we will perform multi-modal high-dimensional profiling of melanoma peripheral blood to delineate cellular determinants of immunotherapy-related toxicities and to devise an assay for predicting both immunotherapy response and toxicity from pretreatment plasma cell-free DNA using genome-wide methylation sequencing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The primary focus of this project is the use of non-invasive neuroimaging and 3D facial photography to identify Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder (FASD)-related brain abnormalities from birth to adolescence. Fetal exposure of the brain to alcohol can trigger brain abnormalities that unfold over a lifetime with severe consequences both for the affected individual and for society at large. To date, these abnormalities have mostly been studied starting in later childhood, with very few studies following the consequences of well documented alcohol exposure as they develop in the same individual in the early years and across time into adolescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We recently identified dysfunction in the cerebellum of patients with an extreme excessive eating disorder and found that cerebellar-mediated reward processing potently regulates food intake in mice. This proposal will examine how cerebellar circuits interact with midbrain dopaminergic centers to influence food seeking and consumption. Using intersectional viral tools and single cell sequencing to anatomically and molecularly define the subcortical cerebellar output pathways and deep brain imaging of neural and dopamine activity in diet-induced obese mice, we will define the cerebellar-striatal control of food intake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Muscles (including the heart and fast and slow skeletal muscles) have an ability to change how they contract to meet the needs of changing environments, like exercise, hormones, or genetic disease. We propose to study how they make these adaptations with a particular emphasis on the motor proteins of muscle called myosins. Mutations in these motors cause a large number of diseases and our work should lead to novel therapies for these debilitating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have devised a simple blood test that has the capacity to screen patients for the presence of pulmonary arterial hypertension, as well as give a readout of disease progression over time, based on our studies of the NOTCH3 receptor in this disease. We will test the hypothesis that quantification of serum NOTCH3 ECD levels is a highly sensitive and specific method to diagnose and determine the severity of World Health Organization Group 1 (idiopathic) pulmonary arterial hypertension in all age groups, sexes, and racial/ethnic backgrounds, as well as elucidate the cellular interactions and mechanisms leading to NOTCH3 ECD release into the blood. This novel biomarker test will bring pulmonary arterial hypertension diagnostics into a more patient-friendly, less invasive, and less costly realm and serve as a useful adjunct to other currently used modalities to diagnose this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When our cells activate a gene, they make a disposable copy of it that can be used for various biological purposes. We will investigate whether mistakes are made when these copies are synthesized and determine how these mistakes affect human health. Ultimately, these experiments could provide new insight into the natural aging process and the origins of various human diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hundreds to thousands of phosphorylation events in the T cell signaling pathway create dynamic biochemical networks that orchestrate essentially all functions needed for proper immune responses to malignant cells. We currently have no technology to functionally screen and identify individual phosphorylation sites that drive specific, distinct downstream phenotypes. Here, we propose combining DNA base editor-mediated mutations of phosphorylation sites, proteome-wide, coupled to phenotypic screens to discover novel signaling events that are associated with defects in T cell effector functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an important cause of blinding corneal infections in the USA and worldwide. Our studies have characterized the role of P. aeruginosa virulence factors and the immune response, especially neutrophils that control bacterial growth in infected corneas, but also causes corneal disease and visual impairment. Proposed studies will continue to examine the interactions of bacterial virulence factors with neutrophils at the molecular level, with the goal of understanding molecular pathways underlying these observations. Results from these studies will identify novel inhibitors of inflammatory cell activation that can be used to block the tissue damage and loss of vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lymphocytes migrate from the blood into the various tissues of the body where they provide immunity to infection and control cancer, but can also cause autoimmune and other inflammation associated diseases. The focus of this application is on newly discovered mechanisms that control lymphocyte access to some of the most clinically important organs in the body...including the lungs and airways, stomach, genitourinary tract and the pancreas. The proposed studies could lead to improved vaccine strategies and to novel preventative, therapeutic or curative treatment strategies for autoimmune, inflammatory, and neoplastic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  African Ancestry and other minority populations have been poorly represented in large-scale genomic studies, and yet these populations have the largest disparities in health care and outcomes and have the potential to broaden our knowledge of human genetics. The African Ancestry-Genomic Psychiatry Cohort (AA-GPC) will combine the African Ancestry (AA) participants in this study, the VA-CSP study, and the NeuroGap-Psychosis study creating a study population over 100,000 AA participants. This analysis has the potential for significant novel discovery.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Clinical investigations examining biomarker candidates in Gulf War Veterans' Illnesses (GWVI) are limited,  and studies that encompass both baseline and 10‐year follow‐up data for blood biomarker candidates are  currently unavailable. We thus propose to conduct a 10‐year follow‐up investigation in Gulf War Veterans  to examine promising blood biomarker candidates at baseline and 10‐year follow‐up, a project that has the  potential to be rapidly catalyzed into clinically efficacious interventions for GWVI.      These biomarker investigations could contribute to identifying new interventions for the treatment of  GWVI that are mechanistically anchored and address pathophysiological alterations relevant to the  condition.  They could also function as predictors of GWVI symptoms and therapeutic response to new  treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Germline ETV6 mutations are associated with familial thrombocytopenia and ~30% of carriers develop hematologic malignancies, but the pathophysiologic mechanisms of disease are poorly understood. Preliminary data we have gathered demonstrates that one of these mutations, Pro214Leu, creates a de novo nuclear export signal that leads to the cytoplasmic localization of ETV6. A preliminary bioinformatics approach suggests that creation of a de novo nuclear export signal by a missense mutation may be a generalized mechanism of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to escape from danger is a critical skill necessary for survival. The neural circuits that control escape, however, sometimes over-activate leading to intense feelings of fear and panic in the absence of threat – a process that is understudied. This proposal aims to elucidate escape circuits involving a genetically-defined cell population, cholecystokinin, within the lateral ventrolateral periaqueductal grey, a region of the brain highly implicated in panic, to provide novel avenues for understanding panic mechanisms.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Metastatic prostate cancer is likely to surge over the next decade as Vietnam Veterans age into their 70s. Black men and men exposed to Agent Orange have nearly twice the risk of metastatic diagnosis and death. Fortunately, new therapies have improved survival for men with metastatic prostate cancer, transforming guidelines and clinical practice. However, delivery of these new and complex treatments (i.e. treatment intensification) in men with multiple comorbid conditions raises equity and safety concerns. We aim to use a novel natural language processing tool developed in the VA to prospectively identify Veterans with incident metastatic prostate cancer and investigate patient, facility, and neighborhood factors that influence receipt of treatment intensification. We will also analyze real-world development of adverse events in this vulnerable population, and survey Veterans and physicians about their perception of barriers to care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: This Career Development Award seeks to support the efforts of Veterans Health Administration (VHA) to build the Whole Health (WH) system of care in which Veterans are empowered and equipped to pursue their best possible vision of health and well-being through self-care, conventional clinical care, and complementary and integrative health services. The objective of the CDA is to optimize the implementation of WH-Coaching, a key service in the WH system of care that provides extended, one-on-one support for setting and achieving personal health and well-being goals, for a specific chronic condition population – Veterans with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The proposed CDA will build on my strengths in qualitative research methods and implementation science, while simultaneously filling considerable gaps in my training related to theory-driven evaluation and complex systems approaches, quantitative research methods, co-design, implementation/hybrid trial design, and leadership/mentorship.

PHR: This proposal aims to develop novel percutaneous robotic devices that will lead to a higher instrument placement accuracy and maneuverability, currently a major impediment to successful MRI-targeted interventions. The proposed research has relevance to public health because the devices will have a positive impact on the treatment of cancers in the pelvis. The work is also thematically aligned to the NIH precision medicine initiatives, as we propose to develop and apply precision treatment tools with the imaging phenotype for treatment guidance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medication nonadherence (i.e., not taking one’s prescribed medicine) is a major cause of death, higher rates of hospital readmission, and extra costs for low-income patients with multiple chronic conditions. Major barriers to medication adherence among low-income patients during transitioning from the hospital to home include inability to pay for medications, inability to pick up prescribed medications, and not being given all necessary medications prior to discharge. This study seeks to find out if interventions that directly address these barriers will improve medical adherence and reduce hospitalizations and emergency department visits and costs among these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Musculoskeletal simulations that quantify muscle forces generated during movements, rigorously validated in animal and human studies, have great potential to improve life-long mobility for many persons, but to date suffer from physiologically inaccurate muscle models, significantly limiting their ability to accurately predict the magnitude and time course of muscle force; thereby hampering their usefulness in the clinic. A fundamental underlying cause is that muscle tissue mass has been ignored in muscle models and simulations. This proposal tests the key hypothesis that inactive muscle mass, reflective of submaximal activities of daily living (ADL), significantly limits a muscle’s shortening velocity, work, efficiency, and power output, by examining the contractile properties of different-sized whole animal muscles versus small fiber bundles that will inform the design of mass-enhanced muscle models incorporated into computationally efficient musculoskeletal simulations of human movement across ADL and gait.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unmet sexual and reproductive healthcare (SRH) needs can have deleterious consequences and are associated with poorer physical and emotional health outcomes both among women and their children. This study investigates women’s unmet SRH needs over the life course by specifying the connections between women’s experiences of SRH, the predisposing factors and enabling resources associated with unmet SRH needs, and disparities in unmet SRH needs over time. Findings may inform the development of public policy, public health programming, or clinical interventions to reduce unmet SRH needs and eliminate disparities by identifying the women most at risk and informing when and how to intervene most effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposal will examine a role of recently identified dorsal root ganglion-specific long noncoding RNA (DS-lncRNA) in neuropathic pain. We propose that peripheral nerve injury-induced downregulation of DS- IncRNA may contribute to the development and maintenance of neuropathic pain through enhancement in the binding of RALY (a transcriptional co-factor) to RNA polymerase II and consequent promotion of the RALY/RNA polymerase II-triggered G9a expression in the injured dorsal root ganglion. The proposed study will identify a previously unknown regulatory mechanism for neuropathic pain as well as a novel and potential therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall As a largely refractory disease, a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying therapeutic resistance in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma is urgently needed for the rational development of new therapies. This program project will determine the interdependent contributions to therapeutic resistance of epigenetic programs (Project 1), paracrine signaling pathways (Project 2), and metabolic adaptations (Project 3) in both the tumor and stromal compartments. Supporting these Research Projects, three state-of-the-art Shared Resource Cores and an Administrative and Biostatistics Core will provide central expertise for mouse and organoid models, single-cell analyses, digital spatial profiling, and immune cell characterizations, as well as key biostatistical and informatic support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 1: Epigenetics Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) is one of the deadliest forms of cancer, displaying resistance to a broad range of therapeutics. Alterations of the epigenetic landscape, including aberrant histone acetylation, in both tumor and stromal cells integrate with metabolic and signaling adaptations to drive cancer cell growth, survival, and therapeutic resistance. We take pharmacological and genetic approaches to determine how targeted inhibition of Class I histone deacetylases can disrupt PDA therapeutic resistance programs in both tumor and stromal cells, leveraging these findings to sensitize PDA to existing and/or developing cancer drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Cancer patients who have had long-term treatment with the drug doxorubicin often suffer from cardiotoxicity, caused by an enzyme, topoisomerase 2b (Top2b), which can be prevented by dexrazoxane, an FDA- approved drug that inhibits Top2b. However, dexrazoxane is not commonly used due to a concern for reducing the effectiveness of doxorubicin. This study will test a new strategy to resurrect the clinical use of dexrazoxane by giving it to patients eight hours before doxorubicin based on a different mechanism of action by dexrazoxane.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Restoring function to the lymphatic system can alleviate lymphedema, heart disease, obesity, diabetes, and stroke. Consequently, our long-term goal is to uncover the molecular and cellular events governing lymphatic function in health and disease, with the hope of identifying new therapeutic targets to combat cardiovascular and metabolic diseases, which represent leading causes of morbidity and mortality, and remain highly-relevant to the mission of the NIH. In this project, we will investigate the pathophysiological role of the potential therapeutic target miR-22 in regulating lymphatic metabolic programming, signal transduction, and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 2: Signaling Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma is one of the deadliest common carcinomas due, in part, to both inherent and acquired therapeutic resistance engendered by the complex crosstalk between cancer cells and the surrounding microenvironment. We will utilize a combination of in vivo and organoid co-culture models to systematically map the intricate cellular signaling networks that promote PDA survival and treatment resistance. We will then leverage our understanding of paracrine signaling to intercept key hubs in this resistance network using genetic and pharmacologic perturbation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  CD8+ T cells regulate the adaptive response to infection, antitumor immunity, and autoimmunity through their remarkable ability to detect intracellular antigen and mediate potent cytotoxic functions. Further investigating mechanisms by which long-lasting immunological memory is generated remains of great significance to human health. Findings from this study will enhance our understanding of how the quality of T cell receptor signaling imprints a memory program in CD8+ T cells with important implications in the rational design of vaccine development and adoptive T cell transfer immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Strength deficits following transtibial amputation contribute to gait asymmetries resulting in increased risk of osteoarthritis development in the intact knee for the over 1 million individuals with limb loss in the United States. The underlying causes of muscle dysfunction leading to these negative secondary complications are poorly understood. We propose to characterize the relationships between muscle quality and strength of the quadriceps of the amputated side to resulting knee joint loading of the intact limb.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to define the impact of pubertal suppression treatment in transgender youth on mental health trajectories and underlying neural systems. By comparing transgender youth who receive pubertal suppression treatment to those who do not, with repeated assessments over time, we seek to identify patterns of improvement and/or worsening in each group. The information gained from this project will inform the optimization of standard of care pubertal suppression treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance For hospitals, including Intensive Care Units, operating rooms, emergency rooms, dialysis clinics, interventional radiology, vascular suites, and burn centers, the current Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter (PICC) connection disinfection process is a time-consuming process that relies upon strict nurse protocol and compliance for efficacy. Improper, or incomplete disinfection is a significant cause of catheter related blood stream infections (CRBSIs), which can result in sepsis and even death, as well as a costly event for the hospital or care facility since CMS will no longer reimburse hospitals for their treatment. This project proposes a therapeutic medical device to reduce CBSRIs in patients with PICCs, this reducing mortality, morbidity, and cost of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 3: Autophagy Therapeutic resistance in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) is driven, in part, by metabolic adaptations that support tumor cell survival, including the upregulation of autophagy. Here, we use a combination of genetic and pharmacological tools to define how activation of the AMPK autophagy pathway in both tumor and stromal compartments contributes to PDA development and drug responses. In addition, proposed experiments will determine the efficacy of new autophagy-selective inhibitors in treating PDA and in overcoming resistance to clinical therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Rates of neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome (NOWS) have drastically increased in the past decade, with about 80 babies per day born with NOWS, and the combined associated medical and educational costs projected to be more than $400 million, annually. Recent evidence has suggested that inflammation is present as a result of in utero opioid exposure, and, while inflammation is present during periods of withdrawal in adult rodent models of heroin addiction, the molecular mechanisms of withdrawal in NOWS and long-term effects, such as those related to cognition, remain incomprehensible. Utilizing a rat model of NOWS, we will evaluate inflammation as it relates to physical withdrawal symptoms and subsequent cognitive function in associated brain regions to better understand this debilitating and costly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative 22q11.2 deletion syndrome is the most common chromosomal deletion problem reported in humans, leading to multiple clinical problems that affect the immune, heart, and nervous systems. Our recent work is revealing important roles for coding and noncoding RNAs in affecting the severity of the disease. We will use patient studies and mouse models of 22q11.2 deletion syndrome to determine the impact of these RNA species in the formation and function of the thymus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to establish novel optical strategies for rapid systematic metabolic characterization of biological models in vivo to address questions in the field of HNSCC radio-resistance and recurrence using orthotropic HNSCC models. We will also integrate our optical strategies with the state-of-art Stable Isotope- Resolved Metabolomics (SIRM) to provide rapid and comprehensive understanding in tumor metabolism that relates to radio-resistance. Our synergistic approach will provide the metabolic underpinnings of radio- resistance and recurrence and facilitate advances in the understanding of tumor biology, assessment of recurrence risk and design of therapies that can mitigate radio-resistance and recurrence altogether.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Protein allostery is a fundamental phenomenon in which ligand binding at one site affects substrate activity or ligand binding at a second, distal site of the protein. Allostery is a primary mode of regulation for enzymes and other proteins that drive signal transduction and metabolism, and it is now being used in some drug development efforts, even though the mechanisms of allostery are not well understood. The work in this project will characterize dynamics and allosteric communication pathways for the homodimeric enzymes chorismate mutase and thymidylate synthase, and for engineered optogenetic conformational switch proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Administrative and Biostatistics Core Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma is a highly lethal malignancy that will soon become the second-leading cause of cancer-related death, in large part because patients often exhibit inherent and/or adaptive resistance to therapy. This program project will explore the epigenetic programs, signaling pathways, and metabolic adaptations that drive therapeutic resistance, with the end goal of revealing new therapeutic targets. The Administrative and Biostatistics Core will provide the leadership framework, communication pipelines, project management services, biostatistical expertise, and data storage/sharing solutions necessary to coordinate the activities of the three Research Projects and three Shared Resource Cores that comprise this P01 effort, thereby providing an organizational foundation for success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Core 1: Tumor and Microenvironment Heterogeneity Core The Tumor and Microenvironment Heterogeneity Core (TMH Core) will provide essential support for all three Projects in their efforts to delineate tumor and stromal cell programs that underlie therapeutic resistance in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA). Specifically, the TMH Core will assist with digital spatial profiling of tissues, quantitative and functional characterization of tumor immune cells, and single-cell transcriptomic and epigenomic experiments, as well as provide the necessary bioinformatic and computational support to effectively utilize the resulting data. In combination, these services will facilitate the determination of how heterogeneity in cell type-specific function and localization contributes to therapeutic resistance in PDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The knee meniscus has a unique mechanical function that is dictated by its three-dimensional (3D) structure, and injuries to the meniscus represent a large socioeconomic problem. The overall goal of this proposal is to develop a bioactive nonwoven scaffold that recapitulates the complex multiscale structural and mechanical characteristics of the meniscus and assess its long-term function and the ability to prevent joint degeneration in- vivo. On completion, fundamental knowledge gained about the micro- and macro-level process-structure- function relationships using our new high throughput 3D nonwovens approach can be extended to develop new and translational technologies for the treatment of injuries to other important tissues, including the intervertebral disc, ligaments, and tendons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infectious diseases are leading causes of death in newborns who have distinct immunity and metabolic needs. Vaccines are the most effective biomedical intervention to prevent infection and may confer off-target health benefits, but the mechanisms by which they do so are incompletely characterized in early life. The proposed research will explore the effects of Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine, given yearly to ~150 million newborns across the globe, on neonatal immunity and cellular metabolism to identify molecular signatures of broad vaccine protection against infection that can be harnessed to optimize current and future vaccines tailored to the very young.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it addresses a novel mechanism by which interactions of aggressive cancers such as acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with their niche can promote disease progression. If successful, this work will provide a scientific basis for development of new strategies to treat these aggressive cancers with less than 25% survival rates. This is highly relevant to the NIH mission of developing fundamental knowledge to help reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Core 2: Human Specimen and Organoid Core The Human Specimen and Organoid Core (HSO Core) will provide expertise and essential resources for all three Research Projects in their efforts to develop effective approaches for overcoming therapeutic resistance in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA). The HSO Core will leverage a large biobank of patient-derived organoid models as well as organotypic slice models that recapitulate the PDA microenvironment to test therapeutic combinations and define novel vulnerabilities. The HSO core will also collaborate with the Project teams to develop novel mouse organoid cultures and co-culture systems that incorporates cell types that define the tumor microenvironment to interrogate signaling networks ex vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Many older adults show the biological signs of Alzheimer's disease yet remain cognitively intact; it may be useful to identify and harness the factors that influence such resilience. Here we propose to catalog the genes, molecules, brain structures, and clinical features that increase risk for Alzheimer's disease, and determine how those factors relate to the emergence of cognitive deterioration over time on the path to dementia. Our findings may help clinicians accurately predict, diagnose, treat, and even prevent cognitive decline over time, and also may help scientists understand the biology of resilience to Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Inorganic metals have long been a focus of biomedical research in New Mexico, due to the high prevalence of mining-related metal contaminants in the region. At the University of New Mexico Center for Metals in Biology and Medicine our main focus will be on both studying adverse health outcomes of metal contaminants as well as on harnessing the chemical properties of metals for therapeutic and nutritional purposes. The outcomes of our program have clear benefit to clinical populations and communities in the southwest, including the underserved populations disproportionately impacted by legacy waste from mining operations. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the ongoing opioid crisis and the availability of effective medications that help individuals with opioid use disorder maintain remission, few health care providers prescribe these treatments, leading to inadequate access to care for patients, especially in rural and other underserved communities. This application will support a new investigator seeking to conduct research that examines the full continuum of dissemination, implementation, and sustainment of substance use disorder treatment, with the goal of identifying effective strategies for aligning the evidence base with actual treatment received by patients. The K01 award will provide mentorship and rich opportunities for developing new research skills and knowledge, enabling the investigator to transition to an independent researcher who will lead national efforts to improve treatment access, reduce drug-related harms, and decrease inequities in access and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Core 3: Mouse Models Core Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma is projected to become the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States within the next several years, and an important goal of the NCI has been to develop the knowledge needed to improve diagnostic and treatment strategies for this recalcitrant cancer. Each Project in this P01 proposal is reliant on mouse models to investigate epithelial and stromal interactions that drive both intrinsic and acquired therapeutic resistance, which together contribute to poor outcomes for patients with pancreatic cancer. The Mouse Models Core will work with each Research Project to: 1) investigate hypotheses generated from in vitro model systems using multiple in vivo experimental strategies, 2) test the efficacy and survival benefits of a variety of new therapeutic approaches based on fundamental advances generated by each Project, and 3) assure experimental consistency, rigor, and an economy of scale by serving as a center for performing complex surgeries and orthotopic transplants, and for monitoring survival enhancement in autochthonous models.

PHR: INTEGRATIVE MOLECULAR ANALYSIS CORE – PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of New Mexico Center for Metals in Biology and Medicine (UNM CMBM) Integrative Molecular Analysis Core has direct public health relevance as it will improve molecular analysis research and formally integrate existing UNM Health Sciences Center scientific resources, to foster research training and productivity for mentored investigators, as well as to bolster research quality and depth for our institute. Enhancing our molecular analysis capabilities will further strengthen capacity, quality, and impact of biomedical research for UNM as a whole, as the UNM CMBM will promote synergy primarily in the areas of cancer biology, nutrients and environmental health sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients undergo bladder reconstruction to improve or recover normal urinary function that has been impaired due to non-malignant conditions or as a consequence of surgical treatment of bladder cancer. Herein we propose the application of intrasurgical irreversible electroporation to decellularize an intestinal segment, engineering different types of tissue scaffolds that can aid bladder regeneration, further augmented by a biochemical agonist that can simulate the effects of mechanotransduction. The anticipated clinical impact is to improve the outcomes of reconstructive bladder surgery by reducing patient morbidity and through sustained increase in long-term bladder function, where the significance of our proposed work is underscored by the creation of new tools and techniques for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor sleep health is an underappreciated risk factor for disease, death, errors, and accidents among shift workers, who make up 20% of the US workforce. The purpose of the proposed K23 is to prepare the applicant for an independent clinical sleep research career by developing, refining, and pilot-testing a comprehensive, personalized, media-augmented telehealth intervention designed to improve sleep health among shift workers. This proposal will address the critical lack of evidence-based, accessible interventions by targeting shift workers' unique sleep health problems which manifest during both sleep (e.g., insomnia symptoms, short sleep duration) and wake (e.g., fatigue, sleepiness, poor executive function, depressive symptoms).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Stroke represents a major cause of death and disability in our elderly veterans. Stroke also represents a critical, and potentially preventable, risk factor for cognitive decline mostly in the form of vascular cognitive impairment. Silent brain infarctions are a recently recognized manifestation of covert cerebrovascular disease, without obvious clinical deficit, strongly linked to increased rates for both stroke and cognitive decline. Identifying early markers of stroke risk in all veterans is crucial for developing novel prevention and effective treatment strategies. An increased understanding of mechanisms responsible for silent brain infarcts will improve health care delivery for veterans by identifying potential targets for preventive pharmacological interventions that involve platelet reactivity in the preclinical stage of stroke. This will, in turn, lead to improved quality of life, better medical care and a decreased financial burden for the VA and for society as a whole.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative This proposal investigates the multifaced function of β-catenin in odontogenesis. Using genetically modified mouse strains, we developed new models to elucidate mechanisms underlying tooth morphogenesis mediated by classical and nonclassical signaling of β-catenin. The results obtained are highly relevant to the health of human development because Wnt signaling is causally linked to tooth agenesis and renewal, and understanding the odontogenic potential can facilitate the efficacy of stem cell-based tissue regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The spread of tuberculosis is a global health crisis leading to over one million deaths annually. The global burden of tuberculosis is a threat to the health of all Americans, and directly relevant to the mission of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, given the easy transmission of the disease through the air and the emergence of drug resistant strains that are difficult to treat. Moreover, there exists an increasing population of Americans with enhanced susceptibility to TB due to factors associated with compromised immune systems, including: HIV infection, the use of anti-rejection and anti-inflammatory drugs, as well as natural decreases in immunity associated with an aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: This proposal focuses on understanding the role of malaria in diminishing T cell immunity to Epstein-Barr Virus in children. These two infections interact to increase the risk of endemic Burkitt lymphoma, which is the most common childhood cancer in Equatorial Africa. Results from this study will help us understand how to prevent this cancer and to design better treatments to improve survival for these children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Throughout the developing world, health disparities begin at birth, in part because social discrimination and family contexts influence the health of pregnancy. In this mentored training project, PI Diane Coffey will be trained in the use of biomarkers and in the biology of stress as it relates to pregnancy. Such training will empower a research agenda that uses demographic data to explain inequalities in lifelong wellness as resulting, in part, from social and family structures that are embodied in biologically-measurable dimensions of healthy pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE. Genetic mitochondrial respiratory chain diseases result in severe disease, affecting nearly every organ system, including brain, heart, liver and eyes. Diagnosing primary respiratory chain deficiency is difficult, especially in the subset of diseases that affect Complex V (ATP Synthase; CV), the primary source of cellular energy. This work seeks to understand how CV deficiency affects cellular function both in resting cells and cells undergoing metabolic stress, providing a potential avenue for future diagnostic & treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE  American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Pacific Islanders are increasingly concerned about Alzheimer’s disease, dementia, and cognitive impairment. These conditions will soon have a major impact on their communities because the life expectancies for these groups have improved over the last 50 years by as much as 30 years, resulting in a large increase in the number of older adults. Unfortunately, the healthcare systems that serve these populations are unprepared for the clinical, economic, and social burdens associated with Alzheimer’s disease, dementia, and cognitive impairment. Our goal is to reduce disparities related to these conditions by testing various sustainable and culturally-appropriate interventions. The leadership, resources, and experience of our team can help address the National Institute on Aging’s research priorities for underrepresented minorities and respond to its interest in diversifying the scientific workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) are two fatal and incurable neurodegenerative diseases linked by a shared genetic cause – a heterozygous hexanucleotide (GGGGCC) repeat expansion in a single allele of the C9orf72 gene. The goal of this work is to develop novel CRISPR based therapeutic gene editing technologies and test whether gene editing can reverse the cellular pathology caused by this repeat expansion in patient derived cells. The results of these studies will advance our use of CRISPR technologies for therapeutic editing in FTD/ALS, inform our understanding of the regulation of C9orf72 gene, and will be applicable to many other repeat expansion and single gene disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteosarcoma is an aggressive pediatric solid malignancy that remains difficult to cure even with intensive chemotherapy and surgery. In this study, blood samples from patients with osteosarcoma will be used to profile circulating tumor DNA and circulating osteosarcoma cells to identify genomic features that are associated with a high-risk of treatment failure. Results from this study will enable the development of new risk-based and personalized treatment strategies for patients with osteosarcoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Experience-dependent adjustments of brain function, as it happens during learning and memory, critically rely on activity-dependent modifications of neural circuits that mainly occur at synapses. Alterations of this process is thought to underlie several brain diseases such as autism, epilepsy and major psychiatric disorders. The proposed studies seek to demonstrate a role for local protein synthesis in activity-dependent remodeling of the presynaptic compartment and long-term changes in neurotransmitter release.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Dental decay and tooth loss constitute an important public health issue. Stem cells in continuously growing dental tissues provide an excellent model for deciphering mechanisms that enable repair and regeneration of teeth, as well as other organs. This proposal will use state-of-the-art approaches to study how dental stem cells in the mouse incisor differentiate into enamel-producing ameloblasts, which will lay the long-term groundwork for clinical applications of stem cell biology in human dentition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Title: Human pregnane X receptor and sexual dimorphism in alcoholic liver disease. Alcoholic liver disease (ALD) is a disease that disproportionately affect women and African Americans (AAs). We have shown that the nuclear receptor pregnane X receptor (PXR) in mice promotes the development of ALD. Unexpectedly, we found that alcohol produced a more severe liver injury in female mice which carry the human PXR gene than female wild type mice. This study will use humanized animal models and human liver and blood samples of both sexes to provide important new insights into the mechanisms by which the human PXR gene promotes in ALD, especially in women and treatment options for ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Optic neuritis (ON) is a common manifestation of auto-immune demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and frequently results in visual impairment or permanent vision loss. Our understanding of the contribution of cholesterol homeostasis to MS-related ON pathology and repair is limited by the lack of detailed mechanistic insight into the dual role of cholesterol synthesis and transport in the retinogeniculate system. This proposal will use eye and brain organoids obtained from induced pluripotent stem cells of MS patients, MS donor eye tissue and in vivo models of ON to determine that restoration of cholesterol homeostasis ameliorates structural and functional impairment in MS-like ON and is a viable approach for future translational and therapeutic investigations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative MicroRNAs are important post-transcriptional regulators of gene expression and their mis-regulation has been linked to numerous diseases. The research program proposed here aims to provide insight into the structural and biochemical basis underlying the precise regulation of microRNA biogenesis. A better understanding of the structures, dynamics, and effector proteins regulating microRNA production is necessary for the development of targeted therapeutics to treat diseases linked to the dysregulated gene expression by microRNAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative In vertebrates, olfaction is intrinsically linked to motor action through sniffing, and just as for other sensory modalities, via head and body movements. Due to technical challenges, however, most studies have probed olfactory processing during passive sampling, and even when investigating odor-driven navigation, the effect of movements on odor neural responses has rarely been analyzed. Systematic investigation of the interactions between odor stimuli and sampling movements under closed-loop coupling is essential for understanding how movements and regulate olfactory perception and neural coding at different stages of processing within the mammalian olfactory system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative Many EBV+ lymphomas are able to evade the anti-EBV immune response through the restricted latency program I where only the weakly immunogenic EBNA1 protein is expressed. Here we will develop a novel approach to the treatment of EBV+ lymphomas by using hypomethylating agents to convert latency I tumors to the highly immunogenic latency III program, thereby sensitizing resistant tumors to an EBV-directed anti-tumor immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urogenital tract (UGT) infections with Chlamydia trachomatis (Ct) are increasingly prevalent, a major cause of reproductive morbidity, and annual UGT screening is recommended in <25 and high-risk women; screening for rectal CT infections is not recommended without exposure. The prospective cohort study described in this application will enroll women at high-risk for chlamydia but who have never had anal sex and, over 1-year, will (1) obtain monthly oral, vaginal, and rectal swabs to detect incident Ct infections, (2) collect quarterly blood and cervical cytobrush specimens to study systemic and cervical T-cell responses, and (3) capture weekly sexual behavior and symptoms data to screen for exposure and Ct-related symptoms. The goal of this project is to understand if rectal Ct infections in women are (Aim 1) frequent, long-lasting, asymptomatic, associated with specific rectal-tropic strains, and increase risk of UGT infection and (Aim 2) elicit significant systemic and cervical T-cell responses that may protect against incident UGT infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging adult sexual minority male and transgender individuals are more likely to report hazardous drinking and to have alcohol use disorders compared to those who are cisgender and heterosexual. This is concerning, as alcohol use contributes to HIV risk and HIV disproportionately affects this population. Through a randomized controlled trial, the proposed research will evaluate an enhanced motivational interviewing intervention that utilizes smartphones and mobile breathalyzers to provide real-time messaging that addresses triggers for drinking when individuals visit locations associated with risky alcohol use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative In Phase I, we launched the Center for Translational Pediatric Research at Arkansas Children’s Research Institute in Little Rock, Arkansas. The mission of the center is to use proteogenomic approaches to identify epigenomic mechanisms and therapeutic targets in diseases, including cancer, impacting or translatable to the pediatric population. Our goals for the upcoming Phase II are to further enhance our institutional research infrastructure by developing our multi-disciplinary, thematic research center through strategic expansion of the critical mass of investigators, investing into research infrastructure, and implementing a plan for long-term center sustainability.

PHR: Cancer cell quiescence is an understudied mechanism of chemotherapy resistance and drives poor outcomes for patients with ovarian cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with metastatic Ewing sarcoma have a less than 10% survival rate at five years; therefore, identification of novel therapeutic targets and strategies are urgently needed to treat this type of cancer. This proposal focuses on the functional characterization of LIPI as a cell surface protein with oncogenic function and a potential immunotherapy target due to its highly specific expression pattern in Ewing sarcoma. Ultimately, the results obtained from this proposal will offer significant mechanistic understanding of the players involved in Ewing sarcoma growth and metastasis as well as making a clinical impact by identifying potential targets for treating this disease through cellular therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe and fatal COVID-19 is the result of an exaggerated inflammatory response, but what determines whether an individual has an effective antiviral immune response with mild disease, or an exaggerated response, remains unknown. The proposed research project will test whether age-related immune dysregulation and/or viral- mediated splicing disruption during the earliest phase of infection leads to a delayed or suppressed interferon response permissive to rapid viral proliferation, and a subsequently exaggerated inflammatory response. The study is uniquely able to analyze this elusive early period through the full course of infection by leveraging a repository of paired nasal swab and saliva specimens prospectively collected twice-per-day from patients who became infected with SARS-CoV-2 while enrolled in a COVID-19 household transmission study co-designed and co-led by the applicant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Adult hippocampal neurogenesis plays a critical role in regulating memory and emotion, and this process is dynamically regulated by neural circuit activity. We recently identified a key subcortical region, supramammillary nucleus (SuM) in the hypothalamus, that robustly modulates hippocampal neurogenesis. Our proposal aims to decipher mechanisms underlying SuM-mediated modulation of AHN and activity-dependent contribution of SuM- enhanced ABNs to brain-wide network dynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microglia are the immune cells of the brain and are important in shaping neuronal connections during normal brain development. I have established a new system to study how microglia interact with neuronal connections known as synapses using the zebrafish vertebrate model. I will take advantage of this model to define how the immune system aids in brain development, as well as in hyperactive states like epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurofibromatosis is an autosomal dominant disorder whose neurodevelopmental symptoms include attentional deficits, autistic features, and abnormal processing of visual information. In this research proposal, we will use a multidisciplinary approach to identify retinal and midbrain circuits that contribute to visual processing deficits, which will greatly expand our understanding of these symptoms and provide circuit-level therapeutic targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Patients with electrical conduction problems in the heart have no current therapeutic options for regenerating the cardiac tissue to restore conduction and reduce arrhythmia risks. This project aims to address this gap by developing a new technology that will precisely deliver a cardiomyocyte-coated thread to the heart to create a conductive cell bridge for long-lasting improvement of coordination of cardiac excitation. Successful completion of this project will increase our capabilities to regenerate conduction in multiple etiologies of conduction disorder in the heart with the long-term goal of reducing arrhythmia and improving patient outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – HEALTH RELEVANCE Gaining insight into the molecular basis for the opposing roles that the ERK2-DBP and D domains play in MPN pathogenesis will enable us to exploit this information to develop new strategies for therapeutic intervention. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths worldwide and has limited treatment options. This project proposes to dissect the mechanisms underlying the oncogenic activity of eIF5B, an important translation factor that is overexpressed in lung cancer, using mouse models and human cells. Elucidating the role of this protein in lung cancer pathogenesis and characterizing the translational program driven by eIF5B will ultimately reveal new mechanisms of translational control in tumor progression and immune evasion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite improved survival rates and treatment options, individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) continue to face lifelong disability. Due to disruptions that occur in the pathways of the central nervous system, people with SCI often experience significantly reduced ability to control their movements as well as painful muscle conditions such as spasticity, reducing independence, placing increased burden on caregivers, and increasing healthcare expenses. This project is relevant to public health because it will help guide our understanding of how remaining neural connections reorganize after injury and how transmission in these motor pathways may contribute to the development of overactive reflexes, providing comprehensive knowledge about how to improve existing treatments and develop new rehabilitation strategies for SCI and other neurological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The purpose of our proposed study is to elucidate how mutations in the NEK1 kinase cause Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), an untreatable and devastating neurodegenerative disease. We will use a range of approaches including induced pluripotent stem cell-derived neurons, Drosophila models and postmortem ALS patient tissue to define the role of NEK1 in motor neurons and determine how its dysfunction leads to their eventual degeneration. Our work will contribute towards the identification of therapeutic targets that could be broadly relevant for ALS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Viruses deliver genetic information into living cells overcoming the complexity of biological membranes that surround cells and their organelles. In this proposal, we study the molecular machines and mechanisms used by bacterial viruses and herpesviruses to eject their large DNA genomes into prokaryotic and human cells. This research fills several conceptual gaps in biology, paving the way to understand the molecular mechanisms of virulence and to the application of bacterial viruses in biotechnology and medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA deaminase enzymes of the AID/APOBEC3 family are critical for immune defense but can also mistarget the host genome and contribute to cancer mutagenesis. This proposal aims to leverage knowledge of mechanism and specificity of these enzymes to develop potent antagonists to counteract their pro-mutagenic activities. The outcome of this work will be the first specific and cell-active inhibitors developed using a new paradigm, whereby functionalized DNA can be used to probe or therapeutically inhibit DNA-altering processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) are the most common malignancy and leading cause of death in individuals with the common genetic disease neurofibromatosis type 1. At present, the poor outcomes seen with MPNSTs reflect our limited understanding of the key factors activating Ras signaling in these tumors coupled with an effective means of inhibiting Ras-related signaling abnormalities. This project will address this problem by establishing the therapeutic effectiveness of directly inhibiting key receptor tyrosine kinases driving hyperactive Ras signaling in MPNSTs and understanding holistically how therapeutic effectiveness changes during the course of treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Clinical trials determine whether a neuroscience discovery can improve the health of people with neurological disorders. They are frequently hampered by regulatory or budgetary issues, difficulties with patient recruitment, and other inefficiencies. The proposed CinciNEXT clinical site will partner with the NeuroNEXT network to improve clinical trial efficiency to bring more treatments to people with neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glia and neurons must work together to ensure that appropriate synaptic connections are made and maintained throughout our lives. I recently completed a screen to identify novel glial regulators of synapse development, and found that the immune receptor Crq is required for elimination of inappropriate synapses that initially form during synaptic development. In this proposal, I will address which synapses undergo developmental synapse elimination and which are dependent on Crq, identify the ligand(s) that specify which synapses should be selectively eliminated, and evaluate whether these same mechanisms contribute to the synaptic loss that underlies age-related cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This proposal addresses the need for effective implementation of decentralized HIV care in an urban setting in Lima, Peru, where low levels of retention in care has resulted in low viral suppression levels and increased HIV incidence. Decentralization, an evidence-based practice to improve retention in care, will be guided using NIATx, an evidenced-informed implementation toolkit, combined with Project ECHO, an evidence-informed tele- education strategy to improve specialty clinical skills for non-specialists. The implementation trial uses a stepped wedge design in four large metropolitan regions in Peru with outcomes informed by the RE-AIM implementation framework.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Importance to public health: The purpose of this project is to develop a vaccine to prevent an emerging infectious disease, human monocytic ehrlichiosis by blocking transmission of Ehrlichia chaffeensis from ticks to mammals. Ultimately, our findings are expected to reveal rational combinations of vaccine candidates and delivery methods for tick-borne pathogens that could serve as relevant scientific direction for future prophylactic discovery; however, what is learned will contribute to a broader understanding of formulation and delivery methods of vaccines for tick-borne pathogens. Relevance to NIH’s mission: our work pertains to developing fundamental and translational knowledge that will reduce the burden of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Pseudohypoparathyroidism type Ib (PHP1B) is a rare imprinting disorder that can be caused by deletions/inversions/duplications involving STX16/GNAS. However, most cases are unresolved and previously not recognized abnormalities have emerged, including reduced fertility requiring IVF. By identifying novel human defects and by generating mice with mutations through iGONAD, the mechanisms allowing parent-specific GNAS methylation will be determined.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE  In this project the investigators investigate the previously unknown interactions between calvarial bone injury- induced stem cell niche signaling and the suture stem cells, which are known to play major roles in calvarial bone regeneration. The proposed studies, based on previously published and recently unpublished novel findings, will have broad impact in understanding the molecular circuitry governing craniofacial regeneration and significantly advance our understanding of how injury reshape the niche that regulates stem cell migration, expansion and differentiation. The proposed studies will identify new regulatory components and pathways in calvarial bone regeneration to shed new light on promoting calvrial bone regeneration and treating various skeletal diseases including craniofacial abnormalities.

PHR: Project narrative Mayaro virus (MAYV) is the second leading cause of alphavirus-induced febrile illness in South American countries. This project will investigate the adaptation of MAYV to be better transmitted by the urban vectors Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus. Our findings will fill critical missing knowledge to our understanding of MAYV transmission and will identify and experimentally validate viral genes associated with enhanced transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance to public health: The long-term goal of the proposed Florida International Health Disparities Initiative (FIU-HDI) is to strengthen and expand capacity-building efforts of the current, ongoing FIU-HDI. These efforts include expanding FIU’s research infrastructure to train the next generation of public health, clinical, biomedical, and behavioral researchers at FIU’s Robert Stempel College of Public Health & Social Work and Herbert Wertheim College of Medicine to address health disparities in communicable and noncommunicable health conditions—and advance health equity—among underserved populations in South Florida and the Caribbean. Using community-engaged multidisciplinary approaches, these efforts will: (a) translate into advances in culturally competent interventions, leading to measurable and sustained improvements in health outcomes in these populations, and (b) enable FIU to continue contributing to diversification in the health disparities scientific workforce.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The research program proposed here will provide insights into the guidance cues that support long-distance collective migration of the caudal visceral mesoderm (CVM) in the Drosophila embryo, a process that is required for the assembly of the midgut musculature. Due to the similarities between CVM development and intestinal smooth muscle cell (ISMC) specification in vertebrates, studying CVM cell migration has the potential to provide insight into the basis for human congenital defects such as familial visceral myopathy (FVM). Furthermore, anoikis, or the programmed cell death (PCD) of migrating cells that have detached or adhered to an inappropriate substrate, has been observed in CVM cells; as anoikis resistance is a hallmark of metastatic cancer, the CVM cell migration model has the potential to provide widely-applicable insights into the developmental and pathological mechanisms governing organogenesis and disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The primary goal of this project is to use network analyses to construct a Feeding Interaction Network using automated feeding data collected from animals living in large breeding groups at the Yerkes National Primate Research Center. If successful, these models will identify groups at risk for social instability before the onset of fighting and injury. The application of automated feeding data in the social management of captive colonies of rhesus macaques represents a paradigm shift from more conventional practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Co-morbid chronic pain-depression is common among older Blacks and this co-morbidity worsens physical and emotional function. Access to evidence based non-pharmacological management is limited by systemic racism, stigma, and the lack of culturally-tailored care. Mindfulness based cognitive therapy (MBCT) is an evidence-based, non-pharmacological intervention that could address the social-determinants of the chronic pain-depression co-morbidity among older Blacks, but it requires tailoring. The proposed study will establish the feasibility, acceptability and credibility of Quiet Focus, a cultural adaptation of MBCT aimed at the chronic pain-depression co-morbidity among older Blacks in the community.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The storage of fats (lipids) in fat tissue is crucial for persevering insulin sensitivity and metabolic health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is a complex disease involving many different types of cells interacting in dozens of ways. Due to this complexity, animal models of cancer are of immense value for discovering new ways to diagnose and treat cancer. In this project, the Animal Core Facility will assist both COBRE-supported researchers and the broader NDSU community with the establishment and maintenance of research paradigms involving animals with the long-term goal of developing new therapeutic options for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Biostatistics and Bioinformatics Core (B2C) As the only Biostatistics and Bioinformatics Core specializing in pancreatic cancer research in the region, the B2C will continue to play an integral role in the Center for Diagnostic and Therapeutic Strategies in Pancreatic Cancer (CDTSPC) and the greater North Dakota State University (NDSU) community by providing high-quality, comprehensive study design and data analysis support to all CDTSPC and NDSU researchers. A specific emphasis will be placed on providing this support at all stages of the research process to the Junior Investigators' translational and pre-clinical pancreatic cancer research projects, ensuring that all projects are properly designed and well-powered and increasing the likelihood of securing competitive federally funded research grants. In addition, Phase II of this project will expand the B2C services beyond traditional statistical techniques of the bench and clinical research into other emerging "big data" research areas, including bioinformatics and machine learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma is one of the most lethal human malignancies, with a median overall survival of less than one year and 5-year survival of 10.8%. Lack of efficient strategies to achieve cytotoxic concentrations of chemotherapeutics in the tumor tissue and the tumor's innate resistance to chemotherapy are significant barriers to improving pancreatic cancer treatment outcomes. The proposed research aims to investigate bioengineered mesenchymal stem cells as a novel drug delivery platform for tumor-selective delivery of a synergistic combination of oxaliplatin and entinostat to improve therapeutic efficacy while minimizing toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Regardless of all efforts to develop new technologies and treatments, the 5-year survival rate for PDAC remains low. Although crucial for current cancer therapy, the conventional anticancer drugs used to kill tumor cells and damage healthy cells, wreaking havoc on the rest of the body, decreasing treatment efficacy, and favoring de novo carcinogenesis. Especially in hard-to-treat cancers such as pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), the limitation of the current treatments leads patients to believe, at present, that surgical resection is the only potential cure. Regrettably, only 15-20% of the cases are resectable, the recurrence rate is still high, and the unavoidable rates of long-term survival are dismal. As a solution for the lack of possibilities to increase patients' survival rate, health, and cure during conventional therapy, we propose a new approach to cancer treatment that will selectively kill tumor cells in any proliferative stage with the potential to eradicate the tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE For many individuals suffering with an alcohol use disorder, the current treatments for are insufficient, suggesting that novel therapeutic targets should be explored. Research has established that the neuroimmune system is impacted by excessive drinking, and that manipulating the neuroimmune response can be protective against binge-like drinking. The results of the current study will show how binge drinking alters astrocytes, key regulators of the neuroimmune response, as well as whether astrocytes and their signaling pathways represent a novel therapeutic avenues to treat alcohol abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: HBCD-NC Project Narrative Various adverse and protective environments may affect child development. The Healthy Brain and Child Development National Consortium (HBCD-NC) will follow 7,500 mothers and their children from 24 locations across the U.S. from before birth to 10 years of age to better understand which harmful and protective environments exert the greatest impact on child development. This study will help to improve the health and development of children across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of the proposed research is to understand how cells acquire the capacity to elicit specific responses to environmental cues. We aim to define the mechanistic roles of a novel chromatin remodeling complex in equipping T cells early in development with the potential to kill, secrete cytokines, and promote other T cell-specific functions. Understanding these fundamental processes will allow the modulation of T cell effector programming which can enhance vaccination, cancer immunotherapy and ameliorate autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The PI3K (phosphoinositide 3-kinase)/AKT signaling pathway is one of the most frequently deregulated signaling nodes in virtually all human solid and hematological malignancies. The overall goal of this 7 year application is to dissect the regulation and function of PI3K and AKT proteins in the context of modulating reprogramming of metabolic pathways and identifying downstream mechanisms of PI3K and AKT that lead to tumor initiation and progression. We propose that new findings emerging from this project may lead to new therapeutic opportunities for effectively treating those cancers that harbor PI3K pathway lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Streamlined and comprehensive molecular profiling of circulating tumor exosomes is critical to unlock the wealth of disease information in these extracellular vesicles. Selective immunocapturing and concentrating of exosomes on a bio-chip examined at microscopic resolution are critical for accentuating the CTE signal among a large background from the vast majority of normal exosomes. We propose to develop a novel technological platform to provide radical advancement in the ability to count single exosomes and associate the surface protein and cargo genetic biomarkers with cancer, a goal aligned with NIH’s mission of developing new approaches critical for cancer diagnostics and detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a bacterium that infects people with immune compromise, engages in a process of cell-cell communication called quorum sensing. This project seeks to answer how quorum sensing changes in people with chronic infections, with the idea that these studies will eventually lead to development of new therapies for bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is one of the deadliest cancers and is characterized by an expansion of fibroblasts which modulate the tumor microenvironment. This proposal aims to elucidate molecular signatures and functions of cancer associated fibroblast subtypes in PDAC. This research will contribute to fundamental knowledge of PDAC biology, and may ultimately lead to design of more effective therapeutics for PDAC patients.
