IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Abnormalities in the Positive Valence System (PVS) are associated with depressive symptoms and reduced behavioral activation in mid- and late-life. This study will investigate the engagement of the PVS during exposure to social rewards, part of a novel streamlined psychotherapy for mid- and late-life depression. Use of computational modeling will enable identification of neuroimaging and behavioral profiles associated with greater treatment response, and may guide future personalization of psychotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This program trains students to understand both the life of a cell at the molecular level and how this relates to human health. This is achieved through a combination of formal lectures, mentored laboratory-based research, and group-learning experiences, with a foundation of scientific rigor and transparency. The anticipated outcome of this educational experience is to nurture a diverse, close-knit group of students who are equipped to become the next generation of outstanding scientists in a variety of careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Glia play important roles in neural development, synapse plasticity and normal brain function, but it remains largely unknown how glia are involved in stabilizing the synapse through the action of homeostatic mechanisms. Epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a dynamic process that is sensitive to changes in neuronal function in mature nervous systems. In this proposal, we will take advantage of transcriptome profiling, genetic, molecular, cellular, electrophysiological, imaging and bioinformatic approaches to systematically dissect how the glial epigenome responds to chronic perturbations and stabilizes synapse physiology in the nervous system.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Maximizing independent function during the progressive decline of balance and mobility in older adults with chronic diseases, such as Parkinson's disease (PD), is a unique challenge for rehabilitation. Tele-rehabilitation for balance disorders is relatively unexplored and may be beneficial to older adults who cannot attend in-person rehabilitation. In this project, we will test 80 people with PD to: 1) determine if using wearable sensors at home can improve objective assessment of balance and 2) investigate if balance-focused tele-rehabilitation can improve balance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Optimizing genetic counseling (GC) quality and improving efficiency of care will require the profession to first be able to accurately and comprehensively measure GC processes and determine which processes are most critical to achieve positive patient outcomes. This research will measure variability in GC processes using a novel, pragmatic measure and link variations in processes and session time to patient-reported outcomes. Using community-based and practitioner-engaged participatory research approaches, this study will test a genetic counseling efficiency intervention with the goal of improving patient reported outcomes in prenatal, cancer, and cardiology settings and increasing GC efficiency by reducing in person visit time.

PHR: Narrative Colonization of the mucosa of the upper airways is the first step in pathogenesis of the leading respiratory tract pathogen Streptococcus pneumoniae. This ongoing project examines host and bacterial factors to understand the key molecular characteristics of colonization including why it i) is prolonged, ii) recurrent, iii) varies markedly by serotype, iv) is most prevalent during infancy, and v) leads to host-to-host transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The PhD in Clinical Investigation (PCI) at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine combines specialized training to prepare biomedical scientists to understand and appreciate the methodologies of clinical and population science, to practice team science as both leaders and members of research teams, and to advance the discipline of translational science. Building from our program's success and increased demand, we seek to evolve PCI by incorporating formalized emphases on integrating TS and health equity (HE) into our training. During the next funding period, we seek to leverage the non-categorical PCI and develop new Research Focus Areas in Infectious Disease, Cancer Outcomes, and Brain Sciences, to provide PCI trainees with funding opportunities that go beyond the four disease-agnostic slots while emphasizing our institutional strengths and applying TS and HE lenses to all trainees' projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity, particularly when accompanied by visceral and hepatic adiposity and low physical fitness, can cause insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes in youth and is a major pediatric public health concern. The mission of the C-DART program is to train post-doctoral MD physician-scientists for productive academic careers in clinical and basic research in prevention and treatment of insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes mellitus and other metabolic complications of obesity and excess visceral and hepatic fat deposition in children.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unintended pregnancy and rising rates of sexually transmitted infections significantly impact the health and economic burden of individuals and communities in the United States. This is particularly true for health disparities faced by Latinx youth. This research extends a study examining structural and interpersonal factors that affect youth violence and sexual health in early adolescence (ages 13 to 15) in a California agricultural community shaped by socioeconomic disparities resulting from generations of Mexican migration. We will follow youth through emerging adulthood (ages 18 to 21) to understand the social factors that affect sexual health outcomes, which will help us develop interventions to improve sexual health and well-being during this critical life transition among Latinx youth who constitute an underserved and growing US population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: These studies will define the molecular interactions and bacterial factors regulating apoptotic and pyroptotic single-cell death outcomes during Yersinia infection, informing potential immunological therapies to better combat bacterial infections. Importantly, the experiments proposed in these studies use powerful single  cell-based approaches, allowing us to define previously unobserved cell fate choices that are masked by bulk population-based assays. Since cell death is a conserved immune response against microbial infections, and apoptosis and pyroptosis result in drastically different consequences to surrounding cells and tissues, findings from this work will inform host-centric therapeutic and experimental approaches to combat bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This multidisciplinary program aims to develop next generation optical coherence tomography (OCT) methods and new imaging biomarkers of retinal microvascular and relative blood flow speeds at the capillary level for understanding and managing diabetic retinopathy (DR). The proposed studies address impactful questions related to clinical DR management, including early disease detection, predicting risk, monitoring disease progression and treatment response, and improving clinical trial efficiency. The long term goal is to create an imaging based tool to guide medical intervention and accelerate drug development, which can lead to better preservation of visual function in DR patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of the Precision Medicine, Education, Data Informatics, and Community Translation (PREDICT) Institute is to serve as a holistic and replicable framework for the utilization of electronic health data and community translation to affect the decision- making process to improve health outcomes. The PREDICT Institute will extend the technical research exchange (TREX) program at Xavier to include training of current and future underrepresented researchers on health informatics best practices to diversify the research workforce and leverage community-based approaches to enhance clinical research efforts in vulnerable populations. The use of population health and bioinformatics data will demonstrate their value as useful tools in collective approaches required to achieve health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The cellular positive transcription elongation factor b (P-TEFb) is required for transcription of HIV and cellular genes critical for immune functions. However, P-TEFb is severely down-regulated in latently infected cells as well as dysfunctional immune cells frequently occurring in HIV-infected individuals. Our proposed study will establish methods to alter P-TEFb functions in these cells, which would be beneficial for controlling HIV latency and improving immune functions in these individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) causes several human cancers including Kaposi’s sarcoma, primary effusion lymphoma and multicentric Castleman’s disease. These malignancies inflict morbidity and mortality to the society in US and worldwide. This project will investigate the mechanisms mediating the metabolic pathways supporting the growth and survival KSHV-induced cancer cells, and identify potential therapeutic targets for developing novel prevention and treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The REFOCUS project-“Research Examining Factors Associated with the Opioid Crisis among Underserved African Americans” has significant public health implications by examining how structural, social and cultural factors influence nonmedical prescription opioid use (NMPOU) and treatment service use among African Americans across the adult lifespan. Overdose rates have risen exponentially among African Americans but this group has received much less attention. The REFOCUS project will generate data directly applicable to culturally-tailor interventions targeting African American opioid users in order to reduce NMPOU and improve treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative We recently showed that patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) that have high inflammation have poor outcomes and demonstrate that a distinct immune response cooperates with mutational background to promote leukemogenesis, including remodeling of the bone marrow niche expansion of dysfunctional B and T cell populations. We hypothesize that targeting this aberrant immune response will modulate disease progression and therapeutic response. Our proposal is designed to deepen our understanding of the different contributors to inflammation in AML and to delineate the inflammatory response of AML patients of specific molecular subgroups of AML that generally confer high inflammation during different frontline therapies to improve treatment response and survival of these poor-risk patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT: This study addresses the unsolved problem of chemotherapy resistance in advanced cancers through evidence- based treatment combinations that target Chase, an enzyme first of its kind. Chase renders the common chemotherapy drug Gemcitabine ineffective. Development of the combinations concurrently with the evaluation of Chase and related molecules as predictors of treatment response could enable the clinical translation of these combinations for the treatment of high-risk, advanced bladder cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the prevalence and cost alcohol use disorder (AUD), treatment strategies are ineffective, especially in preventing relapse. A key feature of AUD is that following long-term drinking, alcohol taking and seeking is motivated by the drive to avoid alcohol’s withdrawal symptoms. This proposal focuses on understanding how the brain controls the motivation to avoid the negative states induced by withdrawal and how we can use this understanding to prevent relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the molecular basis of HIV infection is critical to the development of new preventative, therapeutic, and curative treatments. This project focuses on understanding the role of CPSF6 in the virus lifecycle, a host protein recruited to the incoming virus core for yet unknown reasons. We hypothesize that recruitment of CPSF6 disrupts its normal function in the host cell, contributing to a permissive state for virus replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ion channels are a major protein class important for human health and disease. Although many ion channels are linked to Mendelian disorders, a major challenge is to understand which mutations in these genes disrupt the function of the protein and cause disease. This work will study large patient cohorts and generate large in vitro functional datasets to better understand ion channel biology and decipher which mutations in ion channel genes are linked to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease and stroke are the leading causes of death and disability in the United States, and are intimately related to cognitive impairment and dementia. Cardiovascular disease is not simply a disease of the heart or blood vessels, but rather it impacts every organ. We propose a Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE), the “Vermont Center on Cardiovascular and Brain Health” (VCCBH) that will nucleate the University of Vermont's considerable research expertise in cardiovascular and neurovascular research to address these issues from diverse, mutually reinforcing basic science, clinical science and epidemiology perspectives. While advancing science, the Center will support the transition of early career faculty to independent scientists.

PHR: The Network of Excellence in Neuroscience Clinical Trials (NeuroNEXT) at the University of Pittsburgh (NEXT- UP) will continue to leverage the regional dominance of UPMC in healthcare, the CTSI, existing clinical research networks at the University of Pittsburgh, and other institutional resources for its successful clinical trials structure. NEXT-UP will actively support career development for early stage academic clinician researchers in neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance: Atherosclerosis is a progressive cardiovascular disease that remains the leading cause of death in the USA and worldwide in spite of widespread use of statins, other lipid lowering therapies, and life-style modifications. Of major concern, the incidence of symptomatic atherosclerosis in younger individuals is rising at an alarming rate primarily due to the global epidemic of obesity and early onset type 2 (insulin resistant) diabetes (T2D) and the associated metabolic disease (MetD) characterized by insulin resistance and increases in blood glucose, insulin, triglycerides, and cholesterol levels. Indeed, numerous high quality studies provide evidence that each of these factors may contribute to accelerated atherosclerosis development, progression, and end stage disease pathogenesis including rupture of the protective fibrous cap overlying advanced atherosclerotic lesions resulting in a heart attack or stroke. However, a major unresolved question is which if any of the T2D/MetD associated changes impair the ability of smooth muscle cells (SMC) or other cell types to form and maintain the protective fibrous cap. The goals of studies in this proposal are to address this question, and to identify novel therapeutic approaches to enhance the ability of these cells to form and maintain a thick and mechanically robust fibrous cap (i.e. analogous to a stronger patch on a tire) even in the context of T2D/MetD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) represent one of the greatest health problems in the United States and the state of Michigan. Building on longstanding strengths in dementia research, outreach and training at three universities working as a consortium, the Michigan ADRC will lead a regional effort to identify, understand and modulate the many factors beyond β-amyloid that contribute to brain dysfunction and degeneration in ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent technological advances have enabled the production of large immune monitoring datasets, providing an opportunity for systems-level efforts to harness the power of the immune system in developing immune therapies and diagnostic tests. In this project, we will develop machine learning algorithms for analysis of the immune system at a single-cell level, in a multiomics setting integrated with various other biological measurements, and subject to adjustments based on population-level factors. This work will provide a strong quantitative bridge between large-scale epidemiologic trends and deep biological profiling to investigate the complex mechanisms that govern the immune system in clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE More than 400 million people suffer from diabetes in the world and one third of them may eventually develop diabetic kidney disease (DKD). The loss of podocytes, an integral part of the filtration system in the kidney, is a major contributor to the DKD progression. In this research proposal, we aim to investigate the mechanisms mediating the podocyte loss in diabetic kidney disease, so that future therapeutic approaches may be developed to mitigate the podocyte loss in DKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research represents a new and alternative strategy for characterizing important structural parameters of disordered proteins, proteins with intrinsically disordered regions, and mixtures of disordered proteins, all of which are critical for cellular function and are implicated in many degenerative disorders and epigenetic diseases. Disorder makes these proteins difficult to characterize structurally, and existing methods for analyzing them are unable to separately analyze mixtures of disordered proteins often found in cells. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission as it contributes to the fundamental knowledge of human molecular biology and is relevant for its application in reducing illness in patients with neurodegenerative disorders and epigenetic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative TBCK-encephalopathy is a recently described genetic disorder that causes intellectual disability, seizures and weakness in children across the world. Most of the children affected to date are Puerto Rican, presenting with severe loss of neurologic function, while other children have milder symptoms. Elucidating how loss of the TBCK protein leads to neurologic disease, particularly by examining the role mitochondria in relevant disease models, may provide insight into the mechanisms that lead to neurodegeneration and may help develop new therapies for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project narrative Treatment of melanoma with drugs leads to the emergence of new cell lineages that are drug resistant. In this proposal we will explore whether the new cell states that convey resistance in melanoma are dependent upon an epigenetic enzyme called histone deacetylase HDAC8. We will determine how activation of HDAC8 allows melanoma cells to survive in the presence of drug and to evade immune attack, and will develop new therapeutic strategies that limit HDAC8-mediated drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The virus that causes COVID-19 has a large RNA genome that often folds into structures at important sites. We will attack its genome using a new type of nucleic acid drug that recognizes not only the sequence but also the structure of the viral RNA. Using this innovative technology, we have identified promising drug candidates and will optimize them and discover new drugs for effectively treating the disease.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Mechanical signals promote osteoblast differentiation and bone formation, but the molecular mechanisms remain unclear. The aim of proposed studies is to uncover the underlying mechanisms and this will be accomplished by studying a mechanosensitive ion channel Piezo1 and its downstream effectors in osteocytes. The successful completion of this work may provide new strategies to modulate regenerative responses and develop therapies to treat the bone loss related to disuse or advanced age.

PHR: This application is for continued T32 support of a research training program at Stanford University to create independent scholars who can conduct rigorous research on ethical, legal and social implications of genetics and genomics (ELSI). Since 2016, with support of a T32 award, we have appointed 7 postdoctoral scholars into the program, all women, one Latina and one African-American. The goal of this renewal is to train 7 more postdoctoral fellows and to continue our successful contribution to the diversity and excellence of the ELSI research communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: As the human lifespan increases, a critical challenge is to simultaneously improve healthspan. Studying individuals that are predisposed to exceptional longevity will help us achieve that goal. Biobehavioral factors can extend healthspan, by improving well-being and driving healthier outcomes. We will develop a monkey model of familial exceptional longevity and identify the unique biobehavioral phenotypes of these individuals to stimulate new research that will help people live longer, healthier lives.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will develop a fluid mechanics approach to studying tracer transport through tissue for perfusion quantification in magnetic resonance imaging, which is termed as quantitative transport mapping (QTM). Thesuccessful outcome of this project will establish the fluid mechanics based QTM for perfusion quantification as a more effective alternative to Kety's method with preservation of local mass conservation and without the problem of arterial input function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  This proposal focuses on the fungal pathogenic Mucor species complex, which includes zygomycete pathogens that cause devastating infections in humans that are difficult to treat, with limited drug treatment options, and requiring surgical debridement in some patients. In this proposal, we aim to elucidate the molecular mechanisms and targets of epimutation, a novel mechanism of antimicrobial drug resistance in which RNAi silences drug target genes, and define the impact of host-pathogen interactions on epimutation. Results from these studies will inform treatment and prevention strategies for patients afflicted with Mucor infections by providing insights into novel mechanisms of pathogenesis and resistance to antifungal drugs as well as by stimulating development of novel antifungal drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cytochrome b5 reductase 3 (Cyb5R3) regulates soluble guanylyl cyclase heme iron redox state, a key enzyme controlling cerebral artery vascular tone. In this application, we will investigate whether a high frequency genetic variant (T117S) in Cyb5R3, which exists with 23% minor allele frequency in African Americans compared to less than 1% in Euro-Americans, contributes to cerebral vascular dysfunction and ischemic stroke. The proposed studies will fill a major void in our understanding of the role of CYB5R3 T117S in the pathogenesis of ischemic stroke, with the potential for the development of new strategies and therapeutics to treat a large proportion of AA who suffer from ischemic stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Mishandling of salt balance by our body contributes to the development and progression of many common diseases, including hypertension and organ damage due to failure to remove excess amount of salt. We propose to demonstrate a new major regulatory mechanism of salt handling by the kidney, and that malfunction of this mechanism by the protein Na/K-ATPase compromises our body's ability to remove salt from the body. Therefore, the proposed investigation has profound basic and clinical implications, and may also provide new targets for developing better therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nanotechnology has provided important advancements in the area of engineering innovation, however, introduction of engineered nanomaterials in these technologies is not without hazard, and the negative effects on human health, at present, can only be speculated without detailed evaluation of their toxic nature. The proposed experiments are relevant to public health because they will enhance our understanding of the pathogenesis of engineered nanomaterial exposure and aid in the development of biomarkers and prophylactic interventions designed to lessen complications that are associated with engineered nanomaterial exposure. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission that pertains to the pursuit of fundamental knowledge to extend healthy life and reduce the burden of illness.

PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to the mission of the NIH because Cryptococcus neoformans is an important human pathogen that is difficult to treat with limited drug options, and this project aims to understand a novel mechanism of antifungal drug resistance. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Low-grade gliomas (LGG) predominantly affect adolescent and young adult (AYA) patients and two thirds of these patients experience malignant progression and lethal outcomes given we have no effective strategies or treatments to predict or prevent malignant progression. We discovered that current treatment failures are associated with the accumulation of immunosuppressive myeloid cells from the bone marrow, which evolve to impair the function of anti-tumor immunity. With this study, our goal is to develop novel immune surveillance approaches for AYA patients with LGGs at risk for malignant progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This project seeks to elucidate the concept of the brain cell type and its relation to the brain architecture and function, by establishing links between molecular and anatomical cell types, circuit connectivity, and functional neural activity in the mouse primary visual cortex (V1). We will record activity of neurons, use multiplexed fluorescence in-situ hybridization (mFISH) to identify their cell types as defined by gene expression, analyze neuronal morphologies and connectivity using Electron Microscopy (EM) reconstruction of the V1 circuit, and release the resulting data and knowledge as a free atlas for the community. The findings and data from this project will serve as foundational resources for future scientific studies and biomedical applications aiming to leverage the relations between brain cell types, circuit structure, and its function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Little is known about what host-microbe interactions mediate urinary tract infections (UTI) by Acinetobacter baumannii, a bacterial pathogen whose alarming rates of multi-drug resistance (MDR) poses a global health threat. Given the waning effectiveness of antibiotic therapies, we must investigate the host and microbial determinants of MDR A. baumannii UTI in order to develop novel, antibiotic-sparing therapies and identify patients at risk of these infections. We propose a multidisciplinary approach that will not only address fundamental questions on A. baumannii uropathogenesis, but can also be readily applied to address similar questions in other forms of MDR A. baumannii disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Antibiotics are often prescribed using a “one-size-fits-all” approach in critically ill patients, despite the multiple physiologic changes that occur during critical illness and can affect antibiotic concentrations and exposure (pharmacokinetics) and their ability to reach targets (pharmacodynamics). This proposal seeks to develop and prospectively validate population models describing antibiotic concentrations and their variability in critical illness for use in model-informed precision dosing (MIPD), an approach in which dosing regimens can be tailored to individual patient and clinical factors, and to evaluate the association between antibiotic target attainment and outcomes. This research is highly relevant to public health as it will optimize the use of antibiotics in critically ill patients, maximizing their efficacy and limiting their toxicity to improve clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will identify brain and biobehavioral mechanisms that explain why individuals with depression show diverse patterns of success or failure with regulating their affect and their parasympathetic nervous system. We will identify subgroups based on their patterns of success with regulation in everyday life, examine brain mechanisms that underlie these groupings, and will test a real-world intervention to improve regulation success. This knowledge will be critical for understanding the heterogeneity in depression and for developing real-world interventions to prevent or improve the course of depression, toward the goal of precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Numerous conditions that cause learning/memory impairments (e.g., Alzheimer’s, epilepsy, traumatic brain injury, post-traumatic stress disorder, schizophrenia, and stroke) affect the hippocampus, and the dentate gyrus specifically. Mossy cells, a commonly overlooked hippocampal cell type, regulate activity in the dentate gyrus and are particularly vulnerable to damage in many of these disorders. The proposed research will determine how mossy cells regulate the formation and retrieval of memories, offering new targets to treat memory impairments commonly observed in neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a progressive neurodegenerative disease whose pathologic hallmark is cytoplasmic mislocalization of the nuclear protein TDP-43 in motor neurons, where it is bound up in cytoplasmic stress granules. Both cytoplasmic toxicity and loss of nuclear function of TDP-43 contribute to neuronal death. The goal of this proposal is to determine the effects of reversing TDP-43 mislocalization, by sustainably knocking down Ataxin 2, a key stress granule component, and by enhancing nuclear import, both alone and in combination with Ataxin 2 knockdown.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: SCN3A-related neurodevelopmental disorder (SCN3A-NDD) is a recently identified condition caused by pathogenic variants in the gene SCN3A encoding the voltage-gated sodium channel subunit Nav1 .3; this syndrome is defined by treatment resistant epilepsy, severe to profound intellectual disability, and, unexpectedly, malformation of cortical development, yet how sodium channel function might regulate brain development and channel dysfunction lead to brain malformation is entirely unknown. The objective of this proposal is to investigate how variants in SCN3A lead to these complex neurological phenotypes including epilepsy and structural brain malformation. The work proposed here will link across levels of analysis from human genetics, to ion channel and neuronal dysfunction, to clinical phenotype, in order to inform therapeutic discovery or preventative measures for this devastating disorder which is currently without treatment or cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Disorders of the brain remain an enormous medical challenge and new platforms that serve as functional bridges between cell-assays and animal testing are needed to improve our understanding of the disease and to develop and translate therapeutic approaches towards human patient trials. In this proposal, our interdisciplinary team from three CTSA Program hubs (UNC, Duke, and U. of Florida) seek to advance discovery and translation of therapies for brain disorders by further developing the organotypic brain slice (OBSC) platform. Using our OBSC models of neurodegenerative disease, brain cancer, and stroke, we will develop new technological innovations to add disease-relevant capabilities to the platform, screen therapeutic agents to develop better treatment options, and enable immune-based approaches to target new aspects of disease, all with the goal of advancing accessibility of the novel OBSC model and improving the outcomes of patients suffering from brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because blood cancers are exquisitely sensitive to radiation, targeted radiation delivery via radioimmunotherapy (radionuclides stably linked to target-specific antibodies) has gained interest with a commensurate increase in radioimmunotherapy clinical trials. Although clinical efficacy has been observed in stand-alone radioimmunotherapy for cancers, or as part of conditioning regimens prior to allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, how the normal bone marrow niche differentially responds radioimmunotherapy compared to conventional approaches is not well-understood, limiting potential interventions to mitigate the negative effects from radiation to the marrow. This proposal will address current limitations and identify how to modulate specific bone marrow niche alterations for desired clinical goals by identifying how the hematopoietic stem cells, vascular endothelial cells and stromal cells in the bone marrow niche respond to radioimmunotherapy with an alpha- emitter (astatine-211), beta-emitter (yttrium-90), or X-ray radiation, as gauged by stem cell functional assays, architecture restructuring using microscopy, and differential gene expression from RNA sequence analysis.

PHR: Narrative The project will focus on developing a new software strategy enabling collaborative studies that apply diffusion MRI to investigate the human brain. The software will be easy to deploy and will automatize dMRI processing and quality check with a user-friendly dashboard. Upon the development of our software strategy, it will be easier for clinical centers to join decentralized studies, increasing the ability of such studies to identify subtle neurological changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Primary graft dysfunction (PGD) is a deadly complication following lung transplantation affecting over 50% of recipients. While PGD has been traditionally thought to be due to ischemia-reperfusion injury, we have discovered that transplant recipients have high incidence of pre-existing lung autoantibodies which react with the newly transplanted lung causing severe damage which presents as PGD. In the prior funding cycle, we identified novel pathways through which the pre-existing autoantibodies cause damage to the transplanted lung. In the next cycle, we will identify clinically actionable treatments to protect the transplant recipients against the damaging effects of these autoantibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The molecular composition of a cell’s surface dictates how cells communicate, interact with their environment, and is the physical platform for certain diagnostic and therapeutic modalities. Our discovery of cell surface glycoRNAs changes the view of what types of biomolecules can exist on the cell surface to regulate critical aspects of cell biology. This proposal aims to significantly advance our ability to study glycoRNAs through chemical tool development, elucidate the molecular context of cell surface glycoRNA, and expand our view on the scope of species that can produce glycoRNA conjugates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oncogenic gene fusions involving Nucleoporin 98 (NUP98) are recurrent in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and are associated with poor patient outcomes. NUP98 fusion oncoproteins localize within the nucleus in membrane-less organelles, or “puncta”, that are necessary for cell transformation and deregulated gene expression, and the studies proposed here will interrogate the composition of NUP98 FO-associated puncta and their potential for therapeutic targeting. By identifying which members of the NUP98 FO interactome are functionally important and determining if puncta disruption is necessary for therapeutic benefit, this research plan may identify new therapeutic approaches for high-risk, NUP98-rearranged AMLs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Extremely high rates (>50%) of primary graft dysfunction (PGD) due to ischemia reperfusion injury (IRI) are the predominant cause of impaired post-lung transplant outcomes resulting in both short-term mortality as well as chronic lung allograft rejection. In the prior funding cycle, we developed state-of-the-art research tools and complex murine models of sequential spleen and lung transplantation to unravel a fascinating multicellular signaling complex led by recipient classical monocytes primed in the spleen that was responsible for the pathogenesis of PGD. In the next funding cycle, we will use complementary genetic and pharmacological techniques to identify the mechanisms through which classical monocytes are activated after reaching the transplanted lung as well as those that result in the recruitment and priming of classical monocytes in the spleen while generating a molecular atlas of PGD to facilitate rapid clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Dopamine replacement therapy of Parkinson’s Disease is critical to manage movement symptoms, but frequently complicated by the development of treatment-related involuntary movements or impulsive behaviors. Understanding how dopamine replacement therapy produces its therapeutic and pathological effects through distinct groups of brain cells would make it possible to harness the therapeutic effects without the complications. This project will measure brain activity in a mouse model of Parkinson’s Disease, to better understand how dopamine replacement therapy improves movement, causes involuntary movements, or leads to impulsive behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will produce a host of novel data to understand behavioral economic demand for cannabis and tobacco among young adult dual users, which is critical to progress in preventing and treating dual use among a high-risk group. This study will produce the first prospective investigation of behavioral economic demand for cannabis and tobacco (cigarettes and/or e- cigarettes) over one year (Aim 1), the first evaluation of demand as an antecedent of dual tobacco and cannabis product use and characterization of the relative contributions of demand indices for each substance to behavioral health sequelae of use (Aim 2), and the first model testing whether demand for cannabis and tobacco mediates a link between social cognitive theory-based factors and cannabis and tobacco use (Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Sickle cell disease (SCD) is complex and requires multiple modes of action to optimally manage painful vaso-occlusive crisis (VOC) and associated poor quality of life. Several drugs are approved for the treatment of SCD, however, none retain all of the essential properties necessary for VOC management including anti-adhesion, anti-inflammation, anti-sickling, and antithrombosis. Vascular Vision Pharmaceuticals (VVP) specializes in the development of novel therapies for the treatment of sickle cell disease using first in class non- anticoagulant heparin (S-NACH) that retains all of these essential properties while removing dose limiting toxicity, particularly bleeding associated with this class of drugs; the multiple modes of action and S-NACH’s nanoformulation (VVP728) provide a highly desirable therapeutic for SCD management,

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative       The  proposed  Hispanic  Alliance  for  Clinical  and  Translational  Research  is  relevant  to  public  health  because  it  will  help  advance  our  fundamental  knowledge  of  ethnic- specific  factors  that  could  explain  the  disproportionate burden  of  certain  diseases,  and  the  limited  or  lack  of  effective  treatment  for  this  ethnic  subgroup,  which  is     increasingly represented in the US mainland population. The long- term goal of the Alliance is to transform clinical  and  translational  research  in  Hispanic  populations  in  the  Mainland  and  in  Puerto  Rico  by  promoting  inter-  disciplinary  collaboration  and  leverage  of  resources  to  address  diseases  affecting  Hispanic  communities.  The  project  is  relevant  to  the  NIH  mission  because  it  will  contribute  with  training  the  next  generation  of   scientists, develop research capacities, and will enhance the diversity of the scientific workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative T cell anergy is a critical mechanism of peripheral T cell tolerance, and defects in the generation or maintainence of anergy against self antigens leads to autoimmune disease. We have shown that expression of the transcription factor Runx1 is reduced in naturally anergic CD4 T cells in WT mice, which leads to the upregulation of the inhibitory adaptor molecule Dap2IP. The focus of this proposal is to uncover the mechanisms by which Dab2IP overexpression represses TCR stimulation leading to T cell non- responsiveness.

PHR: Narrative The mission of the Wyoming Sensory Biology COBRE (SBC) is to foster and conduct high-quality scientific research that advances the understanding of our sensory systems and disorders related to them. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic alterations in human cancer have been systematically studied over the past decade, but the impact of a majority of these changes on the proteome—the functional end of the genome—are poorly understood. In this project we will implement a large-scale automated data analysis platform that will integrate clinical, genomics and mass spectrometry-based proteomics data from the same samples/tumors, and bring to bear novel big-data algorithms and analysis methods to shed new light on the biology of cancer, the response and resistance to drug treatments and, importantly, help to identify new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The aim of this study is to elucidate how TAR-DNA binding protein 43 (TDP-43) misfolding and aggregation affects the function of oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for myelination in the central nervous system. Additionally, we will investigate whether oligodendrocytes can carry and spread pathogenic TDP-43 species to neighboring neurons, contributing to the progression of TDP-43 proteinopathies. By gaining insights into these mechanisms, our studies will enhance the understanding of TDP-43-related disorders and provide a foundation for future research and potential interventions to improve health outcomes and reduce the impact of neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Lay summary: Alzheimer's Disease, a serious brain disorder, needs better treatment methods. This project is about studying a special group of brain's immune cells that may become old and not work properly, which could make Alzheimer's worse. We aim to learn more about these cells and see if getting rid of them can help slow down Alzheimer's. We'll use a special kind of lab mouse to help with this. If this works, we could learn how Alzheimer's develops and potentially find new ways to treat it by focusing on these old cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is a common and often deadly condition of organ dysfunction due to infection that is responsible for 1.7 million hospitalizations and an estimated 260,000 deaths annually in the United States; survivors of sepsis are often left debilitated due to muscle atrophy, which hinders independence and reduces quality of life. Unfortunately, other than physical rehabilitation, there are no treatments currently available for post-sepsis muscle atrophy because we do not understand how sepsis causes muscle atrophy. This project will study how the gut microbiome, the bacteria that live in the human intestinal tract, contributes to muscle atrophy during sepsis, with a goal of identifying new targets for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study was one of the first to demonstrate that cerebral amyloid deposition precedes cognitive decline by as much as 10-15 years. There appears to be great variability in the time from becoming amyloid positive until cognitive decline. Longitudinal studies, such as this one, which has been going on for 15 years, provide a unique opportunity to characterize the progression to Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses an important research priority in the field of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, about a novel epigenetic mechanism for which there is currently little data in both blood and brain and across race, to link vascular risk factors such as diabetes to dementia, cognitive decline, and postmortem brain pathology in older White and Black persons. Because vascular risk factors are common and modifiable with treatments and lifestyle approaches, this project is likely to have a high and sustained impact on improving public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This proposal aims to generate a histologically-validated map of twelve hippocampal subregions for neuroimaging, a critical step towards determining Alzheimer’s disease pathogenesis and developing novel therapeutic interventions to halt Alzheimer’s disease progression. This project will use a cell based approach from histology to make a cellularly-validated atlas in FreeSurfer that will be applied to other existing in vivo datasets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical, pathological and epidemiological evidence clearly show overlap between cardiovascular and Alzheimer’s diseases caused by a critical genetic link: the apolipoprotein E gene. We will develop novel photon counting cardiac CT imaging and use it in combination with brain MR imaging and behavior assessments to study the impact of APOE genotype in mouse models and to provide data on phenotypic differences in these mice when exposed to a high fat/high sugar diet and the role of exercise in protecting against Alzheimer’s and cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Patient-centered care should include medical treatment to achieve goals of care, but not medicines that are either likely to be harmful or unhelpful. Deprescribing is the process of reducing or stopping the use of inappropriate medications or medications unlikely to be beneficial supervised by a health-care professional. We will develop and test a novel tool and methods to generate adequate safety evidence to support thoughtful and effective deprescribing using a new data-based approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Cognitive dysfunction associated with aging and Alzheimer's disease is a significant and growing public health problem. The proposed research will determine the utility of electrical stimulation of the vagus nerve for remediating neurobiological and cognitive impairments in aging, as well as Alzheimer's disease-like neuropathology. This work will be significant because it will provide the foundation for using vagus nerve stimulation as a therapy for treating age-related cognitive impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Greenness, or the lack of greenness, has the potential to touch every life. Therefore, longitudinal research on greenness has the potential for tremendous public health impact, particularly given the accumulating evidence on the relationship of greenness to chronic diseases. Research on neighborhood greenness and health suggests that benefits can be obtained even with relatively small increases in greenness. Findings that longitudinal greenness exposure protects against cognitive decline, vascular outcomes and/or Alzheimer’s disease, would further support the role of increased greenness in promoting successful aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While APOE4 is identified as the strongest genetic risk factor for developing sporadic Alzheimer's disease (AD), the molecular mechanisms underlying the pathogenic nature of APOE4 are not fully elucidated. Motivated by our novel findings, we will characterize in this renewal application, the regulation of microglial function by the APOE-synj1-PIP2 signaling pathway during AD development with in vivo studies of humanized APOE mouse models, ex vivo microglial culture and 3-D co-culture system of human iPSC-derived brain cells, as well as validation studies of human brain samples. The scRNA-seq data from mouse brains and RNA-seq data from human iPSC-derived brain cells will be integrated to perform high resolution multiscale network modeling and to elucidate novel pathways and molecular signatures underlying APOE4-induced neuroinflammation in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposed research aims to examine the effect of CMS' telemedicine policy on health care utilization among community-dwelling older adults with ADRD, and its variations by race/ethnicity. This proposed research is highly relevant to public health because the findings from this study will provide valuable and timely information on how this public policy affects the older population with ADRD, and provide implications on reducing racial disparities in health among this already vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative: Aging, the strongest risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease, causes detrimental changes in various cell populations in the brain, yet we have little understanding of the mechanisms tying aging to Alzheimer’s-related brain changes. This proposal investigates how exposure to youth-associated blood-borne proteins act through the innate immune cells of the brain to revitalize cognition using several levels of analysis, including gene expression, cellular, and behavioral assessments. Insights gained from pursuing this concept will inform therapies at the intersection between aging and Alzheimer’s disease as well as those directed towards neuroimmune interactions.

PHR: Project Narrative Lewy body dementia is the second most common form of dementia in the elderly, with no effective means of diagnosis, prevention, or disease-modifying therapy. The proposed research will use an innovative approach and cutting-edge technologies to discover and study disease mechanisms and molecular targets for development of biomarkers and therapeutics to treat this debilitating dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is one of the most persistent and devastating dementias because it eventually leads to a complete loss of memory and the ability to function independently. Patients with AD have abnormal levels of an important neurotransmitter regulatory molecule called BH4, and our previous studies have shown that giving BH4 to psychiatric patients with abnormal BH4 levels helps restore their memory deficits. In this study, we will test if 1) AD patients also have memory deficits due to abnormal levels of BH4 produced by a BH4 gene, and 2) if we can restore this gene pathway and treat cognitive impairment in mouse models of BH4 loss and AD, which may lead to new treatment of memory loss in AD, targeted to patients with BH4 abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia. Genetic and pathology studies have suggested that certain brain cells, known as microglia, slow down disease progression, but to do so they need a molecule called TREM2. We propose experiments to understand how TREM2 activates microglia, why TREM2 is not functional in AD, and whether an antibody that actvates TREM2 can be used in the therapy of AD in a mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Periodontal disease has been associated with increased risk of dementia and Alzheimer’s disease although no causitive relationship has been established. Our preliminary data demonstrated the presence of Aβ peptide in saliva in an Alzheimer’s disease transgenic mouse model. This correlated with a unique profile of oral bacteria in diseased mice as well as increased numbers of cavities and enamel thinning in males. Based upon our rodent findings, it appears that Alzheimer’s disease changes are present in the oral cavity. Monitoring these changes may be useful correlates of disease progression. Alternatively, a novel mouth-brain interaction may be involved in disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Alzheimer’s-related disease frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) are two fatal and incurable neurodegenerative diseases linked by a shared genetic cause – a heterozygous hexanucleotide (GGGGCC) repeat expansion in a single allele of the C9orf72 gene. The goal of this work is to use patient induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) and CRISPR gene editing to reveal novel therapeutic gene editing approaches. The gene editing strategies we are developing are applicable to other repeat expansion and single gene disorders, potentially including genetic cases of Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative The proposed study is highly relevant to public health because advanced mathematical and statistical methods will allow for more in-depth analysis of high-resolution fMRI data, in particular, data used in the characterization of brain function, which offers significant potential for more effective diagnosis and treatment of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). This study will investigate memory activation in the medial temporal lobes with high-resolution imaging at 7 Tesla with multivariate analysis to identify brain dysfunction in prodromal AD. The methods developed from the findings acquired in this study will have a far-reaching influence on MRI/fMRI research in neurodegenerative diseases by improving fMRI data quality, facilitating automated and instantaneous brain segmentation, and more accurately identifying individuals at risk for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Missense mutations in neural precursor cell expressed developmentally down-regulated gene 4-like (Nedd4L) are associated with periventricular nodular heterotopia (PNH), a rare neurological disorder caused by impaired cortical neuron migration. Our recent work suggests that Nedd4L functions to promote cofilin phosphorylation and subsequent actin polymerization, both of which are critical to neuronal migration. We will test the hypothesis that Nedd4L, which is an E3 ubiquitin ligase, ubiquitinates certain phosphatases to promote cofilin phosphorylation, and PNH-associated missense mutations on Nedd4L impair this process and neuronal migration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will characterize key cellular and molecular events that participate in the development of Alzheimer’s disease and identify therapeutic pathways to reverse these pathological events. We discovered that synapses containing elevated amounts of PSD-95 are protected against the detrimental effects of amyloid- beta, a peptide thought to cause Alzheimer’s disease. We will study PSD-95 in several brain regions as it might explain cell vulnerability and develop a pharmacological approach to increase synaptic PSD-95, which has the potential to open a new therapeutic avenue against Alzheimer’s.

PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Knowledge of the contextual and individual factors in countries like Mexico that influence older adults' risk for dementia as well as their access and use of care resources are established gaps in population aging research. This project will investigate the life course pathways that influence dementia risk, the availability of care resources, and how care resources are used by older adults in a country with the likely care burden of dementia for families and institutions. Our findings will help determine the resource needs in countries like Mexico.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular senescence is a hallmark of age-related tissue dysfunction and is enhanced in the brain during Alzheimer's disease (AD), but very little is known about the causes or consequences of senescent-like states in post-mitotic cells, especially neurons. This project seeks to understand neuronal senescence during aging and AD using a neuronal culture system that preserves age-related cellular features lacking in other in vitro models. By comparing gene expression, metabolism, and senescence-associated secreted factors in neurons and fibroblasts from the same individuals, this work will reveal cellular processes that differentiate healthy aging from AD and those that specifically impact neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE Recent data support that changes in the functional properties of glutamate and GABA neurotransmission in the hippocampus and frontal cortex in the CNS contribute to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and age-related declines in cognition and memory. A further understanding of the balance between glutamate levels and glutamate and GABA neurotransmission in vivo are needed from the frontal cortex and hippocampus in AD models and in normal aging. These studies will aid in the identification of targets and consistent, comparable non-invasive spectroscopic monitoring techniques for existing FDA approved drugs as well as possibly new targets for drugs to treat AD to address the growing population with dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The primary objectives of this project are to assess the effects of a cash transfer program on the slowing of biological aging and reduction of dementia risk in younger and older individuals. Additionally, we aim to quantify associations between biological aging and cognitive function in this population. Results of this research could have substantial impact for public health by revealing causal, long-term consequences of economic interventions for health and cognitive aging. Moreover, it will generate new knowledge about biological aging and Alzheimer’s Disease risk in low resource settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is one of the most important public health challenges of our time, with women disproportionately impacted. We will uniquely examine whether sex differences in immune pathophysiology, in part, underlies the sex-dependent impact of cardiometabolic dysfunction on AD risk in midlife. Understanding this shared etiology could provide insights into development of sex-dependent early interventions to prevent AD or attenuate disease burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis, or dysregulated host response to infection, is one of the most common causes of hospitalization in the U.S. with a high mortality rate. DHCR7, an enzyme involved in cholesterol synthesis, was associated with mortality in human sepsis, and fish treated with a DHCR7 inhibitor were protected from toxicity in a zebrafish model that recapitulates features of human sepsis. This proposal will clarify the mechanisms by which inhibition of this enzyme exerts a protective effect, with implications for the development of human sepsis therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative In a recent large-scale of genome-wide analysis study, a rare coding variant was identified in Abelson interactor family member 3 (ABI3) gene and this variant is associated with an increased risk of late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The overarching goal of this application is to understand the role of ABI3 in microglia and the mechanisms by which ABI3 affects AD. This may lead to identifying the key regulators of the mechanism and subsequent identification of the new therapeutic targets in AD.

PHR: Most human disease, especially cancer, is based in abnormalities of tissues. The University of Virginia will support the Cooperative Human Tissue Network by recruiting patients to donate samples and then by giving high quality human tissue specimens and biofluids (blood, urine, etc.) to scientists to help them understand the causes of disease, to create new diagnostic tests for disease and to create new therapies for disease, with an emphasis on cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To be able to optimally use neurodegenerative biomarkers in clinical practice and as surrogate endpoints to clinical trials, several unanswered questions in the field must be addressed. We will evaluate different proposed neurodegenerative biomarkers using a population-based community sample of Mayo Clinic Study of Aging, a biracial cohort from Mayo Clinic Jacksonville and ADNI in order to will develop a deeper understanding of how to utilize these neurodegenerative markers for clinical care of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementias (ADRD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will complement ongoing large-scale Alzheimer disease (AD) genomic studies in individuals of diverse ancestry including non-Hispanic whites, African Americans, and Hispanics from Puerto Rico and Peru. Since DNA variants identified in these studies may not provide information on the underlying biological mechanisms, we propose to 1) use high throughput RNA sequencing, single cell RNA sequencing, and genome-wide methylation microarrays to define gene expression and DNA methylation differences between AD and control; 2) characterize how DNA variants modulate those expression and methylation changes and 3) use statistical methods to extend these findings into large existing genomic datasets. Performing this study in diverse populations including African American and Hispanic populations will broaden the spectrum of AD genomics to individuals that are underrepresented in most existing research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drugs to prevent or treat Alzheimer´s disease (AD) are desperately needed, and this project proposes an innovative reverse translational approach to repurpose drugs for AD, by bringing together researchers from the fields of molecular epidemiology and basic science in a cross-disciplinary effort. We will analyze drugs with indications for other age-related conditions for their preventive effect on AD, using a series of causal inference methods on epidemiological data, followed by drug screening in human cultured cells and C. elegans, as well as validation in mouse models of aging and AD pathology. Our approach is a cost-effective strategy to discover new drugs for AD prevention, and since we are investigating already approved substances, they may arrive at the bedside more quickly, due to a reduced need for clinical testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Protease-activated receptor-4 (PAR4) is part of a unique family of GPCRs activated by cleavage of the amino terminus by thrombin and generation of a tethered ligand. PAR4 is thought to play important roles in generation of excess thrombin and thrombosis, but these roles are unconfirmed due to the lack of appropriate tools and bioavailable antagonists. We will optimize SAR around PAR4 to explore the role of PAR4 activation in cerebrovascular damage during Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this study is to examine the association of financial exploitation in old age with markers of Alzheimer’s Disease. We will investigate whether financial exploitation due to poor financial decision making is associated with cognitive decline, change in economic preferences, decline in brain functional connections, and Alzheimer’s Disease genetic risk. Findings will inform early detection and intervention programs focused on cognitive health and wellbeing in old age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The renewal application will test our hypothesis that amyloid-β deposition in human Alzheimer's disease (AD) brain, which activates brain macrophage “microglia,” and enhances seeding of tau aggregates via phagocytosis of tau-containing neuronal processes and secretion of extracellular vesicles. This will be conducted by 1) characterization of the tau seeding activity of extracellular vesicles isolated from AD brains, 2) microglia-specific deletion of microglia activator or glia specific deletion of extracellular vesicle producing enzyme in animal models and 3) characterization of extracellular vesicles isolated from activated pluripotent stem cell-derived microglia-like cells. This study is critically relevant to understand the progression of neurodegenerative diseases and will elucidate potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a complex, heterogeneous disorder, partly influenced by genetics. Identifying new genes for AD is very important as it can lead to a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying AD and can identify novel therapeutic targets. We propose here analytical tools that leverage diverse omics datasets including genomics, transcriptomics and epigenomics in order to improve gene discovery. We will apply these methods to some of the largest genetic datasets in AD to identify new risk genes for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal will explore the idea that a modified version of the Ab peptide might be used therapeutically to block aggregation of the wild-type peptide. Our study endeavors to identify the biophysical mechanism of inhibition and to test a gene therapy vector for delivery of variant Ab in mouse models. We intend this work to serve as a framework for exploring peptide self-inhibition in Alzheimer's disease and other disease-associated aggregation disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal evaluates a new approach for AD therapeutics; we would screen small molecules and peptidomimetics for their ability to mimic Humanin (HN) activity for normalizing brain phospho-Akt (p-Akt) levels, with the goal of identifying potential candidates for preclinical development with enhanced potency, drug-like properties, oral brain permeability and efficacy in an Alzheimer's disease (AD) model. Such a new therapeutic class for AD could be used alone or in combination with currently approved drugs to protect neurons from NMDA- and Aβ-related toxicity. An efficacious candidate may have broader therapeutic applications in traumatic brain injury (TBI), stroke, Aβ-induced cerebrovascular dementia, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), but specifically could provide a new therapeutic approach for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MAYO CLINIC JACKSONVILLE Aging-related disturbances in cerebral blood supply and blood-brain barrier (BBB) integrity leads to neuronal damage and white matter lesions, which often results in cognitive decline known as vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID). APOE4 significantly exacerbates cerebrovascular pathology and the cognitive performance of the elderly. Since p16INK4a triggers cellular senescence during aging, we will comprehensively examine how endothelial cell senescence induced by p16INK4a contributes to the pathogenesis of VCID and how APOE4 modulates the mechanisms using mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Six million Americans live with Alzheimer’s disease or related dementias and there are no disease modifying drugs. The proposed research will potentially lead to new treatment options based on lysosomal degradation activators, which would address this significant public health need. Defining the mechanism by which our lysosomal degradation activators function to normalize familial Alzheimer’s disease phenotypes in cellular and organoid models is aligned with NIH’s mission to develop fundamental knowledge of human disease that can be translated into benefits for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Microglia play both protective and pathogenic roles in neurodegenerative disease but mechanisms that specify or restrict these opposing activities remain poorly understood. In this proposal, we will test the hypothesis that defects in homeostatic functions of LXRs and SREBPs are broadly linked to pathological microglia phenotypes and investigate the potential of synthetic mimetics of endogenous LXR ligands to exert protective effects without causing side effects associated with conventional LXR agonists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the high performance of automated segmentation, substantial proofreading is required to correct reconstruction errors within large-scale connectomic datasets. To enable auto- corrections at scale in existing and emerging large datasets, we propose to develop “Connects- Proof, a scalable automated proofreading framework for connectomics”, that leverages, integrates, and extends software tools initially developed for the cubic millimeter MICrONS dataset: NEURD (short for NEURal Decomposition), an automated error detection and correction framework, and NeuVue, a scalable manual proofreading platform. Enabled by automated proofreading, accurate large-scale connectomes can provide unprecedented insights to understand brain function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is an often-deadly disease without universal treatment options, however new discoveries can lead to new cancer treatments to the benefit of all. Progress is dependent on good scientific ideas supported by high- quality novel resources so that investigators can ask and answer critical research questions. The Cooperative Human Tissue Network Midwestern Division (CHTN MWD) will respond to the cancer researchers’ ever-changing challenges by supporting them with custom prepared high quality human tissues and biofluids enriched by innovative clinical data sets.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: Research Narrative The current study aims to characterize the emotional input that three samples of typically developing infants receive over the first year and a half of life—a critical time period for learning to identify and respond to emotion information. By documenting infants’ natural exposure to emotion information, we can build a better understanding of how infants develop emotion categories, how they learn to use emotion information to guide action and build expectations about social interactions, and how specific experiences or individual differences shape development in these domains.

PHR: Project Narrative The human intestinal flora is a complex environment where bacterial and fungal organisms co-exist in the gut. While the microbiome can profoundly influence host physiology, specific fungal-bacterial transkingdom interactions remain poorly characterized. The proposed research will analyze interactions between these organisms and their specific influence on immunity and mycobiota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Almost 50% of American adults over 30 years old have periodontitis, which represents around 65 million people, 9% of them have severe periodontitis, and the prevalence increases gradually with age. Current treatments for periodontitis, including the standard scaling and root planing combined with systemic or local administration of antibiotics or antiresorptive bisphosphonate, do not effectively address safety concerns or adequately prevent periodontal bone loss. Instead of relying on exogenous cells, proteins, or antibiotics, our study develops an innovative biomaterials-based strategy with strong anti-inflammatory, anti-bacterial, and bone-forming abilities to prevent periodontitis-induced bone loss and improve periodontal bone regeneration by enhancing our body’s innate healing capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) spectrum disorders represent one of the most common causes of dementia in younger individuals but can be challenging to diagnose, resulting in high social and economic burden. FTD often causes changes to a patient’s speech, which makes speech an ideal target for a digital tool to aid the diagnosis of FTD. In this proposal, we outline a project to develop a digital technology that will use speech recordings from a self-administered speech exam and provide predictions for abnormal speech characteristics and FTD subtype using machine learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Non-enzymatic glycation (NEG) of bone, a modification of matrix by sugars, is associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and linked to bone fragility fractures. This project will establish Carboxymethyl-lysine (CML), a product of NEG, as a new biomarker of T2D fracture and determine how the oxidation and glycation processes, associated with diabetes under obese and non-obese conditions, impact accumulation of CML and other AGEs and enhance bone fragility. The results will open new strategies to diagnose, treat and mitigate T2D and fragility fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite recent evidence of the role of grit (i.e., persistence of effort, perseverance) in cognitive resilience in aging, causal evidence is nonexistent. By combining brain imaging with transcranial magnetic stimulation, this project will determine if modulation of neural circuits via stimulation leads to improved grit and memory in healthy aging and preclinical Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Ketone supplements and ketogenic diets have the potential to bypass deficits in brain glucose metabolism that occur in Alzheimer’s disease. This proposal will develop and validate noninvasive imaging biomarkers of glucose and ketone metabolism using mouse models that recapitulate human AD. Results from this work will provide an improved mechanistic understanding of the role of lipids and ketone metabolism in AD and lead to clinically translatable biomarkers for better diagnosis and management of deficits in brain metabolism that occur in patients with AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly all cases of COVID-19-associated nephropathy (COVAN) occur in persons with high-risk apolipoprotein L1 (APOL1) genotype, resulting in significant morbidity and mortality and a disproportionate burden of kidney disease on persons of West African descent. This study aims to identify host factors that regulate APOL1 and immune-glomerular interactions in COVAN, providing novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets. Improved understanding of the host factors that effect COVAN penetrance and development of targeted therapeutics are critical to mitigating the racial disparities caused by COVAN in COVID-19 related health outcomes and other forms of APOL1 nephropathy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Germ cell development requires properly generated piRNAs to maintain germline DNA integrity, the failure of which will impair male fertility. This project aims to unveil how the piRNA processing machinery is constructed in male germ cells, thus critically informing the mechanistic causes of male infertility for targeted therapies. Findings may also lead to a novel strategy for developing non-hormonal male contraceptives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia in older adults, but the contribution of the peripheral immune cells in AD pathology is yet to be fully elucidated. This is partly due to the lack of an effective and reliable model to capture the complex interactions between the various human cellular components of the brain and the peripheral immune cells. Drawing upon our considerable experience in AD biology, 3D modeling of AD in a dish, microfluidic systems, cellular engineering, and bioinformatics, we propose to study the pathogenic roles of CD8+ T cells in AD using our human cellular models and AD-like transgenic mouse models to gain a deeper understanding of CD8+ T cells biology and their disease-modifying role in AD.
