IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Because hospitalized patients with cancer face unacceptable morbidity and mortality from sepsis (a life- threatening dysregulated response to infection), there is urgent need for interventions to identify oncologic sepsis early and enable timelier appropriate treatments. However, incumbent electronic health record-based sepsis prediction tools – linked to improved mortality in other populations – have failed to deliver on their promise in oncology because of design and implementation limitations. This project aims to advance the simultaneous and iterative development of a machine learning tool to predict oncologic sepsis alongside the user-centered design of implementation strategies to improve sepsis care and outcomes for hospitalized patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Poor science achievement in childhood negatively impacts adult health, due to poor scientific literacy and reasoning. LEARN Science – Library Efforts to Advance Reading and Nutrition Science – is an informal life science and reading program through a nutrition science lens to improve science knowledge and science identity among children in kindergarten through second grade (K-2) in Mississippi using public libraries. Informal science education through a nutrition science lens leverages an opportunity for not only improved science achievement, but also for improved health of children – now and in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic dysregulation has been implicated in dementia; however, our understanding of metabolic pathways underlying cognitive health is still inadequate. This application aims to systematically investigate brain metabolomic profiles associated with cognitive decline and dementia, by examining approximately 1,800 metabolites in postmortem brain tissue, leveraging data and biospecimens from 1,200 deceased participants in two community-based aging cohorts. Findings from this research may provide critical evidence to fill in the current knowledge gap and to inform the development of novel interventions for the prevention and treatment of dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety disorder prevalence climbs during young adulthood, a time when neural circuits involved in emotion regulation undergo significant maturation. This innovative project will identify 1) the ability of young adults with anxiety to self-modulate brain function in a region specific to healthy emotion regulation using real-time functional magnetic resonance imaging neurofeedback and 2) the potential impact of neuromodulation on improved emotion regulation ability and anxiety reduction. Findings from this project will lay the groundwork to test if psychotherapy outcomes can be enhanced using neurofeedback to stop anxiety early.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Human Epidermal growth factor Receptor-2 (HER2) is a clinically validated target that is upregulated in 25% of invasive breast cancers and associated with poor disease prognosis. This project will characterize small molecules predicted by computer modeling to inhibit HER2 with a novel mechanism and verified to be selective and effective in inhibiting HER2+ cell lines. The expected findings will meet NIH's mission to reduce illness by validating this class of molecules for breast cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a highly prevalent disorder for which there are no effective therapies. This application identifies a new genetic locus that confers increased risk for AD and is linked to the innate immune response observed in the disease. This application proposes to develop and characterize new mouse models of AD possessing genetic variants of the gene PLCG2 and determine how the variants affects disease pathogenesis to inform the therapeutic targeting of this enzyme.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Tauopathies consist of a group of neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and currently no therapeutic treatments exist for tauopathies. Post-translational modifications (PTMs) of tau are thought to play important mechanistic roles and could serve as a target strategy. This study will test how the citrullination pathway of tau impacts tau biology and neuropathology in vitro and in vivo, which may provide a new foundation for citrullination during tauopathies and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's Disorder (AD) is one of the most pressing public health issues as the world's population continues to age, but there is no known effective prevention or cure exists. The Alzheimer's Disease Sequencing Project (ADSP) has sequenced a large number (n>17,000) of AD patients and normal healthy elderly controls. Leveraging the rich resources from ADSP, we propose to comprehensively detect genomic copy number variations (CNVs), find CNV and AD association for different ethnicities, and further facilitate the identification of genetic therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Traffic-related air pollution has been associated with an increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease (AD); however, the vehicular emissions components responsible for this effect, and the mechanism(s) by which air pollution promotes AD remain largely unknown. To answer these questions, we will expose rats expressing human AD susceptibility genes in real-time to air pollution from a major freeway and compare the effects of gases vs. particulate matter from light vs. heavy duty vehicles on their lungs and brains, and determine whether lung inflammation leads to changes in the brain. These studies are needed to corroborate human studies linking traffic- related air pollution exposure to increased risk for AD, and to inform regulatory and health interventions to reduce AD risk for individuals living, working, or attending school near busy roadways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative A central question in aging and Alzheimer's disease (AD) is when (and if so, how) neural substrates underlying decision-making are altered and whether impairment in decision-making can be attenuated or halted. This effort seeks to uncover the role of aging, sex and AD-associated pathology on economic decision-making in mice. To uncover whether and how Aβ-dependent mechanisms induce changes in circuits underlying various forms of decision-making, we will use mouse models of AD combined with a unique behavioral platform designed to resolve decision-making complexities, whole-brain imaging and three parallel interventions (genetic, pharmacologic and optogenetic).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As the burden of Alzheimer’s disease in the United States and worldwide is high, there is a critical need to develop novel PET ligands to image illness-related biological processes in the brain. This work will develop key imaging tools designed to advance the scientific understanding of GluA2-specific AMPA receptor in the ionotropic glutamate system and facilitate the discovery of neurotherapeutics for Alzheimer’s disease patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Recent evidence suggests that breakdown of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is an important process in the pathogeneisis of Alzheimer's disease and related dementia (ADRD). However, the relationship between BBB damage and other pathogenic events in ADRD are not clear. This project will use cutting-edge BBB imaging techniques, assays, and animal models to systematically investigate BBB dysfunction in humans and animal models in both cross-sectional and longitudinal settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although great progress in recent years has been made in defining key innate immune receptors involved in Alzheimer’s disease, our knowledge of the specific intracellular signaling molecules that coordinate immune responses in Alzheimer’s disease remains poorly defined. In our preliminary studies, we have identified previously undescribed roles for the innate immune signaling adaptor CARD9 in an amyloid beta-mediated mouse model of Alzheimer’s disease. For this project, we will further define roles for CARD9 and the CARD9- associated kinase SYK in the innate immune response to amyloid beta and we will also evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of using SYK/CARD9-activating agents to limit Alzheimer’s-related disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Many lipid mediators generated from the metabolism of long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids have potent activities in regulating inflammation. We intend to test an approach to preserve the anti-inflammatory actions of epoxy fatty acids by inhibiting their degrading enzyme, soluble epoxide hydrolase (sEH). We hypothesize a sEH-regulated brain-liver axis model and will determine if sEH dysfunction in microglia and liver contributes to Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is clinically important by focusing on memory circuits that are differentially affected in Alzheimer disease. By interrogating their changes at multiple levels, from molecular to in vivo function, the results of this work will provide a more sophisticated understanding of disease pathophysiology and breakdown of information flow in this region. This will enable novel strategies to improve memory in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial permeability transition is a key event in the induction of cell death during the progression of neurodegenerative disease. This project will determine the single-particle cryo-EM structure of ATP synthase c-subunit leak channel that houses the pore of the mitochondrial permeability transition. The successful completion of the proposed project will result in novel therapies and preventative strategies for Alzheimer's disease by targeting the ATP synthase leak channel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Numerous studies support the association between glymphatic clearance and Alzheimer’s disease (AD), which is a slowly progressive, irreversible neurodegenerative disease with a long preclinical phase; aging is the major prevalence factor of AD. The project aims to develop an advanced non- invasive, non-contrast MRI biomarker to identify egress pathways and quantitative intrinsic cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) outflow metrics in mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and AD patients, compared with age-, sex-matched healthy subjects. We will also investigate changes in egress pathways of intrinsic CSF outflow in healthy, MCI, and AD subjects with different physical activity levels using actigraphy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The precise aspects of dysglycemia and glucose homeostasis that drive the risk of Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease related dementias are unknown, hampering development of successful prevention strategies. The proposed research will leverage wearable technology to investigate the association of glucose homeostasis, from continuous glucose monitors, with incident neurocognitive indicators of Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease related dementias in the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis. This study will suggest new mechanisms of Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease related dementia development, identify new primary and secondary prevention targets, and have the potential to change clinical care

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Microbial infection has been recently proposed as a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD). In this project we will evaluate whether peripheral infection mediated by sepsis and brain infection induced by meningitis represent a causal component of AD. This hypothesis will be explored using established models of infection and AD, and a battery of established and novel biochemical, immunohistochemical and imaging assays.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it develops a new biomarker to predict early stages of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) using machine learning technology applied to cutting-edge dry-electrode ambulatory electroencephalography data. Prediction will rely on the development and validation of a state-of- the-art system that combines epileptogenic activity and functional brain networks. Once such a biomarker has been developed, this will provide the basis for a noninvasive, inexpensive, and portable AD screening tool that can be easily deployed in-home or in residential communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease progression has been linked to changes in overall bulk fluid flow into and out of the brain. At the cellular level, the fluid flow that cells feel is called interstitial fluid flow, and it's role in Alzheimer's is, as yet, unstudied. Here we will measure, manipulate, and model interstitial fluid flow as it relates to increases in Alzheimer's pathology and alleviation of associated symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies proposed here aim to investigate the mechanisms of how immunoproteasome deficiency in activated glial cells exacerbates amyloid and tau pathology and spread in Alzheimer’s disease in vivo and in vitro. Employing single-nucleus RNA-sequencing (snRNAseq) and quantitative proteomics, we aim to elucidate the role of immunoproteasome deficiency in differential gene expression, proteome, and pathways in AD models and the aging brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Understanding the aggregation of the β-amyloid peptide to form toxic oligomers is fundamental to understanding the molecular basis of Alzheimer’s disease. This project seeks to understand the structures and biological impacts of these elusive oligomers, through the design, synthesis, and study of synthetic peptides that are based on the β-amyloid peptide and form well-defined oligomers that can be studied in exquisite detail. These studies will advance the field of Alzheimer’s disease research by providing a molecular-level understanding of key species in neurodegeneration and identifying molecular targets for developing diagnostics and therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public health relevance. Late onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD) is a debilitating neurological disorder affecting the elderly, for which no cure or disease modifying therapy is available yet. We have recently described that microglia, the cell type implicated in LOAD susceptibility by genetic studies, in the human aged brain exists in a variety of functional states and we found one of these microglia phenotypes, named Cluster 7, to be downregulated in AD. Thus, the overarching goal of this proposal is to understand the means through which this microglia subset is involved in healthy aging and AD pathogenesis in humans, in order to provide us with novel microglia centered targets for disease monitoring and potential therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Narrative: Alzheimer’s disease shows distinct progressive histological and behavioral hallmarks but its cell- type basis is not clear. Recent human postmortem studies begin to provide compelling rationale that constituent cell types bear a non-uniform risk profile, but the underlying cell specific progression of vulnerabilities remain unknown. Through cross-disciplinary systems biology approaches we will identify the vulnerable subclass of cells in AD, establish cell-type specific AD signatures and further investigate biological relationship between healthy aging and AD pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: The purpose of this project is to enhance our knowledge on the relationship between metabolically abnormal versus normal overweight or obesity with normal cognition and i) neurodegeneration as reflected by brain atrophy on MR imaging ii) neuroinflammation quantified by a new type of diffusion MR imaging called diffusion basis spectrum imaging and iii) AD pathology characterized by amyloid and tau PET imaging. The proposal will generate a new midlife cohort with classifications of metabolically abnormal overweight or obesity with amyloid, tau, neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration imaging markers. Investigating this relationship will establish key understanding of how obesity can increase risk for Alzheimer’s disease and consequently inform future prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease related disorders (ADRDs) are involved not only the accumulation of amyloid ß and tau but also alpha-synuclein (α-syn). We recently developed a novel peptide for delivery short oligonucleotides across the blood-brain barrier to reduce the expression of proteins such as α-syn. In this proposal we will utilize our expertise in delivering an siRNA against α-syn to the brain to examine the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of reducing α-syn to determine in models of Dementia with Lewy bodies if this is a viable therapeutic option to move forward for clinical trials.

IC_NAME: Center for Global Health
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research project is designed to improve the health and survival of children, adolescent, and adults living with HIV who suffer most from the world’s leading infectious causes of death: tuberculosis (TB) and HIV. Our team is uniquely positioned to develop, implement, and evaluate evidence-based, innovative approaches to prevent, find, and cure HIV-associated TB in five CDC target priority countries. Our research will develop innovative new strategies to improve our ability to FIND and PREVENT TB, while determining the most cost- effective prevention strategy and promoting best practices to SUSTAIN the impact of our work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 2 diabetes confers a greater excess risk of cardiovascular disease in women than in men. We propose to use The Look AHEAD (Action for Health In Diabetes) Study to examine the association between endogenous sex hormones (testosterone, estradiol and sex hormone binding globulin) and cardiovascular disease risk factors, over 8 years, by sex, and in response to the intensive lifestyle intervention among 3000 study participants with type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WHITE RIVER JUNCTION VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The fungal pathogen Candida albicans is a leading cause of hospital-associated bloodstream infections, and is directly responsible for increased mortality, length of stay, and healthcare costs in our veteran patient population. Current antifungal therapy remains suboptimal, and there are only three major classes of antifungal drugs available. Furthermore, resistance to current antifungal therapies is developing, and biofilm-related infections are particularly resistant to standard antifungal drugs. Secretion of proteins is an important mediator of filamentation, biofilm formation, and virulence in C. albicans. In this project, we will investigate the role of the endocytic component of secretion, focusing on genes involved in several key sequential steps in this process, and define their roles in filamentation, biofilm formation, and virulence. This project expands upon our long- standing studies of secretion in C. albicans, but focuses on pathways that we have not previously studied and are likely of great importance to understand how C. albicans causes infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed training initiative is highly relevant to public health as it defines a program to cultivate a diverse pool of research leaders who will be able to collaboratively and thoughtfully address a diverse set of public health issues and challenges. The research itself covers a wide range of bioengineering technologies; the scholars will learn the relationship between fundamental and applied research and how to efficiently translate ideas to public good. Most importantly, they will learn to listen and ask open-ended questions that better inform their research and translation of research to clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current antiretroviral therapies cannot target HIV reservoirs in the central nervous system and opioids further increase the efflux of drugs from the central compartment. We have developed an ionic liquid-based drug delivery system that vastly increases the amount of drug that can be delivered to the brain and targets microglia with high selectivity. This proposal will generate new ionic liquid formulations with tunable affinity for different cell types and will establish their safety and efficacy in complementary in vitro and in vivo models.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Suicide is a major health crisis within our Veteran population. In suicide victims, the blood-brain barrier may be compromised, and understanding the biological mechanisms linking stress, the blood-brain barrier, and suicidal behavior is critical to developing diagnostic tools and preventative treatments. This study will assess the blood-brain barrier in suicide victims at the molecular and neuroanatomical levels.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Improving access to acute stroke care for rural populations is critical to addressing disparities in stroke morbidity and mortality. Regional systems of emergency medical and hospital providers are essential to ensuring timely access to stroke care although current system design and triage strategies are suboptimal for rural communities. In this project, we will model and compare the effectiveness emergency triage strategies across rural settings to inform optimal stroke systems of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Disorders and diseases of the lung account for much of the morbidity and mortality that occurs during childhood, and the onset of lung disease in childhood is a strong predictor for respiratory disease in later life. The prevention and/or treatment of childhood respiratory diseases also has the potential to significantly reduce disease and medical costs associated with disease throughout the lifespan. Recognizing the paucity of researchers and physician scientists who focus on basic, clinical and translational research centered on pediatric lung diseases, the proposed training program will address the substantial need for academic pediatric pulmonologists and pulmonary investigators who will establish research programs and train leaders of tomorrow.

PROJECT_TITLE: Multidisciplinary Training Program in Pediatric Lung Diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative The objective of the proposed work is to develop a broadly protective influenza vaccine by engineering the protein hemagglutinin and its multivalent presentation from nanoscale scaffolds. The research is relevant to public health because it could lead to the development of new and effective vaccines that provide robust, durable, and broad protection against influenza viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary B cells can be edited ex vivo to express HIV-1 broadly neutralizing antibodies and then returned to their host where, in response to a vaccine, they proliferate and affinity mature, ultimately generating potent neutralizing sera. However, efficient in vivo editing techniques are necessary to transform this technology into a viable approach for controlling an established HIV-1 infection. Here we develop novel B-cell targeting capsids, efficient editing cassettes, and potent immunogens necessary to edit B cell directly in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Ferroptosis is an iron-mediated, lipid peroxide propagated, non-apoptotic form of cell death that exacerbates renal vascular complications derived from type 2 diabetes and hyperglycemia. Genetic deletion of uncharacterized transmembrane protein 164 (TMEM164) robustly desensitizes renal cells to ferroptosis, protecting against programmed cell death. This proposal seeks to better understand the mechanisms by which TMEM164 regulates ferroptotic signaling, presenting researchers and clinicians a novel therapeutic target for delaying the progression of degenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This project is aimed at defining how the ESRRA-mortalin metabolic axis facilitates thyroid tumor cell proliferation and survival. We will determine whether the metabolism-sensitive transcription factor ESRRA increases mortalin expression in thyroid cancer and whether mortalin, in turn, regulates the interplay between glycolysis and the TCA cycle. We will also identify key processes in this metabolic axis and evaluate their potential as a target to suppress therapeutically challenging thyroid tumor subtypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: To help accelerate progress in the understanding, treatment, and prevention of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) we propose a predoctoral training program that leverages established strengths at the University of Rochester in foundational and translational research on aging and ADRD. Through an innovative curriculum that includes memory care clinical exposure, our primary objective is to develop a cadre of early- stage scientists with the depth and breadth of knowledge, skills, appreciation, and experience necessary to establish careers as independent investigators in the area of dementia research; to work in an interdisciplinary environment designed to aggressively translate research to practice; and to reduce the toll of cognitive disorders in later life.

PROJECT_TITLE: T32 University of Rochester Aging and Alzheimer's disease Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The aging of the US population will lead to unprecedented growth in the number of people affected by neurodegenerative disease. The UAB Training Program in Neurodegeneration is addressing this problem by training scientists in diverse aspects of research on neurodegeneration so that they can leverage the emerging knowledge in this field and develop the cures of the future for these common and serious disorders.
PROJECT_TERMS: Nerve Degeneration;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: UAB Training Program in Neurodegeneration

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE According to the CDC, over 30 million Americans live with diabetes with more than a quarter of adults over 65 years suffer from its debilitating sequela. Although insulin is a commonly used and effective treatment, it comes with the risk of causing fatal hypoglycemia since most diabetic patients have impairment in glucose-regulating brain pathways that normally counteracts sharp drops in blood glucose. By investigating brain mechanisms through which hypoglycemia counterregulation is impaired, we aim to discover potential avenues of intervention to restore brain circuits that protect against fatal hypoglycemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The ability to learn and execute motor skills is central to our everyday existence. Our reliance on motor skills leaves us vulnerable to neurological disorders and strokes that affect the neural circuits involved in their acquisition and control. Our research goal is to identify these circuits, delineate their respective functions, and explain the logic by which they work together to implement motor skill learning and execution. This work will inform the design of new therapeutics and neurorehabilitation paradigms for patients with motor disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are a leading cause of neurological disability. Because of its ability to resolve brain structure and function noninvasively, neuroimaging has become a leading strategy used for translational research in ADRD and a prominent biomarker strategy for clinical differential diagnosis of ADRD, for defining preclinical stages of ADRD, and for evaluating for target engagement and therapeutic responses in trials. This cross-disciplinary training program in translational neuroimaging of ADRD aims to leverage the University of Pennsylvania’s longstanding track record of innovation and translation in biomedical neuroimaging in ADRD to increase training for the current and emerging generation of researchers in neuroimaging approaches that have potential to impact cognitive impairment and dementia including neuropathology, translational research, drug discovery, and clinical trials of ADRD.
PI_NAMEs: DETRE, JOHN A;GROSSMAN, MURRAY ;MCMILLAN, COREY T (contact)
PROJECT_TERMS: Alzheimer's disease related dementia;neuroimaging;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Cross-disciplinary training in translational neuroimaging of ADRD

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: The primary purpose of the training program based in the University of North Carolina Center for Aging and Health is to continue to nurture the development of future physician (allopathic and osteopathic) leaders in research related to aging. The nation’s biggest public health challenge for the coming decades is how to best care for our burgeoning population of persons aged 65 and older – particularly those who are living with multiple chronic conditions and disabilities. This training grant is designed to build on the success of our current funded program by increasing the number of physicians who are trained to conduct important research related to aging, which can help solve critical problems around the care of older persons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Accumulating evidence suggests that infections could play an important role in Alzheimer’s disease (AD), however, exact mechanism is unclear. The goal of this project is to significantly improve our understanding of mechanisms connecting AD and common infections, and suggest new candidates for AD prevention based on repurposing of existing adult vaccines, using large samples of existing population-based human data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Imaging in the biomedical sciences – from the individual molecule to the entire body – is a critical component of research which drives some of the most important discoveries of our time. The development of imaging technologies by scientists should be informed by a knowledge of the important targets around which to develop an imaging strategy and conversely, biomedical researchers should be fluent in the broad range of imaging platforms available to optimally design their studies – a reciprocal relationship that will foster the kind of scientific discovery that can be translated to the bedside. This Program aims to train post-doctoral fellows to acquire core competency in imaging technologies across a broad spectrum, to achieve fundamental proficiency in tools for translational research spanning basic to clinical investigation, and to use these tools to pursue hypothesis-driven research, with a focus on cardiovascular medicine.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Imaging Sciences in Translational Cardiovascular Research
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(JA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Colorectal Cancer is the 3rd most prominent cancer found in men and women, and is the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the United States. I hope that these studies will indentify new molecular targets that translate into new, more effective treatments for cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Signaling Aberrations and Cerebral Cavernous Malformations Pathogenesis Cerebral Cavernous Malformations (CCM) are blood vessel abnormalities occurring in the brain. The CCMs can bleed and cause seizures or strokes. In this renewal application of a program project, four leading laboratories working on this disease will continue our investigation into the underlying processes that cause the CCMs to form, and to cause them to bleed. Using mice that we have genetically engineered to have the disease and comparing these animals with tissue and blood from human CCM patients, we will work towards a fuller understanding of the disease with the goal of generating new ideas for therapy.

PHR: NARRATIVE – CORE A, UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO A program project linking four leading investigators at separate institutions has facilitated exceptional discoveries regarding cerebral cavernous malformations, which cause brain bleeding, and lack effective therapy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1 Cerebral Cavernous Malformations (CCM) are blood vessel abnormalities occurring in the brain. The CCMs can bleed and cause seizures or strokes. In the past we learned that the cells in the malformed blood vessels acquire mutations in specific genes; sometimes in multiple genes. In this project we will broaden our search for these mutations in additional genes, and determine whether individual cells acquire more than one mutation. In addition, we will characterize the gene expression pattern of the mutant and normal cells in the malformations to determine if the mutant cells can alter the normal cells to recruit them into the growing CCM. Finally, using mice that we have genetically engineered to have the CCM disease, we will continue our quest for an effective treatment - testing candidate drugs coming from ideas generated by the program project team.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Cerebral Cavernous Malformations (CCM) are a common neurovascular disease caused by loss of function of genes such as KRIT1 and for which there is no specific pharmacological therapy. Bleeding into the brain is a major cause of symptoms of this disease. These studies are testing the idea that over activity of a mechanism that normally prevents blood clots contributes to bleeding in CCM. This research will define new mechanisms for CCM pathogenesis and may lead to new therapeutic targets in CCM disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Infertility affects 1 out of 6 couples in the U.S, often resulting from aneuploidy, a genetic abnormality in which a cell contains an improper number of chromosomes. The incidence of aneuploidy increases with maternal age; however, there is enormous variation in the frequency at any given age. This study aims to identify genes in the maternal genome that correlate with risk of aneuploidy and evaluate their functional significance in reproduction in model organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria continue to emerge in the human population, reducing treatment options for patients, and prompting researchers to look for novel bacterial targets in order to develop effective treatments. Glycosyltransferases (GTs) are enzymes that are responsible for diversifying the glycan portion of bacterial glycoconjugates, which are essential for bacterial viability and pathogenicity, and represent a viable antibiotic target. The proposed biochemical and biophysical methods will determine structural factors that can be used to determine which glycans GTs act upon and how best to direct therapeutics against them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE – PROJECT 3 Cerebral cavernous malformation (CCM) is a common cause of stroke for which there is no drug therapy. Studies from our group and others over the past 5 years have defined an upstream pathway by which cerebral cavernous malformations arise, but the downstream mechanisms and potential downstream drug targets remain unknown. Our preliminary studies in mice and humans identify two novel downstream mechanisms for CCM formation: gain of PI3K signaling and proteolytic cleavage of the matrix proteoglycan versican. This proposal will use established and new mouse models to test the role of these downstream pathways and determine whether existing FDA-approved agents such as rapamycin can be used to treat CCM disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medications targeting the CGRP signaling pathway are increasingly used for migraine headaches, but constipation is a common side effect. CGRP is produced by an important group of nerve cells in the intestine, but its functions in these cells are not clear. This proposal aims to determine how intestinal CGRP and the nerve cells that make CGRP regulate gastrointestinal (GI) motility; this knowledge will help minimize side effects of anti-CGRP medications and show whether they could be used to treat GI dysmotility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The National Institutes of Health (NIH) has made it a priority to address a disparity in the participation of underrepresented minority populations in the biomedical, behavioral and clinical research workforce. The University of Texas at Arlington is a large research institution that has a minority majority undergraduate population (~35,000 undergraduate students) and thus is an ideal institution to address the need to promote diversity. This program will expose 50 different underrepresented minority undergraduate students each year for 5 consecutive years (250 students total), to a rigorous 10-week summer research education experience with the goal of increasing underrepresented minorities in the future biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The molecular architecture of nonself recognition, including microbial perception and innate immune signaling, bears remarkable similarity from plants to worms, insects, and mammals. Our genetic and biochemical studies on elucidating the signaling networks orchestrating plant immune activation while avoiding autoimmunity reveal the molecular basis of plant defense and shed light on the evolutionarily convergent mechanisms in cellular signaling of animal innate immunity. Our study is relevant to the mission of NIH and is fundamental for basic medical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diastolic heart failure (dHF) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) are both prevalent diseases where there is a poor understanding of the underlying mechanisms behind the disease. Microvascular dysfunction has been implicated in playing a role in both diseases, but importantly has been shown to underlie the development of cognitive impairment; this project will examine the vascular contributions in a mixed dHF/AD pathology as well as investigate the underlying molecular mechanisms. Through my proposed studies, I aim to better understand the pathological role of adenosine kinase (ADK) in vascular dysfunction and eventual cognitive impairment in a mixed dHF/AD pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bidirectional transport of cargo in cells and neurons is carried out by two antagonistic microtubule motors, kinesin, and dynein; however, how these motors coordinate to determine the direction of transport is unknown. Defects in cellular cargo transport are linked to neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer’s and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), emphasizing the importance of understanding the underlying mechanism of bidirectional transport. This project will use novel high-resolution microscopy techniques to track and analyze the complex interplay between molecular motors as they transport cargo along microtubules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Currently there is no successful treatment that restores damaged brain circuitry. Direct reprogramming approaches hold great promise for brain repair since they can convert differentiated cells from multiple sources into neurons in vivo. Important challenges for the application of cell reprogramming strategies to circuit repair that derive from the current lack of precision in generating specific types of neurons with functional properties matching the endogenous neurons in the brain. Precise conversion between neuron subtypes can be induced within the developing brain, but not in mature neurons. Identifying the mechanisms that keep neuron subtype identity unchanged in mature neurons will reveal barriers that preclude functional conversion between neuron subtypes in vivo. We propose to investigate these mechanisms in the cerebral cortex, produce a clinically relevant cortical neuron subtype

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The SARS-Co-V2 pandemic has made it clear that we need new, rapid, and adaptable methods to create and manufacture new vaccines for emerging infectious diseases. While mRNA vaccines have been produced with unprecedented speed and high levels of efficacy, they are challenging to manufacture and need to be kept frozen, preventing their rapid distribution across the globe. As future epidemics caused by new viruses are expected to occur with increasing frequency due to global socio-economic, environmental, and ecological trends, we are pursuing the development of a new DNA vaccine system that would be easier to deploy on a global scale than mRNA vaccines because they could be conserved at ambient temperature and would be easier to manufacture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While blood transfusions have been life-saving for many patients with sickle cell disease, the immune response to red blood cells can be detrimental. This project investigates why patients with sickle cell disease are more likely to make these harmful immune responses. Identifying factors that lead to increased immune responses could allow identification of at-risk patients prior to transfusion and allow for personalized protocols to improve transfusion safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed research is relevant to public health because we aim to improve upon predictive analytic tools that inform clinical decision-making by developing frameworks to address dataset shift, a cause of model deterioration in dynamic settings, a critical step to accurately identify high risk patients who may benefit from earlier interventions. This proposal will evaluate extent and mechanisms of dataset shift during the emergence of the COVID-19 pandemic in an existing EHR-based risk prediction model, understand how rapid shift in model performance impacts case-management, and assess competing methods of model revision and retraining that address dataset shift and optimize predictive accuracy over time. Findings from this work are relevant to the NIH’s mission by generating fundamental knowledge to inform clinicians, researchers, and policy makers about effective approaches to improve the reliability of predictive analytic tools, thereby allowing better risk-adjusted targeting of evidence-based outpatient interventions that decrease likelihood of future hospitalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative summary Islet development in pigs and humans have remarkable similarities, including molecular, genetic, cellular, physiological resemblances not observed in more commonly investigated animal models like mice. Here we propose developmental studies of islet gene regulation and functional maturation, and genome editing in pigs, that should reveal conserved mechanisms underlying islet formation and function, and generate new genetic models of human diabetes mellitus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: LRRK2 (Leucine Rich Repeat Kinase 2) protein is one of the major risk factors for Parkinson’s disease (PD). We recently discovered that LRRK2 interacts with NLRP1 and NLRP3 proteins, which are key mediators of immunity, suggesting a role for specific pathways of cellular innate immunity, inflammation and neurodegeneration in pathogenesis of PD. We will investigate these pathways, which may provide novel targets for development of disease-modifying therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Eighty-five percent (85%) of cardiovascular disease (CVD) deaths occur due to either myocardial infarction (MI) or stroke, platelet-driven events. Antiplatelet therapy is not commonly prescribed to prevent a first MI or stroke as the cardioprotective benefits are offset by major bleeding risk. This study will investigate a previously unexplored platelet candidate to ascertain how it regulates functional responses, to ultimately provide a rationale for the development of a new therapeutic class to dampen the inflammatory and prothrombotic actions of platelets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Total knee replacement utilization continues to increase across all age groups and is placing substantial burden on the economy. To maximize the value of the costly surgery, it is necessary to identify effective and scalable strategies to improve weight management and maintain function in this aging population following knee replacement. This project examines if a weight loss program designed for patients after knee replacement improves weight loss, physical activity, pain, and function, as well as if the program is cost effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Research in pediatric benign hematology plays an important role in advancing the diagnosis and treatment of inherited disorders including sickle cell disease and the thalassemias, hemophilia and thrombophilia, bone marrow failure syndromes, and benign vasculogenesis disorders. Improved therapy and cure for inherited and acquired pediatric blood diseases will improve the quality of life of affected individuals, reduce hospital admissions, and minimize in-hospital acquired clotting complications. The study of benign pediatric hematology disorders is very much underserved as recognized by the NIH and our training program has been a nationally recognized leader in attracting and fostering the development of talented trainees who become the future pediatric science and leaders, advancing our understanding of benign pediatric blood diseases and identifying novel treatments and cures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The immune system and nervous system work together to coordinate host responses to infection and injury. Inflammation is part of the innate immune response, but it is not known how the nervous system senses and transmits signals about inflammatory mediators. Using a novel technique to record from peripheral sensory neurons, we will determine how neurons encode and represent these important immune-related signals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While physical activity (PA) has been widely accepted as an effective non-pharmacological pain management strategy, many Latinos with chronic spine pain (CSP) do not engage in PA, highlighting the need to investigate the multilevel factors that intersect to contribute to this disparity. The proposed study will apply an intersectional perspective informed by the socioecological model to examine multilevel factors that influence momentary PA to better understand determinants of PA participation among Latinos with CSP. The knowledge gained from this study will inform future development of culturally relevant and personalized digital health interventions that address real-time barriers to PA with the ultimate goal of alleviating PA health disparities in Latinos with CSP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pancreatitis (CP) is an emerging, but poorly understood condition in children that significantly impacts quality of life with high healthcare costs. The objective of this application is to delineate the natural history of pediatric CP through careful prospective analysis of INSPPIRE-2 cohort, to define the impact of genetic modifiers on disease course and to determine the mechanisms involved in pancreatogenic diabetes mellitus. Our long-term goal is to develop diagnostic modalities, prognostic factors and better treatment approaches for pediatric chronic pancreatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Backwards lymph flow in the intestine and mesentery may underlie protein-losing enteropathy (PLE). Here, we will apply a novel approach to functionally image and quantify lymphatic transport from the gut to the lymphovenous valve to better understand the role of lymphatics in PLE. We will evaluate a “2-hit” hypothesis that (1) impaired lymphatic flow and (2) inflammatory loss of valve integrity combine to drive clinically significant PLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The development of novel methods to directly introduce molecular complexity can significantly advance synthetic and medicinal chemistry by streamlining the synthesis of biologically relevant molecules. The objective of this proposed research is the development of a novel synthetic platform for the catalytic generation of alkene radical cation intermediates from simple alcohols via visible light photocatalysis to enable the development of new synthetic methods outside the scope of existing technologies. This work will provide a novel entry point to both classical and non-classical reactive intermediates and enable the rapid synthesis of pharmaceutically relevant molecules and analog libraries for medicinal chemistry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The instability of the cancer genome, a driver of malignant evolution, can be targeted for the rational design of therapy, exemplified by the application of PARP inhibitors as maintenance therapy for cancers with BRCA1 or BRCA2 defects that inactivate homologous recombination repair (HRR) of genomic DNA. From yeast genetic studies of synthetic lethal interactions among genome instability suppressor genes, we identified and verified that HRR-deficiency also sensitizes cancer cells to the loss of the FEN1 endonuclease. This study will investigate the FEN1 endonuclease as a rational drug target for HRR-deficient cancers and establish a platform for further identification of synthetic lethal interactions to target cancer genome instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity increases the risk of cancer; thus, individuals that are obese are more likely to undergo chemotherapy in their lifetime. While it is common practice to apply a dosing cap, current recommendations for the treatment of obese cancer patients is full body surface area chemotherapy dosing regimens despite some evidence suggesting that these patients may have exacerbated drug toxicities including perturbations to skeletal muscle mitochondrial function. The primary goal of my proposed F31 is to 1) understand the impact of obesity on chemotherapy-induced skeletal muscle mitochondrial dysfunction and 2) provide mechanistic and therapeutic insights aimed at better improving chemotherapy tolerance with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Hydrocodone is one of the most prescribed and abused opioids in the USA. With the legalization of cannabis across the USA, the use of cannabis for medicinal purposes is also increasing, resulting in increases in the concomitant use of both drugs in the population. As the effect cannabis may have on an individual who is taking hydrocodone is unknown and may cause adverse drug events, the goal of the proposed studies will be to identify potential drug-drug interaction between major cannabinoids and their metabolites and hydrocodone and determine whether these interactions may result in adverse drug events and allow for new medical guidance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alternative splicing is a post-transcriptional regulatory process that is dysregulated in cancer and may generate unique peptides, called neoantigens, that can be recognized by antitumor CD8+ T cells. We have built a bioinformatic pipeline that has identified 21 candidate alternative splicing-derived neoantigens in non-small cell lung cancer, a deadly cancer type. The experiments outlined in this proposal will determine how these molecules contribute to the immunogenicity of non-small cell lung cancer, which may facilitate the development of new immunotherapies for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Neural circuits in the medial entorhinal cortex are critical for spatial navigation, learning, and memory. The completion of this project will provide mechanistic insight into how excitatory and inhibitory neurons in layer II/III mEC synchronize to generate theta-nested gamma oscillations observed during spatial navigation. A map of functional connectivity as well as the extent of recurrent excitation and inhibition between stellate, pyramidal, and fast-spiking interneurons, will provide a foundation for developing accurate models of spatially tuned neurons and grid cell formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Decades of clinical trials have not improved overall survival of pediatric patients diagnosed with H3K27M- mutant diffuse midline glioma (DMG). H3K27M-mutant DMG is one of the most challenging cancers to treat due to its location within delicate regions of the brain and its highly aggressive nature. We outline in this proposal a series of studies that will evaluate a new therapeutic target for the treatment of H3K27M-mutant DMG.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Optogenetics is a promising approach to understanding cellular regulation, but current efforts to recreate synthetic circuits are hampered by a limited toolset of multi-chromatic, orthogonal regulatable proteins. This proposal will multiplex new light regulatable tools to exert control over gene expression. This knowledge will inform engineering approaches to improve control over proteins and/or RNA in mammalian cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Negative mood is a transdiagnostic feature of mental illnesses that together impose an economic burden of more than $600 billion annually in the US and inflict immeasurable human suffering. Conceptual and methodological barriers have slowed scientific discovery of the brain basis of negative affect. I will surmount these barriers with innovative analyses of an existing ultra-high field fMRI data set to test novel hypotheses about a neural circuit involved in negative affect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will study two long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs), that affect cellular function directly as RNAs, without being translated into proteins, and are known to regulate progression of gliomas: an oncogene LINC00152 and a tumor suppressor DRAIC. In the F99 phase, I will focus on structure-function studies of the lncRNAs that will identify the minimal regions of these RNAs important for their action and thus identify how these lncRNAs regulate glioma progression, while in parallel familiarizing myself with animal models and histopathology of gliomas. In the K00 phase, I will focus on two strategies for therapy of gliomas based on the knowledge obtained during the F99: methods of targeting/delivering lncRNAs in gliomas and screening for small chemicals that will reverse the actions of the lncRNAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The effective treatment of bacterial infections of skin, deep soft tissues and wounds continues to be a major unmet healthcare challenge, especially in patients whose antimicrobial responses are compromised by underlying diabetes. The proposed work seeks to establish a new class of antimicrobials, inspired by immune cells, that are synergistic through the combination of histones with agents that target the outer surface of bacteria. The successful outcome of this work would provide fundamental insight into a novel antimicrobial mechanism and produce important pre-clinical data for the development of new therapeutics that treat skin, soft tissue, and wound infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proper three-dimensional organization of DNA within the nucleus is critically important for healthy cells, and alterations to organization are associated with developmental disease and cancer. This research program aims to better characterize the patterns of DNA organization that occur in healthy cells and to investigate how these impact important cellular processes such as gene expression, DNA replication, and DNA repair. A more complete understanding of how 3D genome organization functions within the cell will provide key insights into why this process is associated with human disease and may inform new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The inflammasome component NLRP3 is well known for its function in innate immunity, but its unexpected expression in T cells has sparked an exploration of its role in adaptive immunity. By taking both loss-of-function and gain-of-function approaches, this study will help gain mechanistic insights into the underappreciated anti- inflammatory role of NLRP3 in intestinal Tregs. The results obtained from this study will undoubtedly guide effective therapies for chronic intestinal disorders such as inflammatory bowel disease, in which the anti- inflammatory vs. proinflammatory role of NLRP3 is still debated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Countless times per day, we must categorize and recognize objects in our visual environment to meaningfully and purposefully interact with our surroundings. This project aims to examine the neural correlates of where categorization occurs in the human brain, how it occurs under perceptual ambiguity, and how previous memories interact may mediate these neural computations. Investigating these questions in the human brain using highly spatiotemporally precise neuroimaging methods (iEEG and single-unit spiking data) will provide insight into the fundamental mechanisms of semantics, which will help with the early identification of cognitive impairments in Alzheimer’s Disease and other dementias as well as long-term treatment of epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The complex coordination of cis-regulatory elements (CREs), the so-called cis-regulatory code, regulates many biological processes, including transcriptional regulation and alternative splicing. This project will develop machine learning-based methods to decipher this code by quantitatively characterizing higher-order interactions within CREs and between multiple CREs using functional genomics data. This will have direct applications to fundamental problems in basic biological science as well as to the understanding and treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This grant focuses on novel therapeutic approaches to address small cell lung cancer, an exceptionally lethal disease, using multiple emerging technologies including single cell profiling and novel disease models based on direct modification of human tumors by genome editing in vivo. We will define and target a newly identified stem- like tumor subpopulation we have identified, analyze and target lineage plasticity as a mechanism of acquired drug resistance, and conduct screens to identify new and tractable therapeutic vulnerabilities in human small cell lung cancers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will fill gaps in our understanding of access to and effectiveness of rehabilitation care for patients discharged home following stroke. It will also determine the potential effectiveness of a transitional care model in improving access to and appropriate delivery of rehabilitation care. Findings from this study will inform care delivery at the patient-, provider-, health system-, and policy-levels and may have a significant impact on the health of the nearly 800,000 persons per year who experience a stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use in pregnant women has increased over the past decade, highlighting the importance of efforts to understand how environmental and other exposures during pregnancy affect brain development and child outcomes. The PRELUDE consortium for the HEALthy Brain and Child Development study will recruit 2720 pregnant women in the 2nd and 3rd trimester and follow their children to age 10, using neuroimaging, behavioral assessments, EEG, biosample collection, and assessments of parent-child interaction and the home environment. This research will lead to greater understanding of factors affecting early childhood brain development, allowing targeted interventions and improved outcomes for mother-child dyads.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As evidenced by the recent SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 pandemic, more rapid development of medicines that can be widely, quickly and easily implemented for new viruses would significantly reduce rates of hospitalization and death. Our goal is to develop oral drug cocktails that strongly inhibit SARS-CoV-2 circulating variants of concern and other coronaviruses that could seed future pandemics. Mathematical modeling will be employed at all stages to optimize drug combinations and will ultimately assist in the design of ready-to-launch clinical trial designs with combinations that are likely to be effective in people infected with SARS-CoV-2 or other coronaviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced management of children with type 1 diabetes (T1D) aims to utilize diabetes devices, such as insulin pumps (IP) and continuous glucose monitors (CGM), to optimize glycemic control; however, use of these devices has not resulted in the expected improvements in T1D outcomes. We will identify unmet psychoeducational needs in parents of children using IP and CGM to manage T1D and leverage this information to inform a feasibility and acceptability study assessing an app-delivered psychoeducational intervention intended to improve knowledge and alter behaviors related to diabetes technology use. Successful execution of this project will inform a future randomized controlled trial that will demonstrate the efficacy of an easily distributed psychoeducational tool that will help to realize the full potential of diabetes technologies while also providing Dr. Marks with the training and mentorship needed to transition to an independent physician scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Because of our success with peripheral nerve transfer for restoration of function in preclinical animal investigations, we plan to begin human clinical translation very cautiously with a patient population that most closely matches our preclinical canine model which are patients that have lost control of their bladder, bowel and sexual function but retain intact ambulation recruited primarily from patients with sacral chordoma following tumor removal with sacrectomy surgery. The animal studies in this renewal application will parallel the clinical trial studies to further understand the mechanisms of somatic reinnervation for restoration of bladder emptying function. At present there are no satisfactory interventions for patients with an atonic neurogenic bladder that have lost their peripheral parasympathetic nerves to the bladder and restoration of bladder emptying function is expected to greatly improve the quality of life of these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 30% of all diabetics develop a diabetic foot ulcer, resulting in a lower extremity amputation every 30 seconds worldwide because of a life-threatening infection caused by diabetic foot ulcers. An important driver in non- healing diabetic wounds is impairment in the innate immune system; however, there is limited understanding of the mechanism by which diabetes impairs the innate immune system. I aim to identify the mechanisms underlying diabetes-related impaired innate immune dysfunction that prevents wound healing to facilitate the discovery of novel therapeutics that may prevent amputations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While genetics science has revealed many variants in the human genome associated with brain-related diseases such as Alzheimer's or depression, the culprit effector genes (essential to design effective therapies) remain to be discovered. To that end, I propose a “variant-to-gene” mapping campaign leveraging several cutting-edge genomic techniques (including chromatin conformation capture) in human iPSC lines from individuals and patients of different sex and ethnicity. This study will provide targets for drug discovery and begin to address sex and ethnic differences in brain-related diseases, ultimately advancing the goals of precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Psychological stress can either suppress or enhance pain, but we do not understand how. Furthermore, both chronic stress and pain cause adaptations that make anti-depressants effective in treating chronic pain. The goal of this proposal is to better understand how chronic stress modifies the central norepinephrine system to result increased or decreased control of pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infections by arthropod-borne flaviviruses and respiratory-transmitted coronaviruses are a global detriment to human health with the potential to cause severe epidemics and pandemics. The goal of this project is to characterize the roles of the pan-flavivirus and pan-coronavirus host factors TMEM41B and the closely related protein VMP1 in virus replication and the innate immune response. This work may help to elucidate the druggable potential of both proteins to reduce morbidity and mortality caused by a wide range of flaviviruses and coronaviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Narrative: Overall. NMR spectroscopy has important biomedical applications in structural biology, metabolomics, diagnostics, and drug discovery. The burden of managing the complex computing environment required by NMR impacts both developers and end-users, and slows the adoption of emerging methods. The proposed Center for Biomolecular NMR Data Processing and Analysis will develop robust methods to facilitate discovery, dissemination, management, training, and support for the diverse software needed for biomolecular NMR, to enable the application of NMR to more challenging biomolecular systems, and provide software persistence that is essential for reproducible research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with primary GRM7 mutations and mice lacking metabotropic glutamate receptor 7 (mGlu7) share many phenotypes characteristic of the monogenetic disorder, Rett syndrome (RTT), and we have identified dramatic reductions in mGlu7 expression in brain samples from patients diagnosed with RTT. Our data indicate that compounds that potentiate mGlu7 activity reverse many abnormal RTT phenotypes; coupled with the single gene nature of RTT, this suggests that pairing mGlu7 potentiation with RTT treatment may represent a viable clinical path. We propose to conduct a chemical optimization campaign to develop a candidate for eventual clinical testing, define the RTT populations most likely to respond effectively and safely to this treatment, and validate an EEG biomarker with clinical translatability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (OCSCC), the most common subtype of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), is a devastating disease with poor overall survival and limited targeted therapeutic options. While our preliminary data provide strong evidence that PDCD10 (a multifaceted protein shown to promote a range of oncogenic cellular processes in several solid malignancies) may play a role in driving OCSCC evolution, the direct relevance of PDCD10 in regulating head and neck tumorigenesis have not yet been studied. This proposal will use in vivo and organoid based preclinical models, coupled with comprehensive bioinformatics analysis of longitudinally collected primary human specimens, to evaluate the role of PDCD10 in HNSCC cancerogenesis and driving aggressive tumor cells behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Respiratory infections with influenza viruses cause severe morbidity and mortality in humans and animals worldwide. Yet, current influenza vaccines offer suboptimal protection even when matched to the circulating strain. Flu vaccines that provide broad-spectrum protection against matched and mismatched strains are urgently needed. In this proposal, we will further develop our prototype monovalent M2SR vaccine as a quadrivalent broadly-protective influenza vaccine that can provide effective protection against drifted influenza viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Melanoma is a common and highly lethal cancer. ARF6 is a protein that promotes growth, invasion and metastasis of melanoma and other cancers. Our experiments will impact cancer research by determining how ARF6 controls very common cancer pathways and by providing pre-clinical testing of ARF6-targeted therapy in multiple complementary models of melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Satellite cells are responsible for the marked regenerative capacity of skeletal muscle. Although these stem cells were discovered more than 50 years ago, the molecular mechanisms that program satellite cells for muscle differentiation are incompletely understood. Using unique mouse lines and strategies, the proposed studies will determine the functions of two key myogenic regulatory proteins (MyoD and Myf5) in satellite cell development, myogenic programming and differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  For many patients with blood cancers, undergoing allogeneic bone marrow transplantation is the only chance for cure, but comes with a serious risk for developing inflammation of the intestines that can be life- threatening. In this application, we propose exploring strategies in these patients to protect the mucus layer in the large intestine, which plays a key role in separating the lining of the intestine from the bacteria that reside within the intestine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic pancreatitis (CP) is a progressive, unrelenting disease, often leading to loss of exocrine and endocrine function and debilitating abdominal pain, resulting in significant healthcare costs. The Consortium for the study of Chronic Pancreatitis, Diabetes and Pancreatic Cancer (CPDPC), formed in 2015, has been tasked with undertaking comprehensive clinical, epidemiological, and biological characterization of patients with CP (including adults and children with acute recurrent pancreatitis) to develop treatments and gain insight into the pathophysiology of CP and its sequela: chronic pain, pancreatic exocrine and endocrine insufficiency, and the diabetes/pancreatic cancer association. The Indiana University clinical center pledges to continue its contribution to ongoing CPDPC studies, and propose additional ancillary studies which will be described herein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Combatting resistance is a critical priority in treatment of malaria, and requires continued effort in discovery and development of new antimalarial drug candidates. The recently discovered polyketide natural product bastimolide A is a new potential lead compound for antimalarial drug discovery, and its structural features are unlike other drug candidates, suggesting there may be a novel mechanism of action which could help combat resistance. Using new methods and strategies for 1,5-polyol synthesis, we will (a) synthesize bastimolide A and analogs, including chemoproteomics probes, and (b) evaluate their antiplasmodial potency, improve pharmacological properties, and identify protein(s) and lifecycle stage(s) targeted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Almost 30 million tendon injuries are reported each year, but therapeutic techniques produce mixed successes, with 0-85% of patients showing improvement. We have shown that focused ultrasound (fUS) can be used to create mild collagen fiber fraying and separation in rat tendons, and that the fUS treatment preserves mechanical properties of tendons as well as or better than the conventional dry needling. Our objective is to develop fUS therapy for the treatment of chronic tendinopathies and integrate passive cavitation and tissue Doppler imaging for quantitative feedback of the fUS therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE  The objective of this project is to develop magnetic resonance imaging methods for in vivo evaluation of glymphatic function. The methods will be applied to investigate the role of AQP4 and the glymphatic system in post-stroke edema formation and reabsorption. Such investigation will enhance our understanding of post-stroke pathophysiology, leading to improved patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The importance of the enteric and autonomic nervous systems for maintaining intestinal health is evident in Hirschsprung’s disease (HSCR), defined by the absence of enteric ganglia in distal bowel and caused by a number of mutations that phenocopy the disease in mouse models. This research proposal will investigate neural interactions with the microbiome and immune system that regulate inflammation and determine the role of the microbiome in mediating persistent functional and inflammatory issues experienced by HSCR patients with the hope of facilitating the development of mechanism-based therapeutics to alleviate these chronic bowel complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA misfolding has been linked to human disease and is a major challenge for the development of RNA biotechnology, but our current understanding of how nascent RNA folds during transcription is limited. Using riboswitches as a model system, we will develop high-throughput tools to investigate how transcription coordinates the formation of biologically functional RNA structures and how perturbing these processes can cause RNA misfolding. This work will uncover basic principles of cotranscriptional RNA structure formation that will advance our ability to engineer RNA systems for biomedical applications, and predict how mutations cause RNA to fold into dysfunctional structures.

PROJECT_TITLE: Mechanisms of cotranscriptional RNA structure formation
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award B Study Section[MRAB]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Drosophila neuromuscular junction is a model synapse that uses multiple neuromodulators for neurons to control muscle contractions and electrochemical sensors could be ideal for interrogating this signaling as they can follow neuromodulation in real time. In this proposal, we will develop new electrode fabrication technologies based on carbon nanomaterials, 3D printing, and Si-based microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) strategies and apply these electrodes to neuromodulator measurements in the Drosophila NMJ and in vivo. With a focus on easy, batch fabrication, these electrodes will be made available to the neuroscience community, to facilitate studies of real-time neuromodulation and how it malfunctions during disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE State-level pregnancy termination policies have dramatically changed over the past decade. Only limited research examines the population-level maternal and child health impacts of such policies, and research to date has not identified subgroups most at risk of experiencing an adverse outcome or state-level conditions that might buffer such adverse effects. Understanding maternal and child health effects of these policies is crucial to prepare public health and health care systems to care for groups most affected by policies and to implement other strategies to buffer adverse impacts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic post-surgical pain (CPSP) is a significant public health concern affecting up to 80% of adults who have undergone surgery and is a contributor to the opioid epidemic. Identification of biopsychosocial risk factors is crucial for pain prevention and more effective treatment strategies. The proposed translational research plan will utilize a prospective study design as well as a mechanistic clinical trial to address substantial gaps in the literature, including neurological mechanisms underlying behavioral treatment response.
