IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Since neural degeneration is an important component of the response to neural trauma and is a consequence of a number of neurological diseases, it is a major public health problem. We have reported the unexpected finding that a group of immune cells thought to be required for clearing debris from degenerating nerves is not required, and we present the first evidence that a quite different group of immune cells is required for this process. We will explore in depth the cells and receptors required for this clearance and therefore for nerve regeneration.

PHR: Project Narrative Although highly effective anti-HIV drugs are available and are making an impact on HIV control, HIV epidemic is still a major health problem. This long-standing training program is dedicated to training individuals who wish to secure their PhD or M.D./PhD dual degrees in HIV/AIDS Research and to offer advanced training in specialized HIV/AIDS topics to those who have already obtained a PhD Or MD degrees. An outstanding roster of training faculty and research topics that are aligned with national priorities assure a high quality, targeted training of individuals who will form the future workforce that tackles the AIDS epidemic in the coming years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative While the environment, nutrition, and genetic factors play a major role in the metabolic aspects of aging, recent studies have suggested maternal metabolism can have a profound impact on progeny lifespan, physiology, and susceptibility to metabolic diseases. Our work examines how metabolic disruptions in oocytes reprogram progeny metabolism and aging. Insights gained from these studies provide a foundation to understand how changes in metabolic state of a mother can shorten lifespan in children by increasing incidence of metabolic disfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: A hallmark of HIV infection is intestinal inflammation and loss of gut epithelial integrity, which result in translocation of gut bacteria into the circulation, chronic systemic immune activation, and HIV disease progression. In this proposal we will utilize novel in vivo and ex vivo model systems and cutting-edge technologies to investigate the mechanism by which HIV infection results in death of intestinal epithelial cells and disrupted barrier function. These findings may inform the development new strategies to target gut integrity and improve outcomes for people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is associated with increased estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) breast cancer (BC) risk and a 2-4 fold increase in mortality across all BC subtypes, but mechanisms of increased acquired resistance to therapy and ensuing fatal BC metastasis in obesity remain unclear. This project studies how the estrogen, estrone (E1), which dominates after menopause and is much higher in obese local mammary fat, co-operates with ER/ NFκB and the Receptor for Advanced Glycation End-products (RAGE) in BC cells, adipocytes, and the tumor microenvironment to impair drug treatment responses. Preclinical studies in organoids and PDX models test the ability of new RAGE inhibitor drugs to reverse acquired endocrine therapy resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The overarching goal of the current project is to interrogate the biological role of the G- protein-coupled receptor GPR109A in colonic epithelia and immune cells and the involvement of the ketogenesis pathway in the colon and the metabolites of commensal bacteria in the activation of this receptor. We will investigate how GPR109A and colonic ketogenesis protect against colon cancer and test the hypothesis that GPR109A activation stabilizes the tumor suppressor p53 and its effector signaling. If successful, our study will provide a molecular link between bacteria-generated xenobiotics to colon cancer prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE In this project we investigate tumor cell-intrinsic p38 MAPK signaling as a new mechanism of resistance to immune-checkpoint inhibitors. We will address this using large-scale, high-dimensional multi-omics and spatial data as well as biologic correlatives in pre- and on-treatment biopsies from a human clinical trial combining a p38 inhibitor and anti-PD1 immunotherapy in head and neck cancer. We will further utilize a combination of bioinformatics analyses, mechanistic HNSCC syngeneic murine and in vitro experiments to validate our translational observations. Finally, we will identify and validate additional co-activated immune-resistance mechanisms to target in combination with p38 inhibitor and anti-PD1 for future clinical trial evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than six million Americans suffer from heart failure, a disease characterized by derangements in cardiac energy metabolism and mitochondrial function, which will cost the United States over 40 billion dollars in 2020 alone. The goal of this work is to broadly understand how metabolic and mitochondrial gene regulatory programs are maintained in the adult heart. This understanding could promote the development of novel therapeutics for this disease which represents an urgent unmet societal need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The molecular mechanisms underlying HIV associated neurocognitive disorder, a major comorbidity that persists in 30-50% of patients undergoing combination anti-retroviral therapy, remains incompletely understood. Our ongoing studies suggest that persistent inflammatory signaling potentially driven by epigenetic alterations may drive HAND and that these changes may be beneficially modulated using cannabinoids. Knowledge from the proposed studies will provide a better understanding of the molecular basis of HIV associated neurocognitive disorder and open new avenues for the development of targeted anti-inflammatory therapies for not only HIV/SIV but also numerous other chronic neuroinflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although, treatment of lung cancer has improved in recent years, the majority of patients will still succumb to this disease. Improving our understanding of the tumor microenvironment will increase our ability to reactivate the natural defense mechanisms that are silenced in patients with malignant tumors. The goal of this work is to learn how to harness lipids to improve tumor immunity and sensitivity to currently available cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The COVID-19 pandemic has created numerous challenges and stressors for family functioning that have increased rates of domestic violence and child maltreatment in the United States and across the Globe. Accordingly, developmental scientists, clinicians, and public policy advocates have underscored the public health significance of advancing an understanding of the lasting impact of COVID-19 on family functioning. The current application offers time-sensitive opportunity to examine how the disruptions associated with through building upon the aims of a multi-method, longitudinal study of families in a current R01 project through examining how COVID-19 modifies associations between interparental hostility and harsh parenting in families with young children and how parental self-regulation may underlie these processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a significant health care issue that affects 10 million individuals each year throughout the world and about 2.8 million in United States for whom there are limited treatment options. While numerous invasive therapies have been evaluated, one non-invasive approach that has clinical relevance is environmental enrichment (EE), which is a therapeutic regimen that we have refined over the course of the parent grant to mimic clinical rehabilitation and has been shown to provide significant benefits relative to non- enriched housing. While EE is being optimized as a potential model of neurorehabilitation, additional empirical research is essential to learn more about its capabilities and limitations that ultimately strengthen its validity and applicability, and thus the goal of this renewal is to evaluate EE long-term, the effects of refresher rehabilitation, and bridge therapies that robustly expand on the parent grant successes that will fill gaps and expand our understanding of behavioral outcomes and mechanisms after TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is one of the main drivers of increased mortality attributed to “diseases of despair” in the U.S. Suicide risk prediction algorithms have potential to vastly improve identification of individuals at high risk of suicide, but there is very little evidence to guide routine use of this powerful technology in primary care. Project deliverables will include clinical decision support tools designed to support use of suicide risk predictive analytics in primary care, that can be potentially scaled nationwide, and lay a foundation for future evaluation of the effectiveness of implementation for preventing suicide attempts and deaths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths worldwide, accounting for ~130,000 lives annually in the US alone. We have generated data from a large cohort of lung cancer patients showing that neutrophils inversely correlate with CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocyte content within lung tumors. The purpose of this project is to demonstrate that tumor-associated neutrophils limit the ability of T cells to infiltrate into the malignant portions of tumors. Successful completion of the proposed studies should identify a therapeutic strategy with which to improve T cell infiltration into cancers that would improve response rates to immune based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: RELEVANCE Hypoxia (O2 deprivation) plays a central role in a diverse array of human diseases, including ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, traumatic brain injury, spinal cord injury, pulmonary hypertension, Cerebral Palsy, COVID-19, and cancer. Our tissues respond to hypoxia by employing a conserved hypoxia response pathway, yet we have a poor understanding of how this response combats hypoxic damage. It is critical to identify and functionally characterize key targets of this pathway in order to develop novel applications for the treatment and prevention of disorders and diseases that involve hypoxia as part of their etiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Diminished first-phase insulin secretion is the early and detrimental defect in type 2 diabetes. The preliminary data show an increase in first-phase insulin secretion and improved glucose tolerance to supranormal levels following exocrine pancreas ablation. This proposal aims to understand the dramatic increase in the first-phase insulin secretion following the exocrine tissue ablation, test the effect of exocrine pancreas loss in mice models of hyperglycemia, and identify the underlying causes of the improved insulin secretion that accompany loss of the exocrine tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project provides a comprehensive picture of social, neural, and hormonal changes and their relationship to mental health problems in mid-to-late adolescence, a period of peak symptom severity and diagnosis rates for internalizing disorders and self-harm among girls. Understanding the core mechanisms associated with these problems across adolescence will not only enhance our knowledge of how mental illness develops in vulnerable individuals, but also enable translation of this knowledge for developmentally targeted approaches to early intervention and prevention. This project seeks to inform clinical intervention and prevention approaches that target close peer relationships and leverage biological insights to improve adolescent mental health, specifically through the lens of investigating emergence and recurrence of internalizing disorders in adolescent girls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adherence to combination antiretroviral therapy is required to suppress patient HIV viral loads, which is essential to both optimize individual health and prevent onward transmission of HIV. We therefore propose to investigate a novel urine-based point-of-care assay that detects the presence of tenofovir, the backbone of most antiretroviral regimens worldwide, to detect inadequate adherence and support adherence. Our objectives are to study the ability of this new assay to identify patients in need of adherence support and its usefulness, feasibility and acceptability when used to reinforce and support treatment adherence.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Due to extremely limited infrastructure and healthcare resources, motor and cognitive impairments in general and HIV-Associated Neurocognitive Disorders (HAND) in particular often go undiagnosed in people living with HIV (PLWH) and non-communicable diseases (NCDs) in Low and Middle Income Countries (LMICs). Novel and affordable technology-based strategies are needed to offer both evaluation and treatment. In collaboration with partners in Botswana, where the prevalence of both HIV and NCDs is high, we seek to determine the feasibility, acceptability and preliminary efficacy of an innovative and affordable robot-assisted solution to objectively assess and diagnose motor and cognitive impairments after HIV and HIV-Stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cytochrome P450 2E1 (CYP2E1) is a unique mammalian enzyme that can participate in normal biochemical metabolic reactions and can also contribute to cellular damage through production of reactive metabolites. We are studying this paradox using different approaches including cell culture and animal models. I propose to follow up on my recent discoveries that CYP2E1 can have different effects in different compartments of the cell, and study how, why, and when its activity is important for human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will explore the role of mitochondria and oxidative stress in astrogliosis associated with acquired epilepsy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There are clear day/night patterns in the timing of adverse cardiovascular events, including myocardial infarction, stroke and sudden cardiac death, which all strike most frequently in the morning. This research program will examine how circadian rhythms in the cardiovascular system, behavior-related alterations in the cardiovascular system, and an individual’s own vulnerability may interact to affect risk for adverse cardiovascular events. This research will lay the groundwork for optimizing timed therapies for cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social connection is an essential human aspect, yet is poorly understood despite the developmental implications on well-being and development during adolescence, especially for the current GenZ population. This project will disentangle the different elements of social connection in adolescence and its associations to well-being using multiple measurements across short-term (daily) and long-term (across months) time, as well as neurobiological assessment, across contexts. This information will help inform “when” and “who” need intervention to promote positive well-being (and prevent negative well-being) outcomes in support of healthy adolescent development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria remains one of the biggest infectious disease problems in the world, and a major reason for this is resistance of malaria parasites to available drugs. New antimalarial drugs are needed, and a number of candidates are under development. The goals of this project are to characterize ex vivo sensitivity to new antimalarial agents in Uganda and Burkina Faso and genotypic and phenotypic characterization of drug sensitivity outliers to inform optimal choices of new antimalarial drug combinations and the direction of continued drug discovery efforts

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) and Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) are intersecting diseases affecting a significant portion of the global population. Spatial transcriptomics technology provides insights into cell type heterogeneity, but identifying colocalizing cell types and understanding fibrosis, immune interactions, and epithelial repair in kidney spatial transcriptomics data present computational challenges. In this project, we use AI-based spatial transcriptomics methods with multi-omics cell atlas data to understand the pathogenesis of kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative This proposal seeks to improve the clinical utility of cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) for the evaluation of heart failure (HF) by creating simplified and robust free-breathing, non-ECG gated techniques which can simultaneously assess myocardial function using cine imaging and evaluate myocardial scar using T1 mapping and late gadolinium enhanced imaging in under 5 minutes. HF is highly prevalent affecting 6.2 million patients in the US. If a comprehensive CMR exam could be performed rapidly using a simplified protocol, the diagnostic and prognostic advantages of CMR for the assessment of HF could be extended to a broader range of patients potentially providing more accurate and specific diagnoses of the cause of a patients HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Spinal Muscular Atrophy is a devastating neuromuscular disease caused by insufficient amounts of SMN protein. The basic mechanism of how the reduction in SMN protein leads to the loss of motor neuron function is not known. Using genetic mutations in the SMN gene we can test the function of SMN in cells and mice to determine if splicing defects are the root cause of SMA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Congenital heart disease (CHD) is the most frequent birth defect in the United States, but only few genetic loci have been identified in some CHDs. Genomic sequencing efforts identified many genetic variants as potentially associated with CHD in a patient-specific fashion, but validation has not been trivial, in part due to a likely oligogenic basis for many CHDs, including the severe hypoplastic left heart syndrome. We propose a multi- system platform using Drosophila, with validation in human iPSC and zebrafish models to evaluate CHD gene candidates in health and potentially disease causing, and to build CHD-based gene regulatory networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To-date, depression interventions in low- and middle-income countries have struggled on two fronts: they often fail to leverage the infrastructure of existing chronic care systems to reduce costs and improve quality, and they tend to overlook indirect benefits on broader health outcomes and other individuals. We will evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a stepped-care model of depression treatment integrated into Malawi’s national HIV platform, specifically examining depression symptoms, functional impairment, and overall health of 420 adults with moderate/severe depression. We will achieve this by conducting a stepped-wedge cluster randomized trial in which n=14 health facilities are randomized to implement depression care for patients (n=420) in five steps (2-3 facilities per step) over a 15-month period and measured at three months intervals inclusive of baseline, pre-treatment, post-treatment, 6- and 12-months follow-up—with cost-effectiveness taking into account indirect benefits on comorbid conditions such as HIV and hypertension, and household- level effects such as reduced burden of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Addictive drugs usurp the normal neural machinery for learning and memory to generate maladapted pathological cognitions for compulsive drug seeking. The neural circuits governing drug associative learning interface between the drug-evoked molecular cellular adaptations and drug-seeking behaviors. A mechanistic understanding of these neural circuits is of major significance for advancing our knowledge on drug-induced cognitive states and developing novel therapeutic treatments for substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT This research project is focused on enabling the development of a new class of chemotherapeutic agents based on a protein that is found naturally in the human body. Specifically, the agents are based on ribonuclease, which is an enzyme that can enter human cells and catalyze the cleavage of RNA, leading to cell death. The goal of the project is to obtain fundamental insights into the relationship between the amino-acid sequence of ribonuclease, its three-dimensional structure, and its biological function, and to use those insights to create novel ribonucleases of potential therapeutic utility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunology and microbiology are essential to understanding human health and disease, and therefore obtaining fundamental knowledge of pathogenic microbial agents and the immune response is of paramount importance. This proposal is a request for continued funding of an institutional combined pre- and postdoctoral NRSA Training Program in Immunology and Molecular Pathogenesis at Northwestern. Funded since 1996, this training program remains deeply committed to training the next generation of successful immunologists and microbiologists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research proposal addresses the contribution of B lymphocytes, specialized cells mostly studied for their ability to differentiate into antibody-secreting cells, to the pathogenesis of celiac disease. The proposed studies will shed light on the ability of B lymphocytes to interact with T lymphocytes to promote inflammation and intestinal tissue damage and will test the relevance of B cell therapy as a therapeutic strategy for celiac disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because the geriatric syndromes, such as heart failure and frailty, are a major reason why elders lose the ability to live independently, and result in large individual, family, and societal costs for medical, personal, and custodial care of dependent elders. The proposed project seeks new treatments for ameliorating the geriatric syndromes, and preserving elder independence, based on molecular mechanisms that regulate longevity and diseases of aging. The project will explore one such molecular mechanism, ketone bodies, in deep detail, and attempt to understand how ketone bodies affect specific geriatric syndromes and diseases of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Neutrophils provide a critical defense against infection, but they can also promote tumor progression and metastasis in the aggressive glioblastoma. This study will employ a novel strategy to interrogate neutrophil biology and reprogram tumor-associated neutrophils into antitumor effector cells, which will have implications for developing novel neutrophil-targeted strategies for treating cancer, neutropenia and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human fibroatheroma cap rupture leads to myocardial infarction and sudden death in more than half a million Americans every year. We discovered that microcalcifications within the fibroatheroma can significantly increase the risk of fibroatheroma rupture. We here investigate whether microcalcifications in the cap is an sensitive and specific biomarker of fibroatheroma cap rupture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  A hallmark of HIV infection is intestinal inflammation, which results in irreversible depletion of gut resident CD4+ T cells and loss of intestinal epithelial integrity. This is then believed to cause translocation of gut bacteria into the circulation, chronic systemic immune activation and HIV disease progression. In this proposal we will utilize unique human cohorts in sub-Saharan Africa in combination with in vivo and ex vivo model systems and cutting-edge technologies to investigate the mechanism by which HIV infection results in defects in the gut epithelium and intestinal stem cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The long-term goal is to understand how thermo-sensory stimuli are transformed into adaptive behaviors. By generating a model of these transformations spanning scales from cellular mechanisms to brain wide circuits we can uncover general principles of sensori-motor transformations. This will help understanding neural processing in health and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging is associated with cognitive decline, which can manifest pathologically as age-related dementia and is also the major risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease. There is currently no effective treatment for age-associated dementia and no therapies for Alzheimer’s disease. Our long-standing interest in the meninges and its role in brain function has led us to characterize meningeal lymphatic vessels and to observe many intriguing changes in meningeal immunity with age, and accordingly to raise the questions: are meningeal immune and lymphatic alterations relevant to age-related cognitive decline? If so, could meningeal lymphatic vessels or meningeal immune cells be therapeutically targeted to alleviate age-related dementia and/or Alzheimer’s disease? Here, we will elucidate the role of meningeal vasculature and immunity in age-associated cognitive decline, dementia and mouse models of Alzheimer’s disease using state-of-the-art imaging, surgical and pharmacological techniques in mice, as well as a validation of select findings in human dura specimens from fresh autopsies. Our findings may have significant potential to uncover the etiology of and novel therapeutic targets for age-related dementia and Alzheimer’s disease. ! !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses the molecular origins of chromosome instability, which is prevalent in cancer and reproductive aging. We will test the hypothesis that each person’s unique complement of centromeres contains molecular and genetic information that biases how accurately chromosomes are transmitted from cell to cell. The project is relevant to the NCI mission to discover molecular and genetic origins of human genome stability.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative Thanks to effective treatment, people with HIV (PWH) are living longer and are now exposed to diseases that come along with aging. In sub-Saharan Africa, where most PWH live, less is known about the complex, multiple, interacting diseases that older PWH experience. Our study will describe these diseases of aging in PWH in Ghana, evaluate how they are currently being managed, and build a foundation on which to test a new model of care to treat older PWH to improve both the quantity and quality of live for this group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Narrative: SARS-CoV-2 is a coronavirus and causative agent of COVID-19 that has caused a global pandemic pushing healthcare systems to their limits. To date, there is little understanding how coronaviruses such as SARS-CoV-2 utilize the host lipid network to spread from cell to cell. This project brings together a diverse set of researchers to understand assembly, budding and spread of SARS-CoV-2 from human cells, which should in turn identify novel drug targets in the viral life cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The mission of this new NCI Youth Enjoy Science Training in Health Equity, Highlighting Environmental Inequities, & Growing neighborHood Teachers and Students (YES in THE HEIGHTS) program at the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center (HICCC) is to reduce the cancer burden and cancer health inequities in the HICCC Catchment Area (CA) through training and mentoring of students and teachers to increase the diversity of future cancer researchers. We will continue our commitment to mentoring students in minority-serving institutions, including students from nearby City University of New York (CUNY), the largest minority-serving undergraduate university in the U.S. and have partnered with Math and Science for America (MfA) Program to develop novel training programs for high school students. Across all five years, YES in THE HEIGHTS will mentor, train and engage over 1,125 individuals within the communities we serve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project seeks to reduce the burden of adolescent depression by evaluating in a randomized trial an 8-week mobile health meditation intervention in adolescents reporting elevated depressive symptoms and characterizing psychological, behavioral, and psychophysiological mechanisms of change using innovative ambulatory assessment methods. Long-term, this program of research is designed to test and optimize the feasibility, acceptability, safety, efficacy, and effectiveness of mobile technologies for the treatment and prevention of adolescent depression. The current study will provide essential training and pilot data for a future large-scale randomized clinical trial involving an active control arm and ambulatory assessment of candidate mechanisms of change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Natural killer (NK) cell immunotherapies have been successfully developed for hematologic malignancies; however, their application to solid tumor malignancies faces several challenges. Using a customizable NK cell platform, we propose to design tumor-specific, off-the-shelf NK cell products as novel immunotherapies to treat brain tumors and prostate cancer. Jeffrey Miller, MD, is uniquely qualified to lead the proposed research, both because he has a successful track record of developing novel NK cell immunotherapies for hematologic malignancies and because he has assembled of team of established and new collaborators in NK cell biology and solid tumor malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Relapse is a common problem in B-ALL. In response to PAR-20-292, we will decouple autonomous cell survival at a critical stage of B-cell developmental with an immunoconjugate against the pre-B-cell receptor. Limited in scope to B-ALL stages of developmental arrest, the immunoconjugate (alternatively, antibody-drug conjugate) will exploit normal internalization and transport mechanisms to effect cell killing, but without pan B-cell ablation or imbalanced T-cell activation. The problems we are trying to solve are relapse, opportunistic infections, and off-target toxicities in children and adults with B-ALL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will lead to a better understanding of how host genetics and intestinal bacterial communities interact with each other to modulate inflammation in the developing neonatal gut. New knowledge gained from this research will also contribute to the development of personalized, microbial-based therapies based on underlying genetic predisposition and/or gut microbiome signatures to help maintain gut homeostasis. Such novel, individualized therapies are expected to drastically reduce the incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis in a safe and effective manner by targeting infants at highest risk of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative RNA interference has an ancient role in epigenetic silencing and chromosome stability, independent of its well-known function in post-transcriptional gene regulation through microRNA. We are investigating mechanisms underlying this role in yeast and mammalian cells, and we have discovered deeply conserved pathways that link RNA interference with transcription, replication and quiescence. Interaction with the transcriptional co-activator BRD4, and with other epigenetic regulators, leads to genome instability with implications for targeted therapies in cancer and autoimmune disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative: Breast cancer is identified in ultrasound scans on the basis of telltale image features, including the presence of “shadows” behind lesions due to their ultrasound absorption. This shadowing can be difficult to detect and obscured by variations in image brightness from benign causes. We propose to construct and test a new ultrasound system to robustly image ultrasound absorption for better classification of breast lesions. This system will be evaluated in tissue-like materials and in mastectomy breast tissue samples.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The wasting syndrome cachexia is a major determinant of mortality in pancreatic cancer. We have found that pancreatic cancer markedly alters liver metabolism. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A novel antigen discovery approach will be applied for comprehensive profiling of temporal evolution of the humoral immune response in patients with Lyme disease differentiating between two treatment outcomes: return to health/show minor symptoms or Post Treatment Lyme Disease Syndrome (PTLDS) - a poorly understood condition with a clinical presentation affecting 10-15% of Lyme disease patients. Here, a longitudinal, prospectively collected patient cohort will be utilized to predict and validate which Borrelia burgdorferi and human protein antigens are associated with the progression from confirmed acute disease, through treatment to PTLDS. By identifying which antigens are immunogenic, it is sought to develop a set of immunologic biomarkers for predicting progression to PTLDS early in the acute phase of the disease thus providing a window of opportunity for early intervention and symptom management.

This project will investigate the role of the virus in determining the symptomatic severity of HSV-2 infection, information that can ultimately be used to improve treatments for viral infection and to reduce viral transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulation of myelopoiesis can be either cell-intrinsic or cell-extrinsic, however, these two mechanisms are not necessarily mutually exclusive and the cause of aberrant myelopoiesis in certain diseases is not always clear. Interestingly, we show that a cell-extrinsic emergency myelopoiesis progressively develops when the inner mitochondrial membrane transporter ABCB7 is conditionally deleted in differentiating B cells in the bone marrow. As ABCB7 levels are decreased due to mis-splicing when the splicing factor SF3B1 is mutated, we hypothesize that patients with SF3B1-mutated myelodysplastic disease may not be strictly cell-intrinsic, but instead is mediated by decreased expression of ABCB7 in B-lineage precursor cells.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women in South Asia, including India, often migrate from their husbands’ home back to their parents’ home in pregnancy and for delivery, which may have implications for maternal and child heath, yet this phenomenon is understudied. We will conduct a multisite longitudinal study in India to understand and describe this phenomenon (which we call temporary childbirth migration) and measure its impact on infant and maternal health, with a primary outcome of preterm birth.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) test is considered highly valuable for early detection of diabetes but is currently not recommended for use among persons living with HIV (PLHIV) due to their lower hemoglobin levels. This study will identify appropriate HbA1c diagnostic thresholds for strata of hemoglobin and markers of inflammation, insulin resistance, and immuno-virologic status, in addition to evaluating an alternative glycated test, fructosamine, with no hemoglobin limitation. Findings will inform the development of guidelines for the optimal use of glycated testing tools among PLHIV and others with low hemoglobin in the general population.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will focus on developing a chatbot that using artificial intelligence to promote HIV testing among men who have sex with men (MSM) in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia (My). Once developed and adequately tested, the new chatbot (named MyTestBot?) will be embedded into a social networking app selected by MSM to create an mHealth intervention to provide MSM with real-time HIV testing-related information, motivation, and behavioral skills. MyTestBot? will provide culturally tailored messages to promote HIV testing in MSM that does not rely on intensive human resources to develop and maintain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is a primary neuroendocrine carcinoma of the skin; a highly aggressive cancer with a 40% 2-year mortality rate. Virus-negative MCC is caused by excessive sunlight exposure resulting in ultraviolet induced damage to the genome while virus-positive MCC is caused by integration of the MCPyV viral DNA into the host cell genome with expression of a truncated form of Large T antigen and an intact Small T antigen. We propose that the distinct mechanisms of oncogenesis in virus-negative-MCC and virus-positive-MCC provides us with the unique opportunity to use orthogonal methodologies to gain a clearer insight into the oncogenesis of MCC and other cancer types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study employs a participatory systems science approach to increase organizational readiness, strengthen collaborations, and enhance efficacy to implement a cardiovascular disease risk reduction evidence-based program, Heart Matters, in rural North Carolina. Prior feasibility and efficacy testing of Heart Matters demonstrated improved blood pressure, physical activity, and social support for African American adults at risk for cardiovascular disease in this setting. The overall objective of this study is to train 18 organizations and establish a tested evidence-based program implementation blueprint that is sustainable beyond external funding and transferable to end-users.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Precision nutrition approaches aim to move away from a one-size fits all approach to identify individual-level dietary and nutritional intake for optimal health by accounting for individual variability in genes, phenotype, environment, and lifestyle for each person (NIH) – i.e., tailoring nutrition interventions and/or recommendations to individuals by accounting for the complex nutritional ecology reflecting the interaction of a complex system. The 2020-30 Strategic Plan for NIH Nutrition Research, developed by the NIH Nutrition Research Task Force, identifies a key need to produce a nutrition workforce that is trained in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) to solve the most pressing problems in nutrition and health, by applying novel methods and working in multidisciplinary teams. We propose to leverage our existing strengths and initiatives at Cornell to implement a novel program to train the next generation of scientists in the domains of AI and precision nutrition to address the future needs for the nutrition workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NIH SuRE Project Narrative  This NIH SuRE proposal aims to develop highly selective metal catalyzed carbon carbon bond formation reactions that will lead to efficient synthesis of novel selenium, sulfur, and oxygen-containing heterocycles with rich biological activities. Further elaboration of this chemistry will likely allow the first enantioselective synthesis of very important classes of heterocycles such as biselenoflavonoids, bithioflavonoids and bioactive biflavonoids, potential small molecule therapeutics for Alzheimer’s disease. This SuRE project is expected to significantly enhance and expand the research capacity towards a sustainable research excellence that actively involves underrepresented minority students in funded research at WSSU, a HBCU.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety and mood disorders are the most common mental health problem in adolescents, and are often associated with disruptions in both emotional processing and decision making. Widespread exposure to light from electronic devices before bedtime is a possible risk factor for developing psychiatric disorders. Using a translational mouse model, this project will explore the effects of altered patterns of light exposure on amygdala plasticity and emotion-related behavior in adolescent mice, which will potentially lead to new complementary strategies to advance health and well-being in human adolescents.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative To stem increasing rates of HIV among gay and bisexual men in Central-Eastern Europe, we will establish the feasibility, acceptability, and early efficacy of a culturally adapted evidence-based program to introduce pre- exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) into Romania’s healthcare practice. PrEP Romania, a hybrid in-person + mHealth PrEP uptake and adherence program, aims to empower gay and bisexual men and their healthcare system to adopt PrEP and support adherence. Findings can inform evidence-based PrEP rollout in other Central-Eastern European countries with similar levels of unpreparedness for biomedical prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance The course Origins of Renal Physiology is highly relevant to biomedical research and the advancement of human health. The number of annual participants (up to 36; 25 of whom will be funded through this grant) represents approximately 10% of the annual “class” of renal fellows in the United States, permitting the course to have a significant impact on the training of fellows nationally. Course faculty include clinical nephrologists and investigators who guide participants in performing experiments to elucidate kidney function including glomerular filtration, proximal tubule, thick ascending limb, and collecting duct transport, water homeostasis, cellular trafficking of transporter proteins, and the structure-function of transporter proteins such as aquaporins, urea carriers, renal stone disease, ENaC and the Na/K/2Cl cotransporter, and participants will also receive relevant case study-based training in Responsible Conduct in Research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Viruses have been engineered into invaluable tools for research and vehicles for therapeutics, but none effectively reach neuroimmune cells. The Zika virus offers a host of mechanisms to selectively target and suppress the intrinsic and innate immune responses of microglia, the predominant immune cell. We propose the domestication of Zika into a neuroimmune selective vector and a platform for tailored immunomodulation. The bioactivity can be harnessed into root cause therapies for the treatment of neuroinflammatory and degenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The gallbladder is the bacterial reservoir for enteric pathogens such as Listeria monocytogenes and Salmonella Typhi, which are responsible for significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. However, very little is known about how enteric pathogens colonize the gallbladder. Experiments in this proposal will define the gallbladder as a replicative niche and identify the bacterial genes required for replication in this organ, which will uncover potential therapeutic targets to reduce colonization and transmission of enteric pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A low-carbohydrate ketogenic diet replicates some of the biological features of fasting or dietary restriction, and like these has recently been shown to improve lifespan and age-related memory decline in laboratory mice. Ketogenic diets are also being investigated in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease, although the mechanism by which it might work is unclear. This project will determine the specific mechanisms of ketogenic diet that improve memory both in normal aging and in Alzheimer's disease models, in order to create new therapies that target both the features of Alzheimer's disease and of the aging brain in which it occurs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative NICHD established the Global Network for Women’s and Children’s Health Research to improve health outcomes for women and children in low- and lower middle-income countries (LMICs) by researching sustainable, cost-effective health interventions and strengthening research infrastructure and public health intervention capabilities in LMICs. A Data Coordinating Center (DCC) provides essential expertise for a large multi-country research network by ensuring rigorous, harmonized standards for study design, development, data collection, and data analyses and high-quality implementation across a range of diverse settings. The DCC also coordinates communications, supports the regulatory approval process, procures study equipment and supplies and provides logistical support across diverse research sites, both inside and outside the Global Network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes the common STI gonorrhea, for which there are dwindling treatment options and no protective vaccine. N. gonorrhoeae has the striking ability to co-opt human metal-binding proteins, normally meant to restrict bacterial growth, as a source of essential metals. This project seeks to understand the structure and function relationships in four outer membrane transporters produced by N. gonorrhoeae during infection of relevant host cells, to determine the metal environment sensed by N. gonorrhoeae during infection of these cells, and to explore whether inhibitory compounds or monoclonal antibodies block these critical metal acquisition functions, which can point to new therapies against this common infectious disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common cardiac arrhythmia, affecting 2-3% of the US population, and existing therapies focus on management of AF, without addressing underlying causes. Inflammation, vascular leak, and consequent tissue edema are widely associated with AF; yet their role in precipitation atrial arrhythmias remains unclear. In this proposal, we will employ a cutting edge experimental toolkit ranging from the single molecule scale to the whole animal to investigate the mechanisms by which inflammation-induced vascular leak elevates AF risk and develop novel antiarrhythmic drugs that target the mechanistic roots of AF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The emergence of resistance to multiple antimicrobial agents by pathogenic bacteria has become a significant global public health threat. The Gram-negative bacterium Acinetobacter baumannii has evolved in the last 40 years from being a low-virulence pathogen of modest significance to become a leading cause of antibiotic- resistant infections worldwide, causing life-threatening infections of multiple tissues. The bacterium is a scourge of intensive care units and is responsible for about a million infections per year globally. Clinical outcomes are poor, with mortality rates as high as 70% reported. Therefore, multi-drug resistant A. baumannii infections present an enormous ongoing challenge and the development of novel approaches to treat these pathogens is an area of acute medical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Rationale Significant knowledge gaps remain regarding a thorough understanding of HIV replication. Many fundamental aspects of this process, including virus particle assembly, remain understudied, and will be investigated in this study using sophisticated, cutting-edge biophysical technologies. The basic science investigations of virus assembly will aid in addressing crucial knowledge gaps as well as help inform efforts toward next-generation HIV therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After an initial infection with many pathogens, the immune system provides protection against re-infection with the same pathogen. However, infection of the human female reproductive tract with Chlamydia trachomatis provides limited protection against reinfection, and reoccurring infections can cause permanent damage and infertility. The goal of this proposal is to 1) determine why the cells of the immune system fail to provide protection against C. trachomatis, and 2) reprogram these faulty cells using new vaccine approaches to provide protection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research directly addresses a long-acknowledged scientific gap: the absence of rigorous evidence regarding the causal relationship between unintended pregnancy and childbirth and adverse maternal health outcomes in the US. This longitudinal observational study will utilize a prospective design, novel comparison groups, and a new validated prospective pregnancy preferences measure that moves beyond conceptually limited “unintended” or “intended” labels, to rigorously address issues of confounding, recall bias, and measurement misclassification that have undermined the validity of prior investigations. Evidence to establish whether adverse maternal health outcomes stem from the intention status of pregnancies – independent of underlying social and contextual factors – can facilitate the development of appropriately focused efforts to reduce maternal morbidity and mortality and promote reproductive autonomy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative The goal of this project is to develop a new technology platform to measure tens to potentially hundreds of different cancer biomarkers from a single fingerstick of blood collected by patients at home as they begin a new treatment. Our team succeeded in quantifying two distinct nucleic acid targets in such specimens for patients beginning treatment for metastatic castrate resistant prostate cancer. A substantial increase in the number of targets is now needed to validate measurements and to address the diverse genetic landscape of the disease, and could enable the prediction of drug response so that treatment regimens can be rapidly and finely tuned to enhance efficacy and increase survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prevalence of menthol cigarette (MC) use in the U.S. has reached an all-time high and directly contributes to furthering tobacco-related health disparities. The proposed research will be the first to focus on examining the potential impact of menthol flavoring in cigarettes on biomarkers of systemic inflammation as a subclinical indicator of CVD risk – directly targeting the FDA Center for Tobacco Products (CTP) research priority to understand the cardiovascular and inflammatory health effects of tobacco additives. Research findings are expected to provide the FDA with comprehensive scientific evidence for the development of MC regulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Black women are 2 to 3 times more likely to have pregnancy-related complications leading to maternal death compared to white women nationwide. In response, the State of California passed two bills requiring that all clinicians receive continuing education courses that address implicit bias and mistreatment in effort to improve the quality of care provided to Black women during pregnancy and delivery. This research will be among the first to refine and pilot test a racial equity training intervention for prenatal care clinicians in effort to improve their implicit racial attitudes and beliefs, increase their awareness of causes of racism and health disparities, and enhance their motivation and self-efficacy to use tools and strategies, thereby shifting the healthcare culture and environment.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Reactivation of a persistent infection caused by the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma gondii can result in fatal toxoplasmosis in immune-compromised patients and recurrent ocular disease in otherwise healthy people. Persistent Toxoplasma infection has defied elimination with current treatments. This project will identify new parasite components that are critical for long term persistence of the parasite and thus uncover novel targets for preventing systemic and ocular toxoplasmosis in at-risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromatin remodeling complexes are dysregulated in more than 20% of human malignancies, including adult and pediatric cancers. In this study, we will leverage the low somatic mutation frequencies in rhabdoid tumor and alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma to mechanistically interrogate how chromatin remodeling drives both therapeutic sensitivity and resistance. We will use the information to identify novel therapeutic vulnerabilities that increase the penetrance of therapeutic response and restore chemotherapeutic sensitivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lyme disease is a tick transmitted infection with upwards of 470,000 people diagnosed each year in the United States. If untreated or misdiagnosed, the agent of Lyme disease, Borrelia burgdorferi, can persist for long periods of time and can be difficult to treat; thus, understanding how initial infection is regulated may yield better therapeutic or preventative strategies. In this application, we will study how a regulatory protein, important for infection in mammals, directly regulates both DNA and RNA to augment the infectious and pathogenic potential of B. burgdorferi.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic non-healing skin ulcers are a source of considerable suffering worldwide, particularly in rapidly growing aging populations. Why skin becomes fragile and heals poorly as we age remains unclear, although current research indicates that a major reason may reside in defective “stem cells” in skin that normally fuel its renewal and regeneration in order to maintain healthful and youthful function and appearance. Our findings indicate that stem cell pathways involving cell metabolism, DNA regulation, and cell-cell communication may underlie defective wound healing. Our research proposal is designed to explore this hypothesis with the overarching goal of developing new approaches that will pave the way for stem cell-directed combined therapies that will accelerate wound healing and potentially even repair and restore age-damaged skin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Considering the rates of elder abuse in the Unites States are growing and many victims have depression and are not receiving care, we propose a randomized controlled trial (N=140) of Tele-PROTECT compared to a video-delivered depression education (DepEd) intervention to test the effectiveness of our behavioral therapy (Tele-PROTECT) specifically targeting older adult victims of abuse. The goal of Tele-PROTECT is to reduce symptoms of depression and support empowerment to take steps to ensure safety for older adults living with abuse and depression, to be delivered via video in English and Spanish, in tandem with the participant’s elder abuse services. The proposal will identify potential barriers and supports for implementation, with the ultimate goal of disseminating Tele-PROTECT nationally to address the widespread needs of this vulnerable older adult population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early adolescents diagnosed with asthma have difficulties consistently performing disease self-management behaviors, placing them at elevated risk for morbidity and impaired quality of life. The goal of this project is to address the critical need for improving health outcomes in early adolescents with poorly controlled asthma by conducting a randomized controlled trial of a novel intervention, delivered via smartphones, that aims to facilitate helpful caregiver support as early adolescents develop and master asthma self-management behaviors. If successful, our smartphone-based intervention has long-term potential in improving health outcomes for a large number of early adolescents diagnosed with asthma.

PHR: This application is for the fourth competitive renewal of our training program, now entitled “Training in HIV Pathogenesis, Vaccination and Cure”. Over the last 15 years the program has trained 79 distinguished young scientists, the great majority of whom are continuing in research. HIV/AIDS continues to be a severe health burden in the US and globally; experts on HIV/AIDS trained by our program are well positioned to lead the effort to reduce this disease burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: The goal of this application is to pursue our seminal findings by assessing the specific mechanisms that underlie the anti-cancer effects of thioredoxin (Trx)1 and Trx2 down-regulation in mice. We will investigate whether reduced Trx in the cytosol and mitochondria enhance apoptosis/autophagy, which reduce damaged cells and cellular damages leading to less genomic instability. The changes in these pathways could lead to a reduction in age-related spontaneous tumor development in mice.  This study is the first project to test the beneficial effects of reduced antioxidant in both the cytosol and mitochondria on age-related spontaneous tumor development using unique and well-defined knockout mouse models. The outcome of this project could provide critical information in understanding the cellular basis for cancer prevention and therapy in the elderly population; many of whom have an increased risk of various age-related diseases, especially cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE St. Louis encephalitis virus (SLEV) is a re-emerging mosquito-borne flavivirus that causes a spectrum of manifestations in people ranging from febrile illness to encephalitis and death. To circumvent limitations of existing models, the goal of this project is to develop immunocompetent mouse models of SLEV using recombinant collaborative cross mice to recapitulate the spectrum of human disease outcomes and to understand virus kinetics, tropism, pathology, and innate immune responses that associate with protection from neurologic disease. The outcome of this project will the development of new human-relevant mouse models of SLEV which can be further used to study the spectrum of pathogenesis, define virus-host interactions and host genetic determinants of susceptibility and severity, test interventions like therapeutics and candidate vaccines, and rapidly adapt to model human disease for other new or re-emerging encephalitic flaviviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with chronic kidney disease frequently develop heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, which increases hospitalizations and shortens lifespan. The circulating metabolome, which constitutes small molecules that can modulate tissue function, is altered in patients with chronic kidney disease. To shed light onto possible new treatments for heart failure in patients with chronic kidney disease, we will study whether an altered metabolome in patients with chronic kidney disease contributes to heart failure with preserved ejection fraction in this high risk population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks to illuminate the cardiogenic cellular hierarchy and the gene regulatory networks that determine the origins and fates of distinct cardiovascular progenitor cells during heart development. Results from these studies will yield new insights into how disrupted cardiovascular regulatory networks lead to congenital heart disease and how they may be modified to develop treatments to improve patient outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use in pregnant women has increased over the past decade, highlighting the importance of efforts to understand how environmental and other exposures during pregnancy affect brain development and child outcomes. The PRELUDE consortium for the HEALthy Brain and Child Development study will recruit 2720 pregnant women in the 2nd and 3rd trimester and follow their children to age 10, using neuroimaging, behavioral assessments, EEG, biosample collection, and assessments of parent-child interaction and the home environment. This research will lead to greater understanding of factors affecting early childhood brain development, allowing targeted interventions and improved outcomes for mother-child dyads.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While it is clear that LEMD2 L13R mutation results in cardiomyopathy, little is known as to the specific role of LEMD2 in cardiomyocytes and mechanisms by which LEMD2 L13R mutation leads to cardiomyopathy. Proposed studies are aimed at understanding the function of LEMD2 in the heart at the molecular, cellular, and physiological levels, and gaining insights into mechanisms by which LEMD2 mutation causes cardiomyopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer (CRC) and (EAC) account for the majority of gastrointestinal cancer deaths but can be prevented with screening. For the screening tests to be most effective they need to be optimized for individuals at low-risk and high-risk for CRC and EAC; however, the current methods for CRC and EAC risk prediction have low accuracy. We propose to create an integrated and highly collaborative Biomarker Characterization Center to discover, validate and develop into clinic-ready assays, tests for accurate CRC and EAC risk prediction. We further propose to discover and validate tests based on simple brushing samples of the esophagus that can detect a nascent cancer condition called high grade dysplasia (HGD) and early EAC in people with Barretts esophagus (BE), a high risk precancerous condition for EAC, which will decrease deaths from EAC and the burden of BE surveillance.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Uncontrolled hypertension, the leading risk factor for death, is exceedingly common among people living with HIV (PLWH) in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA). Despite the pressing need to develop hypertension care models for PLWH in SSA, few effective interventions targeting this population exist. Using an implementation science approach, this project will adapt an evidence-based hypertension intervention, proven effective in other settings, for integration within HIV clinics to improve hypertension control among Tanzanians living with HIV.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persons with HIV have a higher risk of developing metabolic and cardiovascular diseases, which are leading causes of mortality among residents of low and middle-income countries (LMICs). Weight gain is common after starting integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI)-based antiretroviral therapy, which is increasingly being used for HIV treatment in LMICs. This study will assess the prevalence of cardiometabolic disease among persons with HIV who gain weight on INSTI-based regimens in LMICs, and the metabolic and lipid pathways contributing to weight gain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We will use multiscale all-atom molecular dynamics simulations as a `computational microscope,' to provide insights into the dynamics of the HIV-1 envelope protein (Env) that are unattainable with current experimental techniques. Together with top flight experimentalists, we will develop and simulate a series of models to explore the dynamics of Env as well as its interactions with its receptor, co-receptors and the cell glycocalyx, under physiological conditions. In addition, we will use advanced simulation techniques to optimize immunogen design as well as provide critical information about hitherto unseen therapeutic vulnerabilities in Env.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The International Workshop on HIV Pediatrics is the only meeting entirely devoted to research in prevention and treatment of HIV infections in infants, children, and adolescents, making it the premier forum for the world’s leading researchers. By bringing together experts from different disciplines with presentations in a variety of formats, the meeting offers a collaborative setting where the latest developments are presented and junior investigators are supported and encouraged to continue their scientific work in this field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We have developed a network of adult and pediatric medical research institutions to form The Ohio State University Clinical Center (OSU CC). In a multidisciplinary collaboration with other clinical centers in the Consortium for the Study of Chronic Pancreatitis, Diabetes and Pancreatic Cancer Clinical Centers (CSCPDPC- CCs) (U01), the OSU CC has helped developed 4 major observational studies during the initial funding cycle that address research gaps in our understanding of the exocrine pancreas. Specifically, the OSU CC seeks to confirm and validate proposed diagnostic biomarkers in chronic pancreatitis, pancreaticogenic diabetes and pancreas cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes, chronic pancreatitis, and pancreatic cancer are common and inter-related diseases that require better approaches to diagnosis and treatment. The Mayo Clinic team is an active participant in multiple CPDPC initiatives, with recruitment into the PROCEED and NOD cohorts, plus the DETECT study. By gaining new knowledge through our contributions, the CPDPC will lead to clinical advances in these pancreas diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in any gene important for normal immune function can lead to a variety of manifestations of primary immunodeficiency (PID), yet our ability to diagnose and cure these mutations is limited. Beyond sequencing, we do not have a way to functionally discern a PID patient's causative mutation from the thousands of benign natural sequence variants. This work will utilize advanced novel CRISPR gene editing techniques to recreate and directly test the influences of individual variants in primary human cells in order to provide a mechanistic understanding of PID-associated mutations, new diagnostic tools, and novel strategies for non-viral gene correction therapy to benefit patients with genetic diseases of the immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Development of effective therapies for obesity have been hindered by our limited understanding of the mechanisms regulating food ingestion and weight. This fellowship proposal tests how central neurotensin circuitry may be leveraged to reduce feeding and increase physical activity so as to support weight loss. Via this research the applicant will learn state-of-the art techniques to reveal the neural mechanisms regulating energy balance, which he can leverage throughout his career to understand the cause and treatment of obesity and other neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Current cholesterol treatment guideline put atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk assessment at the center of decision-making for initiating and dosing of lipid-lowering therapies; however, there remain limitations and controversies regarding how efficiently this guideline directs medication to those who will receive a large absolute ASCVD risk reduction benefit. Our study will draw on large, contemporary, and racial/ethnically diverse data sources to develop more refined ASCVD risk assessment approaches, help direct treatment to ethnic subgroups and groups with a high burden of adverse SDOH who have a high ASCVD risk, and ultimately, improve cardiovascular outcomes and narrow cardiovascular health inequities.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project narrative In sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), where need and resource constraint are highest, sub-optimal antiretroviral treatment (ART) retention threatens to derail global HIV epidemic control efforts. Through a quasi-experimental, pre-post designed test of an mHealth innovation and subsequent scale-up in two, high-volume, public ART clinics with over 35,000 ART clients in Malawi, we aim to demonstrate that interactive, two-way texting (2WT) can increase ART retention in a routine setting while providing distinct advantages in terms of data quality, costs, and reduced healthcare worker burden over routine retention efforts. User-centered assessment of successful 2WT integration into the existing electronic medical records system facilitates transfer from research to routine practice, enabling scale-up of this mHealth intervention to improve ART retention across Malawi and SSA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the multifunctional RNA-binding protein EWSR1 is associated with the neurodegenerative disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Lou Gehrig’s Disease) as well as rare pediatric sarcomas (Ewing sarcoma). EWSR1 contains an intrinsically disordered, low complexity region implicated in its pathological functions. This project is relevant to NIH’s mission because defining the mechanistic and structural details of EWSR1 functions is the first step toward development of effective, targeted therapies for these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  In order to combat infections and reduce antimicrobial resistance, it is essential to detect and characterize bacterial/fungal susceptibility to antimicrobials in the early stages of infections to reduce the inappropriate use of antimicrobials and the rate of death. A stimulated Raman scattering imaging - wide-field fluorescence in situ hybridization system will be developed to enable single cell level antimicrobial susceptibility and identity test within 2 hours from fresh sample to final report.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The successful completion of this project will lead development of mouse model of glaucoma to aid insights into molecular pathways that cause trabecular meshwork dysfunction, elevation of intraocular pressure and neurodegeneration in glaucoma, a leading cause of irreversible vision loss. Furthermore, successful completion of this project will provide mouse model to develop novel treatment strategies for glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eosinophilic allergic mucin chronic rhinosinusitis (EMRS) is a debilitating chronic rhinosinusitis subtype that disproportionally burdens sociodemographic minorities, who often present with more advanced disease, have worse post-surgical treatment outcomes, and higher rates of morbidity such as facial bone deformities and vision changes. The etiology behind the disparities in EMRS presentation and outcomes are not explained by clinical disease severity alone, leaving important questions about how to reduce disease burden unanswered until researchers understand the multiple factors that influence EMRS treatment outcomes. The results of this research will determine the important multidimensional factors that predict EMRS treatment outcomes and will help inform clinical practice recommendations and interventions to improve care and reduce disparities for EMRS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Trimethylamine N-oxide (TMAO) is a common dietary derived metabolite that has emerged as a central driver of cardiovascular disease. But efforts to leverage this pathway therapeutically have been impeded by a lack of a clear mechanistic understanding of TMAO action. Therefore, we propose to define how TMAO causes atherosclerosis by defining TMAO’s direct effects on its only known receptor and elucidating the TMAO atherogenic stress response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Data Coordinating Center (DCC) will enable the dietary biomarker development centers (DBDCs) Consortium to bring together multidisciplinary experts to enhance the field of dietary biomarker development by providing administrative, biostatistics, data management, self-service analytics, interactive reporting, and data analysis support to identify biomarkers of dietary intake. Specifically, the DCC will 1) provide a robust administrative management structure that enhances communication and improves the DBDC’s productivity and quality, 2) provide data harmonization, transfers, integration, processing, and management, 3) develop self-service analytics to generate data summaries, dynamic/interactive reporting, and analysis support for integrated biomarker validation, and 4) communicate and disseminate knowledge within and beyond the Consortium. Our team’s nationally recognized expertise in data management, harmonization, and coordination of large networks, and our experience in biomarker research uniquely positions the DCRI to provide all of the services and support required by the DBDC’s Consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain functions arise from complex networks of many different types of cells connected in neural circuits. The goal of this UM1 project is to map the identities and compositions of the many different kinds of cells in various regions of the human brain. Determining the molecular properties and locations of cells from a diverse population of human brain samples will aid in our understanding of normal human brain functions and the underlying mechanisms of a variety of human neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer (PCa) is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in men. Currently, there is a significant unmet need for identifying men at initial diagnosis who will ultimately progress to metastatic, lethal disease. This project investigates the combination of clinically translatable imaging technologies: diffusion basis spectral imaging (DBSI) MRI and matrix assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI) histologic molecular imaging to identify “imageable” biomarkers associated with poor outcomes in men being evaluated for prostate cancer at initial diagnosis. This proposal characterizes the contribution of a protein that regulates gene expression to the biology pancreatic cancer. The insight gained from these studies will real novel mechanisms contributing to this highly chemoresistant disease and may provide new avenues for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New targeted anticancer agents are urgently needed for the treatment of Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)-positive lymphomas, chief among them Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), the most common lymphoma worldwide. VK-2019, a potent EBNA1 inhibitor, is selectively toxic to EBV-infected tumor cells, but not to EBV- negative cells in vitro and in vivo. A phase I clinical study with patients with advanced EBV-positive nasopharyngeal carcinoma demonstrated that VK-2019 exhibits a favorable pharmacokinetics and safety profile. In this Phase Ib study, we propose to confirm the safety and tolerability of the drug, obtain a preliminary signal of anti-tumor efficacy, study the effects of VK-2019 treatment on EBV and cellular gene expression and on the tumor microenvironment, in EBV-positive DLBCL patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of neoplasia and death resulting from this disease remains a significant public health challenge globally, and it has become increasingly evident that immune-based approaches will have a substantial impact in our understanding of cancer prevention, diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment. Pre-doctoral training provided by the Tumor Immunology Training Program (TITP) is directly pertinent to public health. The continued primary mission of the TITP is to educate, train, and prepare the next generation of talented scientists with the concepts, knowledge, and skills of fundamental and translational tumor immunology, which provides the necessary foundation to develop and advance innovative approaches to human cancer biology and therapy.
