IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the success of immunotherapies and cellular therapies, most aggressive lymphomas will relapse with no consensus on the next best treatment strategy. We found recently that photothermal therapy with a toll-like receptor 9 agonists coated branched gold nanoparticle in a murine lymphoma model had (1) improved local and systemic anti-lymphoma T cell responses, (2) increased mature dendritic cells populations in lymph nodes, and (3) increased memory T cells populations in the spleen and untreated tumors. In this proposal, we will first further characterize the immune response of our photothermal therapy platform in various B cell lymphoma models, then combine our platform with T cell engaging immunotherapies such as checkpoint inhibitors and bispecific antibodies, and lastly examine a subcutaneous lymphoma lysate/nanoparticle mixture photothermal therapy platform for patients without easily accessible diseased lymph nodes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) and other metabolic diseases are becoming increasingly common among youth. Although obesity is a strong risk factor for metabolic dysfunction, only a fraction of youth with obesity develops T2D, suggesting factors beyond obesity are also at play. In this proposal, we will leverage an ongoing, longitudinal, pre-birth cohort study to examine variability in pancreas composition (fat fraction) and size (volume) in adolescence according to individual traits and prior nutrition/growth factors, and whether these pancreatic markers are predictive of dysglycemia onset during puberty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain’s lymphatic system regulates fluid homeostasis and removes toxic macromolecules in brains. The goal of this project is to investigate how the brain lymphatic system can be rejuvenated to treat neurological disorders such as craniosynostosis and Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The outcome will help develop new therapeutic strategies against these devastating neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Implantable neuroelectronic interfaces have the potential to treat drug-resistant neurological diseases, yet traditional electrode implantation requires invasive open-skull surgery and damages the brain. The pro- posed research aims to address these limitations by developing minimally invasive endovascular neural interfaces capable of monitoring and modulating neural activity. This neuroelectronic platform can be read- ily extended to the detection and treatment of many other models of chronic and progressive neurological diseases, such as Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, epilepsy, and stroke, paving the way to clini- cal translation to the treatment of these conditions in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This research addresses the urgent need to assess the neurodevelopmental effects of chemicals on public health. By developing a high-throughput zebrafish screening platform, it offers a cost-effective and efficient alternative to conventional methods. Ultimately, the findings from this study have the potential to inform policies, enhance risk assessment, and guide the development of safer chemical alternatives, thereby reducing illness and disability associated with neurotoxic chemical exposures and promoting overall health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Neurodevelopmental disorders (NDs, including autism, intellectual disabilities, attention-deficit/hyperactivity and others) affect at ~15% of people, appear in childhood/early adulthood, and cannot be cured. Certain pollutants and industrial chemicals cause NDs but predicting whether a chemical will impair brain development is very difficult. Our project will develop assays to identify chemicals that cause NDs; the assays will utilize neurons and related brain cells derived from human stem cells (a type of stem cells derived from adults - no embryos are hurt in the process), will be more predictive than current tests, and will reduce the use of animals in medical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative There is an unexplained antagonistic relationship between alcohol use and physical activity, which begins during emerging adulthood. Studies examining the impact of such health-compromising (alcohol use) and health-enhancing (physical activity) behaviors on neurophysiological mechanisms are sparse, and the current study will examine these co-occurring health behaviors on cardiovascular and neural pathways central to self- regulation. The goal is to inform addiction vulnerability and identify brain-body mechanisms that may serve as targets for neuroscience-informed treatment interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Approximately 75% of pancreatic cancer patients who undergo primary tumor resection will develop metastases, and nearly 50% of early postoperative metastases will occur in the liver. We discovered that inflammation from infectious complications during surgery, like sepsis, can influence the ability of pancreatic cancer cells to form liver metastases. In this project, I will determine how sepsis impacts the liver to uncover new therapeutic targets that can block the tumor-promoting effects of perioperative inflammation in order to reduce liver metastasis among resected pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endophthalmitis, a bacterial infection inside the eye, can quickly lead to permanent vision loss. Bacteria need iron to survive, so immune cells may overload themselves with iron to keep it away from them. This proposal examines whether iron chelation could be an effective anti-bacterial and anti-inflammatory treatment for endophthalmitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Soil-transmitted gastrointestinal helminths (e.g., the human-infective threadworm Strongyloides stercoralis and hookworms in the genera Necator and Ancylostoma) infect over one billion individuals globally, with the burden of disease disproportionately impacting disadvantaged communities with poor sanitation infrastructure. Soil- transmitted helminths rely upon sensory cues to navigate various environments, participate in host seeking, and complete their parasitic life cycle. This proposal seeks to define the role of ambient oxygen as a neuronally detected chemosensory cue in S. stercoralis (i.e., a uniquely genetically tractable soil-transmitted helminth) and identify molecular pathways in the parasite oxygen-sensing machinery vulnerable to chemotherapeutic targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer is an aggressive disease that is frequently diagnosed in late stages after metastasis has occurred, highlighting the need for a better understanding of early transformation events and tumorigenic mechanisms. Completion of this research proposal will help address this gap in knowledge by revealing the functional contribution of a de novo expressed gastric protein, Gastrokine 2, which is hypothesized to play a tumor suppressive role in pancreatic tumor progression. Knowledge gained from studies could impact biomarker development with the potential for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative It is of key interest in cancer research to create ways to reprogram tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) from a pro-tumor (M2-like) to an anti-tumor (M1-like) phenotype and thereby induce immune effects that can bring about tumor regression. However, at present, there are no methods that can enable physicians to rationally and selectively reprogram TAMs for therapeutic purposes. In this proposal, we are optimizing an off- the-shelf nanodrug that carries in vitro-transcribed mRNA to genetically reprogram immunosuppressive macrophages (M2-like TAMs) to express tumor-clearing (M1-like) phenotypes as a new approach to treat otherwise incurable ovarian cancer and, ultimately, other types of malignancies as well.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: With NIH/NCI SBIR support, CivaTech Oncology developed CivaSheet®, the only directional intraoperative radiation device to deliver a curable radiation dose to microinvasive disease at the surgical margin while protecting healthy tissues. Phase I/II clinical trials for pancreatic cancer demonstrate no device related toxicity and 0% local recurrence. Controlling localized pancreatic cancer is the first step to providing better outcomes for these difficult to treat patients. To enable patients the best possible outcomes, we request funds to expand patient access to CivaSheet by evaluating cost outcomes, applying for reimbursement coverage, and engineering support to scale manufacturing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Currently, data are not available that can inform adolescent and adult women on recommendations for beverage intake pattern(s) that aid in achieving optimal bladder health. We aim to identify best beverage intake pattern(s) for preventing lower urinary tract symptoms across the life course by using an innovative mobile device application for collecting information in real time, along with a more traditional population-based survey study. Ultimately, we want to know how adolescent and adult women can optimize intake patterns to be most conducive to a truly healthy bladder, with lowest risk for developing lower urinary tract symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall This application proposes the continuation of the Biomolecular Multimodal Imaging Center (BIOMIC) at Vanderbilt University, a Tissue Mapping Center associated with the Human BioMolecular Atlas Program (HuBMAP). The mission of BIOMIC is to build a platform of integrated technologies for imaging and molecular analysis that enables the construction of comprehensive 3-dimensional molecular atlases of human tissues. The application of these technologies to the human kidney will provide a new paradigm of understanding the normal state of this organ across multiple dimensions, both molecular (e.g., lipids, metabolites, proteins, and RNA) and spatial (e.g., whole organs to single cells).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latino populations have a high burden of type II diabetes leading to worse health outcomes. Telemedicine has been shown to improve diabetes outcomes but is under-utilized among Latino patients. To inform telemedicine implementation strategies and improve care, the proposed research will develop a multilevel, culturally tailored intervention to promote telemedicine use among Latino patients with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: By elucidating the mechanisms of radio-resistant DNA synthesis and the role of the BRCA2 tumor suppressor in DNA replication upon DNA damage, this study will advance our understanding of cellular response to DNA damaging agents and tumor relapse after the treatments. Results from this study may provide a scientific basis for the rational design of novel approaches to prevent therapy-induced cancer development and tumor relapse after radiation and chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite effective treatments and guidelines for care, glaucoma is the leading cause of blindness in Black Americans and represents a major disparity in health and health care. The proposed research advances public health by taking a community-engaged, population health approach to address the substantial public health gap between well-established guidelines for detecting and treating glaucoma and studies that document applications of these guidelines. This project aligns well with the missions of the NIH, NEI and National Academy of Medicine (NAM), as it works toward the elimination of preventable vision loss by approaches that go beyond the typical clinical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Of the 800,000 cancer patients who qualify for checkpoint blockade therapy each year, nearly 700,000 fail to respond. The purpose of this project is to identify molecules from gut bacteria that promote an anti-tumor response to checkpoint blockade therapy and discover their mechanisms of action. The results will lead to more effective cancer therapeutics that will increase the number of cancer patients who respond to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Metaplastic breast cancer (MpBC) is a rare, aggressive, highly lethal subtype of breast cancer, and the main therapeutic option for metastatic MpBC remains systemic chemotherapy, despite known resistance to most chemotherapy drugs. This proposal seeks to explore a targeted combinatorial approach consisting of simultaneous inhibition of two major pathways implicated in MpBC, the nitric oxide synthase and the phosphoinositide 3-kinase pathways, to eradicate primary tumor growth and metastasis. Our proposal will investigate the mechanisms by which these two pathways inhibit primary tumor growth and assess interactions between various cells in the tumor and its environment using specimens derived from murine MpBC models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because it adds to our fundamental knowledge about reaching and grasping behaviors of the upper extremity in infants with and without hemiparetic cerebral palsy. The application of new measurement methods, knowledge about healthy and impaired spontaneous arm and hand use, and response to treatment will enhance health and help reduce disability for the millions of individuals of cerebral palsy and other physical disabilities who need rehabilitation. Thus, the proposed research is consistent with NIH mission that pertains to the development of fundamental knowledge to extend healthy life and develop translational clinical research to help reduce the burdens of illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This renewal T32 grant application for a Pulmonary Development and Disease Pathogenesis Training Program seeks to continue support to recruit and train outstanding pre-doctoral and post-doctoral candidates, preparing them to advance science and make discoveries that improve the diagnosis and treatment of pulmonary diseases, enabling them to become future research leaders in research and medicine. This Program meets a critical national need to increase the quantity and quality of young investigators who can apply cellular, molecular, and genetic strategies to the study of lung disorders. There is an ever-increasing loss of M.D. and Ph.D. candidates from academic-scientific careers at a time in which unparalleled opportunities exist to identify mechanisms of underlying disease pathogenesis and to develop novel biomarkers, diagnostics, and treatment strategies to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infections by fungi pose an escalating health problem, with a global disease burden affecting billions and killing more than 1.5 million people annually. Successful completion of this project will deliver one or more optimized chemical compounds that can kill hard to treat fungi, especially cryptococcal species, and make current antifungal drugs work better by blocking resistance mechanisms. By providing valuable leads for future development into drugs, it will ultimately help generate greatly needed new, more effective antifungal antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinx (im)migrant populations experience a significant behavioral health burden while utilizing behavioral health treatment at lower rates than non-Latinxs, indicating an unmet treatment need. This study will investigate the role of social relationships – which are disrupted in the (im)migration process – in shaping behavioral health treatment-seeking in Puerto Ricans displaced by Hurricane Maria, who endorse high levels of behavioral health distress. The results of this study can inform culturally-congruent outreach efforts and treatment services for this community to improve behavioral health outcomes, while also suggesting routes to reduce future treatment disparities for Latinx groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The five-year focus of the University of Rochester Clinical and Translational Science Institute is on “translational research without walls,” moving beyond the physical and virtual confines of institutions, by accelerating integration of translational research with the Learning Health System, expanding innovative approaches to dissemination and implementation and creating a translational research data ecosystem that seamlessly integrates data across the translational spectrum, linking our research and clinical data warehouses and expanding education efforts across our pilot programs to achieve translational research data and analytic excellence. We will enhance translational research collaborations at the local and national levels across the spectrum of stakeholders, extending community-based participatory research, facilitating multidisciplinary team formation and expanding our local and national collaborations. We will educate the next generation of translational science workforce leaders, expanding our approaches to ensure competence in the collaborative, technical, and regulatory skills necessary to accelerate the translation of high impact research to clinical applications, and we will catalyze the development, implementation and dissemination of methods and processes that advance translational research locally and nationally across the CTSA Consortium. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The vaginal mucosa is a complex and understudied ecosystem. Despite the importance of the vaginal microbiota on reproductive health, the fundamental principles that govern microbial interactions and persistent colonization remain largely unknown. We will define the nutritional landscape and characterize the impact of nutrient acquisition and exchange on community dynamics during bacterial colonization and persistence within the vaginal mucosa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Cystic fibrosis-related diabetes (CFRD) is a common complication of CF that leads to worse lung function and increased mortality. While it is understood that patients with CFRD have differences in their sputum cultured microbes, how their microbiome differs in CF patients with and without diabetes is not known. This proposal aims to study the microbiome in CFRD, the influencers of glycemic changes in CFRD, and how the microbiome changes with glycemic modification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Successful vaccination to prevent COVID-19 requires that people be willing to be vaccinated and that the vaccine be easy and accessible for them to obtain. Appalachian Kentucky is a region experiencing high vaccine hesitancy, an important challenge that need to be addressed to reduce COVID-19 rates. We will study ways of simultaneously addressing willingness to be vaccinated and vaccine accessibility and see if addressing those problems increases vaccine uptake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the Deep South Center to Reduce Disparities in Chronic Diseases is to promote health equity and reduce the burden of cardiometabolic diseases, including obesity, diabetes, and hypertension, among Black Americans and low-income populations in our tri-state region (i.e., Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana). The Center represents a partnership between the University of Alabama at Birmingham, Tuskegee University, Pennington Biomedical Research Center, and the University of Mississippi Medical Center, along with regional non-academic partners to translate and sustain cardiometabolic research in real-world community and clinical settings. The Center is focused on expanding and diversifying the region’s research workforce, promoting equitable collaborations between researchers and non-academic partners, and advancing scientific discovery through synergistic research projects focused on multi-level, multi-domain interventions for the prevention, treatment, and management of cardiometabolic diseases in the Deep South.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Pancreatic cancer causes approximately 40,000 deaths every year in the U.S.A. and currently there is no effective treatment for tumors that cannot be surgically removed. More than 90% of human pancreatic cancers are caused by mutations in a protein named KRAS that works together with another protein called PIK3CA to promote cancer growth. The goals of this proposal are to clarify how PIK3CA causes pancreatic cancer progression and to test whether a drug that blocks PIK3CA can be used to treat this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Outreach Program To Inspire Minority and Underrepresented Students (OPTIMUS) at the University of California San Diego seeks to create an engaging cancer research fellowship program for underrepresented minority high school students in the local San Diego region. The program includes a mentored research experience, a cancer education curriculum, and a community outreach effort. Ultimately, OPTIMUS strives to increase diversity in cancer research and create a biomedical workforce that better reflects our diverse community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an epidemic of chronic kidney disease in Central America and mortality rates are highest in El Salvador and Nicaragua. This Field Epidemiology Site will recruit 800 residents of the most affected regions of each country including ~400 people with low kidney function at baseline, and ~400 people with high or healthy kidney function at baseline, including men and women. We will follow them for three years to examine kidney function and disease progression over time, and exposure to multiple environmental, social, behavioral and occupational risk factors as part of the Chronic Kidney Diseases of UnceRtain Etiology (CKDu) in Agricultural Communities (CURE) Research Consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Headaches in children are common, with a small proportion associated with brain abnormalities (e.g. brain tumors) that require emergent identification. However, a large proportion of children with headaches unnecessarily receive neuroimaging in emergency departments, exposing them to risks, such as an increased lifetime risk of cancer from the radiation in computed tomography scans. Our research will create the first decision-making algorithm that will allow physicians to determine the precise risk of emergent brain abnormalities in children with headaches based on clinical findings, allowing physicians to accurately identify those who require emergent neuroimaging and those who do not.

PHR: Metastatic breast cancer in the brain is a deadly disease with limited treatment options while other cancers have benefited from the advancement of novel targeted and immune therapeutics. In this study, we seek to investigate a novel strategy to eliminate metastatic breast cancer in the brain by repurposing proton pump inhibitors targeting fatty acid synthase.

PHR: Narrative: The goal of this proposal is to develop new technologies to probe protein kinases, which are key regulators of cellular function and important therapeutic targets. These technologies will be applied to study interactions between immune cells and cancer cells in the context of cell-based immunotherapy. Given the importance of protein kinases in a variety of different diseases, including cancer, the technologies and knowledge generated here should pave the road for development of enhanced therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL) Childhood cystic kidney diseases (CCKDs), such as Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD), Nephronophthisis (NPHP), and Meckel-Gruber Syndrome (MKS), are devastating disorders causing significant morbidity and mortality. While remarkable progress has been made in identifying genetic factors responsible for cyst pathogenesis, there remain large gaps in our knowledge as well as controversies regarding the function of the affected proteins and which of the associated pathways are at the etiological heart of these diseases. The mission of the UAB Childhood Cystic Kidney Disease Core Center (UAB-CCKDCC) is to work with the PKD Consortium and the Central Coordinating Site to develop and share cilia-related bioassay and reporter systems, relevant genetic models and biomaterials, and clinical data for CCKDs that will allow the research base to overcome significant obstacles and drive the translation of basic science discoveries into effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is increasing recognition that place matters when considering cancer outcomes, as a growing body of evidence is showing that structural and environmental factors related to neighborhood disadvantage are associated with cancer incidence, treatment, and mortality. However, there is a need for a more comprehensive assessment of the many different types of neighborhood exposures for cancer incidence for individuals as they change residential locations and accumulate socioeconomic and environmental exposures over the life course. In this proposal, we will consider the cumulative effects of historic neighborhood socioeconomic deprivation, racial segregation, environmental pollutants, and built environment exposures at different times over the lifecourse to better represent the neighborhood exposome for individuals in relation to colorectal, lung, and breast (female) cancer incidence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Even genetically identical bacteria may activate different subsets of genes leading to coexistence of diverse metabolic states and behaviors within a bacterial population. In this work, we will develop and apply high-throughput single-cell transcriptomics approaches to profile heterogeneous phenotypic states within complex bacterial communities such as spatially structured biofilms and reduced complexity microbiota. We will use the results to develop systems-level understanding of the fine-scale phenotypic structure and pave the way toward predicting the emergent properties of biofilms and natural microbiota.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our T32 training program proposes to equip MD clinical fellows and PhD post-doctoral fellows with the necessary tools (i.e., didactic training, experiential training, career development, and a trans-disciplinary approach) to perform high-quality clinical outcomes research in female lower urinary tract disorders and to serve as future leaders in this field. Developing this critical mass of highly-trained academic physician- scientists and researchers is important to address the many remaining unanswered questions in this field and to improve the lives of millions of women with bothersome lower urinary tract disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this project is to test whether an intervention to bolster the local food economy (increase fruit and  vegetable production) and develop programs that respond to the critical link between nutrition and development  of chronic illness can increase fruit and vegetable consumption, improve minority health, and reduce health  disparities. Community-centered efforts that build vital local food economies represent a major innovation that  integrates nutrition into the healthcare system and social safety net to reduce disease, lessen disparities, and  save billions of dollars in health care expenditures annually.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease of unknown origin (CKDu) has taken a terrible toll on young working families living in rural areas of Central America. This project aims to identify risk factors for CKDu and decline in kidney function in four Central American countries: Costa Rica, Panama, Nicaragua and Guatemala. We will assess work and environmental exposures, social determinants (e.g., vector-borne or zoonotic diseases; and exposure to toxins as possible causes. This work will be conducted though the SALTRA (Central American Program for Health, Work and Environment) network connecting locally-based universities, NGOs, governmental organizations, public health authorities and local healthcare workers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug overdose deaths have increased twofold in the past decade and are the leading cause of injury death in the U.S. Disparities in access to naloxone, an opioid overdose reversal agent, may be partially responsible for the growing disparities in opioid overdose deaths for American Indian/Alaska Natives and Blacks, whose overdose death rates now exceed those of non-Hispanic Whites. Our objective is to develop a novel, comprehensive place-based measure of naloxone availability and document disparities in naloxone availability so that naloxone-distributing entities can make data-informed decisions on how to increase equity in naloxone access to reduce racial disparities in opioid overdose deaths in North Carolina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Organ transplantation is a life saving therapy for pediatric patients with end stage renal disease, but all transplants eventually fail due to a process called chronic allograft rejection. In addition, opportunistic infections have emerged as a major cause of morbidity and mortality in pediatric kidney transplant recipients. In this proposal, we have assembled a consortium of experienced transplant centers to perform a clinical trial with potential to advance point-of-care, develop an understanding of pathogen-specific immune responses and promote long-term allograft survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Stigma remains a fundamental barrier to the HIV response in the US and around the world reflected as a priority by both government agencies and community partners. However, stigma data remains underutilized and stigma programs achieve limited scale if implemented at all. We posit that the proposed research builds on solid scientific premise and holds tremendous promise to advance the response to stigma and improve the quality of life of people affected by stigma in the US and ultimately facilitate progress in meeting HIV testing, prevention, and treatment goals as described in the Ending the HIV Epidemic Initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance – Penetrating electrode arrays can provide direct access to neural signals across the central and peripheral nervous system with high spatial resolution. Chronic electrode implants could revolutionize treatment for a range of medical conditions, including prosthetic motor control for amputees, and brain- machine interfacing for paraplegics. Unfortunately, device implantation causes an immune response that contributes to device failure over time. This project commercializes a device that uses acoustic fields to mitigate the immune response effects that cause electrodes to fail over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it proposes new approaches to characterize and address some of the most challenging problems in dementia caregiving, clinical management, and research; building on philosophical frameworks, social sciences methods, and up-to- date neurocognitive findings. Patient values are central to several key bioethical constructs in dementia such as advance care planning, while the centrality of values to relationships means that alterations in the values of people with dementia or how they express their values can contribute to caregiver distress. A fuller understanding of these changes from the perspective of people with dementia and their caregivers will inform approaches to support autonomy and to counsel caregivers in their efforts to adapt to these changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Worldwide, tuberculosis (TB) is the most common cause of death in patients with HIV, and the growing epidemic of drug-resistance threatens decades of gains in TB prevention and care. James Brust, M.D. is an accomplished clinician-scientist at Albert Einstein College of Medicine with a strong research program focusing on the interplay of drug-resistant TB and HIV in South Africa. This K24 proposal will support Dr. Brust to 1) expand his multidisciplinary research program into new areas, focusing on novel TB medications, and 2) develop a strong mentoring program for junior investigators in TB, HIV, and global health patient-oriented research at Einstein and at his international collaborating sites.

PHR: This Training Program in Academic Endocrinology assembles a group of outstanding clinical and basic scientists to oversee the training of fellows with an interest in understanding the mechanism and regulation of hormone effects and how they are disrupted to produce clinical disorders. The core goal of this Training Program is to train scientists and physician-scientists in diverse aspects of the field of endocrinology, with an overarching emphasis on translational research. Fellows will be trained in fundamental research techniques in order to contribute to the understanding and treatment of major endocrine disorders, such as obesity, diabetes, and osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In this pilot clinical trial, we will recruit and randomize 120 patients with diabetes and chronic kidney disease (CKD/DM) stages 3 to 5 to a patient-centered and flexible Plant-Focused Nutrition in Diabetes (PLAFOND) diet with >2/3 plant-based sources, which will be compared with a standard-of-care CKD diet, which is usually a low-potassium and low-salt diet, over a 6-month period. Through this study, we will determine whether the plant-focused diet intervention is feasible for patient adherence, whether this diet is safe by avoiding malnutrition, frailty, and high potassium or glucose blood levels, and whether patient reported outcomes are favorably impacted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative  Implicit Bias (IB) is a toxic and pervasive problem in healthcare that contributes to the preventable harm and death of Black patients. The work performed under this grant will produce the first-ever effective IB mitigation training system by virtue of its evidence-based focus on reducing providers’ nonverbal and paraverbal expressions of IB in race discordant medical encounters. It uses a new, distributable, AI-based Virtual Human (VH) simulation technology designed to heighten learners’ engagement and their awareness of IB, presenting them with detailed, personalized feedback and concrete strategies for mitigating IB by substituting positive nonverbal and paraverbal behaviors for negative behaviors and letting them reflect and practice their new skills over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A diverse array of chemicals and drugs including certain chemical warfare agents (sulfur mustard, lewisite), intravenous chemotherapy drugs (mechlorethamine-MEC, paclitaxel, liposomal doxorubicin), and environmental toxins (snake venom metalloproteinases and blister beetle cantharidin) can disrupt the dermal-epidermal junction (DEJ) and cause blistering, thereby placing a patient at risk for infection, loss of fluid and electrolyte homeostasis, and scarring; moreover, an effective antidote to blistering is still lacking and current medical treatments for blistering are limited to supportive therapy. The overall goal of the studies proposed here is to investigate the influence of rationally selected mast cell-derived mediators (histamine and tryptase), neutrophil-derived mediators (myeloperoxidase, MPO and matrix metalloproteinase 9, MMP-9) and keratinocyte-specific collagens (collagen IV, COL4 and collagen XVII, COL17) in the cutaneous response to DEJ disruption over time. The achievement of proposal objectives will more fully describe the complex response of skin to DEJ disruption and provide novel targets for the discovery of drugs capable of reducing blistering and restoring the DEJ.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of predoctoral training in Neuroscience at UCSF is to guide and educate future researchers who will make fundamental creative discoveries, develop innovative research strategies and apply their skills and knowledge as a basis for ultimately protecting and improving health. This proposed training program will play an important role in educating students who will become our future biomedical researchers, and we promote the highest level of scientific integrity, public accountability, and social responsibility in the conduct of science. Having a well-trained cadre of researchers is the principal means that we, as a nation, have for understanding and treating illnesses and disabilities of our own and the world’s population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative NACC (as U01 AG016976, at University of Washington — now seeking renewal as a U24) has been active since 1999, and has established a standardized, longitudinal clinical database of over 42,000 individuals (with neuropathology data on over 6,100), as well as cross-sectional, retrospective data on roughly 66,000 individuals seen at ADRCs between 1984 and 2005. NACC has made these data freely available to researchers worldwide, resulting in hundreds of publications. We will modernize and intensify our informatics approach, making data access and use more efficient; will grow communication and coordination capabilities with the ADRCs and collaborating NIA projects; will develop and apply big-data research tools for the field; and will provide competitive, peer-reviewed research support for several new investigators each year. Together with the field’s leaders, NACC will innovate, develop, and drive solutions to meet the changing needs of the field as well as the NIA ADRC program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The marmoset is an increasingly attractive non-human primate (NHP) model for understanding neurophysiology and there is a major interest in the field for using it to study neurodegenerative diseases, particularly to model the social and cognitive deficits that accompany them, which current animal models are unable to do. At present, no NHP models exist with trinucleotide repeat mutations at the endogenous allele as occurs in Huntington’s disease, in part because of limitations in the ability of the CRISPR/Cas9 system to introduce long stretches of DNA, as well as limitations in marmoset reproductive technologies. Therefore, we propose to establish a new strategy that utilizes the expanded developmental potential of ground-state pluripotent cells to generate animals that carry the precise human mutation through assistant reproductive technologies, which we believe will pave the road for transgenic marmoset models as superior preclinical models to transgenic mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gonorrhea poses an immense threat to public health due to rising prevalence and the emergence of antibiotic- resistant bacteria, underscoring the importance of developing new strategies to prevent and treat gonococcal infections. N. gonorrhoeae's evasion of serum bactericidal activity is critical to its ability to infect humans, but while some advances have been made in defining the genetic basis of serum resistance, the description of the genes and pathways that contribute to serum resistance remains incomplete and their distribution in clinical isolates poorly understood. This proposal will address these gaps by applying a synergistic combination of approaches: identifying new serum resistance mutations through application of systematic phylogenetics and computational methods and experimental evolution and comprehensive characterization of their prevalence and distribution in a dataset of >16,000 clinical isolates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is one of the most common causes of dementia and a growing public health concern in the United States. Age is the greatest risk factor for AD, and dietary interventions that can promote health span and extend lifespan have significant potential to slow or prevent AD. This proposal will test the hypothesis that dietary interventions or pharmaceuticals which mimic the effects of these diets to reduce activity of the protein kinase mTORC1 and activate autophagy in the brain can slow or prevent the development and progression of AD.

PHR: The project is relevant to public health because it is expected to result in an innovative application of advanced MRI technologies for guiding bacterial cancer therapies. This proposed multimodal MRI approach can be used to pre-select treatable tumors prior to the treatment by assessing tumor hypoxia and monitor bacterial cancer treatment in a real-time and non-invasive manner, providing new utility for pursuing the optimal efficacy while maintaining safety. Successful completion of the proposed study will provide robust image guidance that can ultimately improve the success rate of bacterial cancer therapies for treating inoperable solid tumors, which is highly relevant to the part of NIH’s mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: 7. PROJECT NARRATIVE The reliance on consumer choice and active coverage management in the Medicare program may place the nearly 6 million older adults living with Alzheimer’s and related dementias (ADRD) at increased risk of financial barriers to needed health services, substantial out-of- pocket health spending, and potentially worse health outcomes. This mixed-methods study will describe the Medicare choices of individuals with ADRD throughout the course of the disease, evaluate the impact of these choices on health and financial outcomes, and examine the role of family caregivers and baseline socioeconomic resources in mitigating potential adverse effects. Results from this study will inform policy makers about the implications of current program design on the equity of Medicare for individuals with ADRD and guide future policy interventions that can support this vulnerable population in managing their Medicare coverage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cervical cancer is a disease that predominantly affects women in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), as these settings lack the personnel resources and infrastructure to implement the cervical cancer prevention strategies that have virtually eliminated cervical cancer in high income countries (HICs). Cervical cancer is a rapidly worsening public health crisis that requires immediate interventions to meet the World Health Organization’s (WHO) metrics to achieve elimination of cervical cancer in the next 100 years. The Pocket CARE algorithm developed and validated as part of this proposal will make possible a single-visit model for cervical cancer screening and treatment that will help meet the key WHO metrics for cervical cancer elimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative About 6 million Americans suffer from heart failure and one third of the patients with heart failure die within a year of the diagnosis. While lower blood magnesium levels have been linked with the incident and outcomes of heart failure, it is unknown whether magnesium supplements (~$0.05 each pill) may lower that risk. We propose to interrogate national electronic health record data from Veterans Health Administration using novel pharmacoepidemiology methodology and develop explainable deep-learning models to help clinicians and patients make personalized decisions to maximize the health benefits of magnesium supplements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Approximately 1 in 10,000 children are born blind or become blind early in life, often due to problems associated with prematurity or complications during birth. Here, we will examine the anatomical, functional and behavioral changes that occur following loss of vision at three important developmental stages. These data can direct therapeutic interventions (e.g. tactile training based behavior), and even allow predictions for behavioral outcomes following retinal implants or gene targeted therapies performed at different ages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance to PUBLIC HEALTH: Old age can lead to a variety of changes and declines in memory, but healthy older adults may be able to selectively remember important information in certain situations. The proposed research examines how stress and rushing can influence how older adults remember important information, how older adults can selectively forget outdated information related to gains and losses, and how older adults may be susceptible to scams and financial fraud that focus on gains and rewards. We introduce ways that older adults can successfully identify features of scams such that selective memory can be used to prevent scams and financial fraud, and the findings have the potential to enhance the quality of life and independence of older adults by providing new ways to help older adults remember important information.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) Children in foster care are exposed to poverty, maltreatment, and out-of-home placement, contributing to poorer physical and behavioral health outcomes than other children in poverty. This study seeks to improve the health of children in foster care by using 12 years of linked child welfare and electronic health records (EHR) data (N ~ 9,600 patients) in combination with Medicaid claims data and caregiver and self-reported health status to evaluate the impact of healthcare delivery models on health outcomes for foster youth and examine factors associated with variation in healthcare use and health outcomes. Understanding relations between healthcare use and health outcomes can inform healthcare systems interventions that parlay to better health outcomes, with potential for spread, leading to long-term improvements in health for foster youth nationwide.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Examining the impact of healthcare systems changes on healthcare use and health outcomes for children in foster care

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Characterizing genetic signatures of natural selection on the human genome is fundamental to understand human evolutionary history and human diseases. In this proposal, we will develop and apply methods aiming at characterize the genetic signatures of natural selection (1) shaping the genetic architecture of human complex traits, (2) leading to different gene regulation and allele effect sizes across diverse ancestry groups, and (3) acting on genes at the exon and regulatory levels. To reach that goal, we will leverage large GWAS datasets, a new powerful conservation dataset, and multi-ancestry single-cell sequencing dataset.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Myocardial infarction is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in developed societies. Although therapies have improved outcomes, cardiomyocytes, the muscle cells of the heart, are lost because these cells lack significant regenerative capacity. This project will investigate how one signaling pathway, involving a kinase and inhibitors, may work to improve heart function after myocardial infarction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative In previous work, we have found that brain responses to different stimuli are more confusable (less distinctive) in older vs. younger adults and that age differences in the brain’s major inhibitory neurotransmitter (GABA) play a role. We propose to track neural distinctiveness and GABA in healthy people over a decade as well as in patients with Mild Cognitive Impairment in order to test if these neural measures predict behavioral impairments. This work could inform efforts to alleviate behavioral deficits associated with normal and pathological aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: NARRATIVE Influenza hemagglutinin is a model system for studying the mechanism by which enveloped viruses fuse membranes during entry into cells. The proposed research will lead to a better understanding of the mechanism of influenza and SARS-CoV-2 entry, specifically, and class-I viral membrane fusion in general. We will also biophysically evaluate avian influenza strains, as well as human pandemic strains that originated in birds to determine the mechanistic features that avian strains must acquire to infect humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative As a consequence of the widespread availability of antiretroviral therapy, HIV in children and adolescents in sub-Saharan Africa is evolving from a universally fatal illness into a chronic condition, often complicated by comorbidities including depression, cerebrovascular disease, and cognitive impairment. However, there are few longitudinal studies assessing these comorbidities in children and adolescents in low-resource settings. This prospective study of Zambian children and adolescents will identify risk factors and biomarkers for HIV- associated comorbidities that will set the stage for future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Degeneration of neurons within the brain and spinal cord lead to cognitive and motor impairment that is debilitating and life-threatening. Genetic forms of neurodegeneration are commonly caused by mutations in RNA- binding proteins, yet little is known about their role in neuronal development, function, and survival. The goal of the proposed study is to develop accurate pre-clinical models for inherited pediatric motor neuron degeneration, and to use these new resources to uncover novel pathogenic disease mechanisms.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative Research suggests post-operative pain management should be patient-centered and differ across patients based on many factors including pain experience and pain tolerance. A clinical decision support (CDS) tool based on patient data from the EHR is needed to implement a patient-centered opioid discharge guideline. This project will integrate the guideline as a patient-centered opioid prescribing tool (PCOPT) into the EHR of a regional health system andassess its effects on patient-centered guideline opioid discharge compliance and patient outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Development and Evaluation of a Patient-Centered Opioid Discharge Prescribing Guideline within the Electronic Health Record of a Health System

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Prevention and reduction of healthcare-associated infections (HAI) is one of the most important patient safety issues in U.S. hospitals and a major public health concern. Although 35-55% of all HAI are preventable, approximately 1 in 25 acute care patients in the U.S. will experience at least one HAI during hospitalization. Results from this study will inform both clinicians and policy makers on the evolving nature of infection control in hospitals and the staffing resources needed to ensure that HAI are prevented.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Prevention of Infections Through Appropriate Staffing (PITAS)
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Cognitive Computing of Alzheimer’s Disease Genes and Risk Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is devastating and its social and economic impact is projected to rise dramatically. Here, in order to discover genes that underlie its mechanisms and clinical risk, we fuse a new mathematical and machine learning framework with experimental testing in diverse models. The outcome will integrate vast amounts of data from evolution, from genome sequencing from experiments and from patients to guide clinical assessment of risk and open new paths for understanding the disease and for drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Social relationships are some of the most robust predictors of human health and mortality risk known to date. This project investigates how their dynamics across the life course are reflected at the molecular level, by combining a powerful animal model for human social behavior with genomic analyses of gene expression in the immune system. By studying the types and timing of the social ties that matter most, and by linking gene expression data with information on immune function and lifespan, this work will provide important insight into the mechanisms that connect social relationships to health, disease risk, and survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The optimal balance between carbohydrates (“carbs”) and lipids (fats) in the diet remains a hotly debated topic within both the scientific and medical communities, as well as the general public. In this proposal, we explore the molecular mechanisms responsible for the metabolic switch between carbohydrate and lipid metabolism in the liver, kidney and intestines. The results from our studies will enhance our understanding of the popular ketogenic diet and intermittent fasting, and shed light on the metabolic differences between males and females.

PHR: The ALDH1L1 gene in folate pathways has high frequency of non-synonymous polymorphisms with resulting haplotypes being different among human populations. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE The overall objective of the P30 ADRC at Columbia University is to support an elaborate but well-integrated research infrastructure to tackle barriers in the field of Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders, which include early detection, prevention and intervention. Embedded within this general objective, the Center’s infrastructure will focus on a group of biological pathways that have emerged as pathogenic drivers of AD. The Center will promote outreach and patient recruitment, provide a rich training environment, and will participate in all national coordinating efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Drosophila, with its genetic amenability and simple visual system, yet very sophisticated visual performances, is a very powerful model system to study how the visual system is built during development. Using the results of single cell mRNA sequencing, we investigate the mechanisms controlling specific connections among optic lobe neurons and how the formation of the different layers of visual processing is coordinated. The principles deduced from this project will be applicable to other sensory systems such as the mammalian retina.
